    io_num For the ED588, output pins are numbered from 0 to 7, allowing you to set or reset any of these 8 pins.For the ED527, output pins are numbered from 0 to 15, providing the ability to control any of these 16 pins.
    Io_state The status be to configured. 0 represents RESET and 1 represents SET.
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    Response: message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code

    CLI Command: python brainbox.py SetIO BRAINBOX_2 4 0

    Description for CLI Command:
    • SetIO: API called to the Brain Box through CLI Command
    • BRAINBOX_2: Aliased name of the Device
    • 4: Specific output pin number of Brainbox device to be Set or Reset.
    • 0: Setting the pin as Low(Reset)

  6. ReadInputs

    Description of the API: API designed to read the status of all input pins from a Brain Box device.
    RPC Command: rpc ReadInputs(CommandRequest) returns(ReadInputsOutputsResponse) {}
    Request: message CommandRequest {
    string device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    Response: message ReadInputsOutputsResponse {
    int32 num_of_ios = 1;
    int32 io_states = 2;
    .generic.CommandResponse cmd_response = 3;
    }
     message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    num_of_ios Represents total number of input pins. For the ED588, total number of input pins numbered from 0 to 7. For the ED527,there are no input channels
    Io_states Current Status of all input pins
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code

    CLI Command: python brainbox.py ReadInputs BRAINBOX_2

    Description for CLI Command:
    • ReadInputs: API called to the Brain Box through CLI Command
    • BRAINBOX_2: Aliased name of the Device

  7. ReadOutputs

    Description of the API: API designed to read the status of all output pins from a Brain Box device.
    RPC Command: rpc ReadOutputs(CommandRequest) returns(ReadInputsOutputsResponse) {}
    Request: message CommandRequest {
    string device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    Response: message ReadInputsOutputsResponse {
    int32 num_of_ios = 1;
    int32 io_states = 2;
    .generic.CommandResponse cmd_response = 3;
    }
     message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    num_of_ios Represents total number of input pins. For the ED588, output pins are numbered from 0 to 7(8pins) and for ED527,output pins are numbered from 0 to 15(16 pins).
    Io_states The status of output of brainbox. The two status 0(RESET) and 1(SET)
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code

    CLI Command: python brainbox.py ReadOutputs BRAINBOX_2

    Description for CLI Command:
    • ReadOutputs: API called to the Brain Box through CLI Command
    • BRAINBOX_2: Aliased name of the Device

  8. ReadInput

    Description of the API: API used to read the state of a specific input pin on a Brain Box I/O device
    RPC Command: rpc ReadInput(BrainboxReadIORequest) returns(ReadIOResponse) {}
    Request: message BrainboxReadIORequest {
    int32 io_num = 1;
    .generic.CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    Io_num Input pin number of BrainBox. 0-7 for ED588. Input pins are not configured for ED527
    Response: message ReadIOResponse {
    int32 io_state = 1;
    .generic.CommandResponse cmd_response = 2;
    }
     message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    Io_state Status of the input pin.1 represents Set and 0 represents Reset.
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code

    CLI Command: python brainbox.py ReadInput BRAINBOX_2 4

    Description for CLI Command:
    • ReadInput:API called to the Brain Box through CLI Command
    • BRAINBOX_2: Aliased name of the Device
    • 4: Represents 4th pin of the brainbox, for retriving its current status

Limitations of the driver

Compatibility: The driver only supports the ED-588 and ED-527 Module not work with other module.

Integration: Integrating the driver with other systems or software may pose challenges, especially if there are compatibility issues or dependencies.

Precautions to take before executing the driver

  • Make sure the Device is in connected with the station
  • Ensure to giving the valid channel number and state.

TESTING AND DEBUGGING

ASCII Commands and Response :

Command Response Description
%AANNTTCCFF !AA Set Device Configuration
#** No Response Synchronized Sampling
#AA00DD > Set Digital Output of Lower 8 Channels
#AA0ADD > Set Digital Output of Lower 8 Channels
#AA0BDD > Set Digital Output of Upper 8 Channels
#AA1cDD > Set a Single Digital Output of Lower 8 Channels
#AAAcDD > Set a Single Digital Output of Lower 8 channels
#AABcDD > Set a Single Digital Output of Upper 8 Channels
#AAN !AA(Data) Read Digital Input Counter
$AA2 !AANNTTCCFF Read Device Configuration
$AA4 !S(Data) Read Synchronized Data
$AA5 !AAS Read Reset Status
$AA6 !(Data) Read Digital I/O Status
$AAC !AA Clear Latched Digital Input
$AACN !AA Clear Digital Input Counter
$AAF !AA(Data) Read Firmware Version
$AALS !(Data) Read Latched Digital Input
$AAM !AA(Data) Read Device Name
$AAM0 !AA(Data) Read Device Model
$AAM1 !AA(Data) Read Device Location
$AAS1 !AA Restore Factory Defaults
$AARS No Response Reset the module to power-on state
@AA >(Data) Read Digital I/O Status
@AA(Data) > Set Digital Output
~AAO(Name) !AA Set Device Name
~** No Response Host OK
~AA0 !AASS Read Watchdog Timeout Status
~AA1 !AA Reset Watchdog Timeout Status
~AA2 !AAVV Read Watchdog Timeout Settings
~AA3EVV !AA Set Watchdog Timeout Value
~AA4V !AA(Data) Read Power On/Safe Value
~AA5V !AA Set Power On/Safe Value
~AAL !AASS Set Device Location

DOCUMENTATION AND SUPPORT

We were provided with the set of manuals from the vendor.

Manuals of ED-588:https://docs.rs-online.com/5b77/0900766b8125576e.pdf

Manuals of ED-527:https://docs.rs-online.com/1634/0900766b81255777.pdf

GLOSSARY

When developing a Brainbox driver, it's helpful to have a glossary of terms to ensure clarity and consistency in communication. Here's a glossary of terms commonly used in Brainbox driver development:

  • Brainbox Driver: Software module or library responsible for interfacing with Brainbox module.
  • API (Application Programming Interface): Set of protocols, tools, and definitions that allow software applications to communicate and interact with the Brainbox driver.
  • Command: Instruction or directive sent to a Brainbox robot through the driver to perform specific actions such as movement, I/O control, or program execution.
  • Response: Feedback or acknowledgment received from the Brainbox after executing a command, indicating the success or failure of the operation and providing relevant information or data.
  • I/O (Input/Output): Interface for interacting with external devices or sensors connected to the Brainbox relay module, allowing the driver to control outputs.
  • ASCII: ASCII TCP is a connection-based protocol, in which the client establishes a connection with the server and the server waits for an incoming connection from the client. Once a connection is established, the ASCII command set is used to configure devices, send data to devices and to read data and status information back from devices. This occurs until the client closes the connection.

C# document

Introduction

Brief overview of the GRPC

Like many RPC systems, gRPC is based around the idea of defining a service, specifying the methods that can be called remotely with their parameters and return types. By default, gRPC uses protocol buffers as the Interface Definition Language (IDL) for describing both the service interface and the structure of the payload messages. It is possible to use other alternatives if desired

Service Defintion

The purpose of this document is to provide a detailed guide for integrating the Python/C++ Drivers with C#. The driver will enable communication between the device and C#. It covers the software development process, including setting up the development environment, implementing the C# integration, testing and debugging, and integrating the driver with the C#.

The primary objective of the document is to provide a comprehensive guide for developing C# API’s. This includes detailed instructions, code examples, and best practices to ensure the successful development and integration of drivers with the C#.

Scope and objectives

  1. Technical Information: Document provides comprehensive technical details about the development of C# API’s including its features, specifications, and operational principles, offering users a thorough understanding of its capabilities and functionalities.
  2. C# API Overview: The document includes an overview of integrating the driver api’s with C# and leveraging its capabilities effectively.
  3. Driver Implementation: The document contains guidelines and best practices for implementing the C# APIS, ensuring compatibility with various operating systems and hardware configurations.
  4. Testing and Debugging: This section covers strategies and methodologies for testing the C# API’s by calling Python Commands, ensuring its reliability, stability, and performance under different conditions. It also provides guidance on debugging techniques to troubleshoot any issues that may arise during driver development or deployment.
  5. Documentation and Support: The document serves as a comprehensive resource for developers, offering detailed documentation on the C# Integration.

C# API DEVELOPMENT

Prerequisites for Waymo Application

Client system must have the following tools to be installed

  • Microsoft Visual Studio 2022 / Latest version
  • Python 3.11.6
    • Command to check python version: python –version
    • Make a note of the path where python.dll is located after installation and update the same in appsettings.json file. (Only during locally testing)

      • Description text

  • Pip version 23.3.2
    • Mostly pip comes as part of python builds in newer version
    • Command to check pip version: pip –version
  • Microsoft Visual Studio Code 2022 / Latest Version
    1. Once setup is downloaded. Please select the following individual component as well before installing.

      2. Description text

  • Install pyModbusTCP using the command – Needed for SC10.
    • py -m pip install pyModbusTCP
  • IIS 10 Express
    • Comes along with windows 10 operating system
  • Grpcio-tools 1.60.0
    • Command to install grpcio:

      • pip install grpcio


      pip install grpcio-tools


    • This is needed to execute python scripts/commands on CLI

Retrieving the source code

Clone the latest code from Github to Visual Studio . Pull the latest code from Git Explorer in Visual Studio and Start working on new driver development.

Description text

Using The API

  • Starting from a service definition in a .proto file, gRPC provides protocol buffer compiler plugins that generate client- and server-side code. gRPC users typically call these APIs on the client side and implement the corresponding API on the server side.
  • On the server side, the server implements the methods declared by the service and runs a gRPC server to handle client calls. The gRPC infrastructure decodes incoming requests, executes service methods, and encodes service responses.
  • On the client side, the client has a local object known as stub (for some languages, the preferred term is client) that implements the same methods as the service. The client can then just call those methods on the local object, and the methods wrap the parameters for the call in the appropriate protocol buffer message type, send the requests to the server, and return the server’s protocol buffer responses.

CREATING PROTO FILES

  • Create Proto File for the new device.
  • Plan the required API’s for the device and write up the api definition with request and response.
  • Create the message class for request and response separately.
  • There is an existing Generic Proto where we have common Request and Response like CommandRequest,CommandResponse.
  • Place protos in Protos Folder like below

    • Description text

Creating Client Files

Steps for writing the client file.
  • Write the RPC for each API Call and pass the required parameters specified in request of each API. Comment the securechannel lines while debugging locally.

    • Description text

  • Call the API using the stub object as below example.

    • Description text

GRPC Architecture

Description text

Repository Design Pattern

Steps to add the layers
  • Add the Service of the new device named devicenameService Fro EG: JanomeService and write down the implementation to call the repo layer
  • Add the Repository Layer and Interface Layer to write the definiciton and implementation to call the python or C++ Drivers to return the response to client back

    • Description text

Python script example for Prosilica_gt6600:

  1. python3 prosilica_gt6600.py GetDeviceDetails 192.168.88.88
  2. python3 prosilica_gt6600.py SetExposureTime ProSilica_GT 6600_1 100
  3. python3 prosilica_gt6600.py SetPixelFormat ProSilica_GT6600_1 Mono12
  4. python3 prosilica_gt6600.py SetGain ProSilica_GT6600_1 21
  5. python3 prosilica_gt6600.py SaveCameraConfig ProSilica_GT6600_1 GT6600_save_settings.xml
  6. python3 prosilica_gt6600.py LoadCameraConfig ProSilica_GT6600_1 GT6600_save_settings.xml
  7. python3 prosilica_gt6600.py GetImageFile ProSilica_GT6600_1 gt6600_getimage.raw
  8. python3 prosilica_gt6600.py SingleTrigger ProSilica_GT6600_1
  9. python3 prosilica_gt6600.py StartLiveStreaming ProSil ica_GT6600_1
  10. python3 prosilica_gt66 00.py StopLiveStreaming ProSilica_GT6600_1

Keyence CL3000 driver document

Introduction

Brief overview of the Project

The CL3000 driver project is focused on developing a robust software interface that ensures efficient communication between the CL3000 confocal displacement sensor and external systems. This driver enables precise control, data acquisition, and management of the sensor, ensuring accurate and reliable measurements for diverse applications, including surface profiling, thickness measurement, and material inspection. The project's goal is to streamline sensor integration and optimize its performance in industrial and research environments.

Purpose of the document

The purpose of this document is to provide a detailed guide for developing a driver for the CL3000 device. The driver will enable communication between the device and external software applications. It covers the software development process, including setting up the development environment, implementing the driver, testing and debugging, and integrating the driver with the CL3000 device.

The primary objective of the document is to provide a comprehensive guide for developed drivers for CL3000. This includes detailed instructions, code examples, and best practices to ensure the successful development and integration of drivers with the devices.

Scope and objectives

  1. Technical Information: Document provides comprehensive technical details about the CL3000 sensor, including its features, specifications, and operational principles, offering users a thorough understanding of its capabilities and functionalities.
  2. SDK Overview: The document includes an overview of the software development kit (SDK) associated with the CL3000 device, offering developers insights into integrating the sensor into their applications and leveraging its capabilities effectively.
  3. Driver Development: It outlines the development process for the CL3000 driver, detailing the steps involved in creating software that enables communication between the sensor and the operating system. This section includes information on APIs, libraries, and programming languages used for driver development.
  4. Driver Implementation: The document contains guidelines and best practices for implementing the CL3000 driver, ensuring compatibility with various operating systems and hardware configurations.
  5. Testing and Debugging: This section covers strategies and methodologies for testing the CL3000 driver, ensuring its reliability, stability, and performance under different conditions. It also provides guidance on debugging techniques to troubleshoot any issues that may arise during driver development or deployment.
  6. Documentation and Support: The document serves as a comprehensive resource for developers, offering detailed documentation on the CL3000 device, driver, and SDK.

Device Overview

Description of the device for which the driver is being developed

The CL3000 device is a confocal displacement sensor designed for high-precision measurements on various materials and surfaces. Key features and characteristics of the CL3000 device include:

  • Ultra-compact coaxial laser displacement sensor suitable for diverse applications.
  • Superior precision and accuracy, unaffected by external factors such as heat or electrical noise.
  • Multi-color confocal method for enhanced performance and stability.
  • Easy installation and integration, even in constrained spaces or on robotic platforms.
  • Effective on curved, uneven, and rough surfaces, ensuring reliable measurement across different target shapes and finishes.
  • Compatibility with transparent, mirrored, metallic, ceramic, and adhesive surfaces.
  • Lightweight design for easy integration with robotic systems, reducing vibration and equipment costs.
  • Utilization of ultra-bright light sources for stable measurements over the sensor's full range.

Overall, the CL3000 device represents a cutting-edge solution for manufacturers seeking precise, reliable, and versatile measurement capabilities for quality control and production optimization.

Technical Specifications of CL3000

Operating Environment

OS

Windows 10 (Home/Pro/Enterprise; 32 bit/64 bit)

Windows 7 (Home Premium/Professional/Ultimate; 32 bit/64 bit)
CPU Celeron DUAL CORE 1.7 GHz
Memory 4 GB or more
Interface

A PC equipped with either of the interfaces below:

USB 2.0/1.1 (operation is not guaranteed with connections via a USB hub)

Ethernet 100BASE-TX (operation is not guaranteed with connections to a LAN or via a router)

Microsoft C Runtime Library

The Microsoft C Runtime Library is required for the DLL to operate.

Run vcredist_x86.exe/vcredist_x64.exe included on the installation media to install the library.

Microsoft .NET Framework

Microsoft .NET Framework is required to run the sample applications.

Run dotNetFx40_Full_x86_x64.exe included on the installation media to install the software.

CL3000 Specifications are as shown below:

Number of optical unit connections Controller only: 2 units; using expansion units / relay units: 6 units
Interface EtherNet/IPR

Supports cyclic communication and message communication; RPI: 1 to 10,000 ms (0.5 ms units)

Maximum number of connections: 8, complies with Version CT14 conformance test

Cannot be used when using PROFINET, PLC link or EtherCAT
PROFINET Compatible with conformance class A. Cannot be used when using EtherNet/IP®, PLC link or EtherCAT
PLC-Link

The following PLCs are supported:

Mitsubishi Electric: MELSEC IQ-R Series, iQ-F Series, Q Series, L Series, FX Series

Cannot be used when using EtherNet/IP®, PROFINET or EtherCAT
Ethernet

Allows for measurement data output and control I/O via no-protocol command communication with PCs and PLCs

100Base-TX, capable of communication with CL-NavigatorN*1
USB Conforms to USB 2.0 HighSpeed, capable of communication with CL-Naviga- torN 1
RS-232C

Allows for measurement data output and control I/O via no-protocol command communication with PCs and PLCs

Baud rate: 9600 to 115,200 bps, data length: 8 bit, stop bit: 1 bit, parity: none / even numbers / odd numbers
Terminal (IN) 13 (supports function switching via software)
Terminal (OUT) 11 *2(supports function switching via software)
Ratings Power voltage 24 VDC +10%
Maximum current consumption With 1 optical unit connected: 0.86 A, with 4 optical units connected: 3.3 A, with 6 optical units connected: 4.5 A
Environmental resistance Ambient temperature 0 to 50°C 32 to 122°F
Relative humidity 20% RH to 85% RH (no condensation)
Vibration resistance 10 to 57 Hz, double amplitude 0.3 mm 0.01"; 2 hours each for X, Y, and Z axes
Monitor/Setting support software CL-NavigatorN

SDK OVERVIEW

The CL3000 Interface Software Suite contains a powerful SDK and helps to develop CL3000 application for Windows on desktop as well as on embedded systems.

With the well-designed and user-friendly API, we will need just a few lines of code to configure the run the device as it supports many languages like C++, CS, .NET languages.

File Structure and Usage the SDK(CL-NavigatorN_1_6_0_0)

The files required at execution are listed below.

CL3_IF.dll : DLL defines the interface for controlling user applications and the CL-3000 Series. CL control can be used to control the system, control the measurements, and modify/update settings. This DLL can also be used to control up to three CLs with one PC application. (However, only one CL can be connected at a time for USB communication.) When multiple CLs are connected, specify a value from 0 to 2 for deviceId when connecting over an Ethernet. Assuming that deviceId is set to 0 for IP address 192.168.0.1 and to 1 for IP address 192.168.0.2, specifying 0 for deviceId(in) when each command is sent results in these commands being sent to the controller with IP address 192.168.0.1.

Linking : The library can be linked implicitly or explicitly. To implicitly link the library, link with “CL3_IF.lib”. “CL3_IF.lib” was built with Visual C++ 2013.

Include files : Include the following header files in the necessary source files.

  • CL3_IF.h
  • CL3_ErrorCode.h

The Table below shows the Components of CL-NavigatorN_1_6_0_0 SDK Package

CL3_IF.dll The DLL
CL3_IF.lib The import library for CL3_IF.dll
CL3_IF.h The header file that defines the CL3_IF.dll interface and the error codes
Source Folder

The folder for the sample source code

The source code for the sample programs created in C#, VB.NET and C++

Steps To Be Carried Out

To build powerful Windows CL3000 applications carry out the following steps:

  1. Install the CL-NavigatorN_1_6_0_0 Software SDK.
  2. Install the desired free Microsoft Visual Studio tool.
  3. Prepare the C++ projects.
  4. Run the project.

Device Interface

  • USB for PC application

    This controller can issue control instructions from multiple interfaces (I/O terminals, RS-232C, connection to CL-NavigatorN via USB or LAN, and EtherNet/IP communications) simultaneously. However, it cannot receive any instructions from other interfaces while receiving a control instruction from an interface.

  • Ethernet / Serial / PLC-Link / EtherNet/ Profinet / EtherCAT for command control

    The Ethernet port on this controller can be used to communicate with external equipment in addition to connecting to our PC application software (CL-NavigatorN). To communicate with external devices, you can use the non-procedural mode (which has the same commands as RS-232C), EtherNet/IP, PLC-Link, PROFINET, or EtherCAT. The IP address, port number, subnet mask, gateway, etc. in the system settings of the controller will be used.

DRIVER DEVELOPMENT

Introduction to driver development for the device

Developers working with the CL-Navigator SDK who wish to create their own C++ applications but do not want to invest in a commercial Integrated Development Environment (IDE) can leverage free Microsoft Visual Studio tools. These tools provide a cost-effective alternative for building C++ applications while supporting .NET languages like C# and Visual Basic, both of which are compatible with the CL-Navigator SDK.

In the past, Microsoft offered single-language programming environments, but these are no longer available. Instead, users must install the full edition of free Microsoft Visual Studio, which provides all the necessary tools for building C++ applications alongside .NET applications. Below are two recommended free versions of Microsoft Visual Studio for developing C++ applications based on the CL-Navigator SDK:

  • Microsoft Visual Studio Express 2013 for Windows Desktop: Although this version does not include the x64 native compiler, it supports the creation of 64-bit executables using the x86-x64 cross compiler running on WOW64.
  • Microsoft Visual Studio Community: Serving as the successor to the Express Edition starting with the 2015 release, Microsoft Visual Studio Community is also available in a 2013 release. It offers functionality comparable to the full Professional Edition of Visual Studio.

Choice of programming language (Python or C++)

For developing the driver we have used C++.

Driver Implementation

The following drivers or APIs are developed and tested

  1. OpenDevice
  2. CloseDevice
  3. GetDeviceDetails
  4. ChangeAlias
  5. Get measurement
  6. GetjudgmentOutputs
  7. Select program
  8. Start storage
  9. Stop storage
  10. Clear Storage
  11. GetStorageIndex
  12. GetStorageData

gRPC API’s Description for CL3000

  1. OpenDevice

    Description for OpenDevice API: Establishes a connection to the CL3000, initializing communication for further operations.

    RPC Command : rpc OpenDevice(.generic.CommandIPRequest) returns(.generic.GenericDeviceModel) {}
    Request:
    message CommandIPRequest{
    string ip_address = 1;
    string com=2;
    int64 port_address=3;
    int32 device_id = 4;
    string file_path = 5;
    int64 device_model =6;
    optional string device_alias=7;
    int32 axis =8;
    }
    Parameter Description
    ip_address ip_address IP Address of the Device
    com COM Port Address of the Device with serial communication(ex. COM1) Not applicable for CL3000
    port_address Port address of the device with serial communication (ex. 1)
    Response
    message GenericDeviceModel{
    string instance_id = 1;
    string device_alias = 2;
    DeviceType device_type = 3;
    DeviceModel device_model_name = 4;
    optional DeviceStatus device_status = 5;
    string ipaddr = 6;
    string mac_addr = 7;
    google.protobuf.Value conn_handle=8;
    string port_name = 9;
    int64 port_address = 10;
    CommandResponse cmd_response = 11;
    }
    Parameter Description
    instance_id New instance for the device in the enumeration
    device_alias Unique identifier (alphanumeric) for every device in the enumeration
    device_type Indicates the type of device like Motion stage, Safety Controller etc (defined below in the DeviceType enum)
    device_model_name Indicate the model name for each device (define below in the DeviceModel enum)
    device_status Indicate whether the device is online , offline or not reachable (define below in the device status enum)
    ipaddr Indicate the ipaddress of the device
    mac_addr Indicate the mac address of the device
    Conn_handle Handle object to keep the device open
    port_name Port name
    port_address Port address
    cmd_response Indicates command response that describes API response code and its description (Defined below in CommandResponse)

    enum DeviceType{
    NONE = 0;
    SENSOR_3D = 1;
    MOTION_STAGE = 2;
    CAMERA = 3;
    IO_MODULE = 4;
    SAFETY_CONTROLLER = 5;
    ANIMATIC_MOTOR=6;
    }
    enum DeviceModel{
    DUMMY_MODEL = 0;
    ED527 = 1;
    ED588 = 2 ;
    JR3000 = 3;
    OPTOE = 4;
    BASLER = 5;
    SPiiPlusEC=6;
    GT6600 = 7;
    MOTOR = 8;
    }
    enum DeviceStatus{
    OFFLINE = 0;
    ONLINE = 1;
    NOT_REACHABLE =2;
    }
    message CommandResponse{
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_message = 2;
    }
    ParameterDescription
    resp_code resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_message resp_message Description of the response code

    CLI Command:python cl3000.py OpenDevice 192.168.1.20 CL3000_1

    Description for CLI Command
    • OpenDevice: OpenDevice is the name of the API.
    • 192.168.1.20: IP Address of the device
    • CL3000_1:Aliased name of the device

  2. CloseDevice

    Description for CloseDevice API: Disconnects from the CL3000, releasing all resources and deleting associated handlers to ensure a clean shutdown.
    RPC Command: rpc CloseDevice(.generic.CommandRequest) returns(.generic.CommandResponse) {}
    Request: message CommandRequest {
    string device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    device_alias Unique alias of the device
    Response: message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code

    CLI Command:python cl3000.py CloseDevice CL3000_1

    Description for CLI Command:
    • CloseDevice: API called to the CL3000 through CLI Command to Close its Connection
    • CL3000_1: Aliased Name for CL3000

  3. GetDeviceDetails

    Description for GetDeviceDetails API: Retrieves detailed information about the connected CL3000, including its configuration and status.

    RPC Command : rpc GetDeviceDetails(.generic. CommandRequest) returns (.generic.GenericDeviceModel) {}

    Request:
    message CommandRequest {
    string device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    device_alias Unique alias of the device
    Response:
    message GenericDeviceModel{
    string instance_id = 1;
    string device_alias = 2;
    DeviceType device_type = 3;
    DeviceModel device_model_name = 4;
    optional DeviceStatus device_status = 5;
    string ipaddr = 6;
    string mac_addr = 7;
    google.protobuf.Value conn_handle=8;
    string port_name = 9;
    int64 port_address = 10;
    CommandResponse cmd_response = 11;
    }
    Parameter Description
    instance_id New instance for the device in the enumeration
    device_alias Unique identifier (alphanumeric) for every device in the enumeration
    device_type Indicates the type of device like Motion stage, Safety Controller etc (defined below in the DeviceType enum)
    device_model_name Indicate the model name for each device (define below in the DeviceModel enum)
    device_status Indicate whether the device is online , offline or not reachable (define below in the device status enum)
    ipaddr Indicate the ipaddress of the device
    mac_addr Indicate the mac address of the device
    Conn_handle Handle object to keep the device open
    port_name Port name
    port_address Port address
    cmd_response Indicates command response that describes API response code and its description (Defined below in CommandResponse)
    enum DeviceType{
    NONE = 0;
    SENSOR_3D = 1;
    MOTION_STAGE = 2;
    CAMERA = 3;
    IO_MODULE = 4;
    SAFETY_CONTROLLER = 5;
    ANIMATIC_MOTOR=6;
    }
    enum DeviceModel{
    DUMMY_MODEL = 0;
    ED527 = 1;
    ED588 = 2 ;
    JR3000 = 3;
    OPTOE = 4;
    BASLER = 5;
    SPiiPlusEC=6;
    GT6600 = 7;
    MOTOR = 8;
    }
    enum DeviceStatus{
    OFFLINE = 0;
    ONLINE = 1;
    NOT_REACHABLE =2;
    }
    message CommandResponse{
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_message = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_message Description of the response code

    CLI Command: python cl3000.py GetDeviceDetails CL3000_1

    Description for CLI Command:
    • GetDeviceDetails: API called to the CL3000 through CLI Command
    • CL3000_1: Aliased Name for CL3000

  4. ChangeAlias

    Description for ChangeAlias API: Updates the alias of the device, allowing it to be referenced by a new identifier.
    RPC Command: rpc changeAlias(ChangeAliasRequest) returns (CommandResponse) {} Request: message ChangeAliasRequest{
    string current_alias=1;
    string new_alias=2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    current_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    new_alias The device_alias to change to
    Response: message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code

    CLI Command:python CL3000.py changeAlias current_alias new_alias

    Description for CLI Command:
    • ChangeAlias: API called to the CL3000 through CLI Command to get new alias name
    • current_alias: The current device_alias used to refer to the device
    • new_alias: The device_alias to change to

  5. GetMeasurementValue

    Description of the API: API is designed to retrieve the measurement value from a specified output channel (OUT).
    RPC Command: rpc GetMeasurementValue (InfoRequest) returns (GetMeasurementValueResponse) {}
    Request: message InfoRequest {
    CommandRequest cmd_request = 1;
    int32 out_number = 2;
    }
     message CommandRequest {
    string device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    out_number OUT channel number (OUT1 /OUT2…OUT8)
    Response: message GetMeasurementValueResponse {
    MeasurementModel measure_model = 1;
    CommandResponse cmd_response = 2;
    }
     message MeasurementModel {
    optional float measured_value = 1;
    optional int32 measurement_info = 2;
    string display_unit = 3;
    }
     message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    Measured value Value of the measurement
    measurememt_info Describe the measured value (Valid, Invalid, Judgment standby, Outside of display range)

    0 Valid data

    1 Judgment standby

    2 Invalid data

    3 Outside of display range (+)

    4 Outside of display range (−)

    display_unit Display unit info (In mm / um etc)
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code

    CLI Command:python cl3000.py GetMeasurementValueSingle CL3000_1 0

    Description for CLI Command:
    • GetMeasurementValueSingle: Name of the API
    • CL3000_1: Alias of the Device
    • 0: OUT Channel Number (Ranges from 0 to 7)

  6. GetJudgementOutput

    Description of the API: Gets the Judgement of the measurement value of the specified OUT Channel
    RPC Command: rpc GetJudgementOutput(InfoRequest) returns (GetJudgementResponse) {}
    Request: message InfoRequest {
    CommandRequest cmd_request = 1;
    int32 out_number = 2;
    }
     message CommandRequest {
    string device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    out_number Out Channel number (OUT1 /OUT2…OUT8)
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    Response: message GetJudgementResponse {
    JudgmentModel judgement_model = 1;
    CommandResponse cmd_response = 2;
    }
     message JudgmentModel {
    optional int32 judgement_info = 1;
    }
     message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    judgement_info Describes the measured value: HI/GO/LO based on tolerance value set

    0 Judgment standby

    1 Higher than the tolerance upper limit

    2 Within the tolerance range

    4 Lower than tolerance lower limit

    5 Invalid data

    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code

    CLI Command:python cl3000.py GetJudgementOutputSingle CL3000_1 0

    Description for CLI Command:
    • GetJudgementOutputSingle:API called to the CL3000 through CLI Command
    • CL3000_1: Alias of the Device
    • 0: OUT Channel Number (Ranges from 0 to 7)

  7. SelectProgram

    Description of the API: API is used to select a specific program from the CL3000 device from available program list.
    RPC Command: rpc SelectProgram(SelectProgramRequest)returns(CommandResponse){}
    Request: message SelectProgramRequest {
    CommandRequest cmd_request = 1;
    int32 program_number = 2;
    }
     message CommandRequest {
    string device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    program_number Program number to be selected, ranges Program No. 00 to 07
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    Response: message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code

    CLI Command: python cl3000.py SelectProgram CL3000_1 0

    Description for CLI Command:
    • SelectProgram: API called to the CL3000 through CLI Command
    • CL3000_1: Alias of the Device
    • 0: Number of the Program to selected

  8. StartStorage

    Description of the API: API is used to initiate the storage functionality on the CL3000 device.
    RPC Command: rpc StartStorage(CommandRequest)returns(CommandResponse){}
    Request: message CommandRequest {
    string device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    Response: message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code

    CLI Command:python cl3000.py StartStorage CL3000_1

    Description for CLI Command:
    • StartStorage:API called to the CL3000 through CLI Command
    • CL3000_1: Alias of the Device

  9. StopStorage

    Description of the API: API is used to terminate the storage process that was previously started on the CL3000 device.
    RPC Command: rpc StopStorage(CommandRequest)returns(CommandResponse){}
    Request: message CommandRequest {
    string device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    Response: message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code

    CLI Command:python cl3000.py StopStorage CL3000_1

    Description for CLI Command:
    • StopStorage: API called to the CL3000 through CLI Command
    • CL3000_1: Alias of the Device

  10. ClearStorage

    Description of the API: API is used to delete all stored data or measurements from the device's internal storage.
    RPC Command: rpc ClearStorage(CommandRequest)returns(CommandResponse){}
    Request: message CommandRequest {
    string device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    Response: message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code

    CLI Command:python cl3000.py ClearStorage CL3000_1

    Description for CLI Command:
    • ClearStorage: API called to the CL3000 through CLI Command
    • CL3000_1: Alias of the Device

  11. GetStorageIndex

    Description of the API: To get last index of stored data
    RPC Command: rpc GetStorageIndex (CommandRequest)returns(StorageIndexResponse){}
    Request: message CommandRequest {
    string device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    Response: message StorageIndexResponse {
    GetStorageIndexModel storage_index = 1;
    CommandResponse cmd_response = 2;
    }
     message GetStorageIndexModel {
    optional int32 index = 1;
    }
     message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    index Recent index of the stored data
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code

    CLI Command: python cl3000.py GetStorageIndex CL3000_1

    Description for CLI Command:
    • GetStorageIndex:API called to the CL3000 through CLI Command
    • CL3000_1: Alias of the Device

  12. Get storage Data

    Description of the API: API is used to retrieve stored data from the device and save it to a specified file.
    RPC Command: rpc GetStorageData (GetStorageDataRequest)returns(GetStorageDataResponse){}
    Request: message GetStorageDataRequest {
    CommandRequest cmd_request = 1;
    int32 start_index = 2;
    int32 request_datacount = 3;
    string file_path = 4;
    }
     message CommandRequest {
    int64 device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    start_index Starting index from which data to be retrieved
    request_datacount Data count to be retrieved
    file_path Path to the file to save the data
    Response: message GetStorageDataResponse {
    GetStorageDataModel storage_data = 1;
    CommandResponse cmd_response = 2;
    }
     message GetStorageDataModel {
    int32 next_Index = 1;
    int32 obtained_data_count = 2;
    }
     message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    next_Index Index that can be used to retrieve the data next time
    obtained_data_count Data count retrieved
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code

    CLI Command: python cl3000.py GetStorageData CL3000_1 0 10 File/cl3000_storage.csv

    Description for CLI Command:
    • GetStorageData: API called to the CL3000 through CLI Command
    • CL3000_1: Alias of the Device
    • 0: Starting index from which data to be retrieved
    • 10: Data count to be retrieved
    • File/cl3000_storage.csv: Path to the file to save the data

Limitations of the driver

While the CL3000 has impressive capabilities in high-precision measurement across various surfaces and materials, it's essential to acknowledge its limitations. Here are some potential constraints or limitations associated with the CL3000:

  1. Target Material Compatibility: While the CL3000 is designed to measure accurately on various surfaces, including transparent, mirrored, metallic, ceramic, and adhesive surfaces, there may be limitations in measuring certain types of materials or surfaces with extreme properties, such as highly reflective or absorptive materials.
  2. Measurement Range: Like any sensor, the CL3000 may have limitations in its measurement range. While it offers stable measurement over its full range, there may be constraints in terms of the minimum and maximum distances or displacements it can accurately measure.
  3. Environmental Factors: Although the CL3000 is designed to minimize the influence of external factors such as heat or electrical noise, extreme environmental conditions such as high temperatures, electromagnetic interference, or vibrations may still affect its performance.
  4. Complex Surfaces: While the CL3000 is effective on curved, uneven, and rough surfaces, there may be limitations in measuring extremely complex surfaces with intricate geometries or features.
  5. Integration Complexity: Integrating the CL3000 into specific applications or systems may require additional hardware, software, or customization, depending on the requirements of the application. Complex integration scenarios may pose challenges in terms of compatibility, calibration, or synchronization with other devices.
  6. Maintenance and Calibration: Like any precision instrument, the CL3000 may require regular maintenance and calibration to ensure accurate and reliable performance over time. Failure to perform proper maintenance or calibration may lead to degradation in measurement accuracy.

Precautions to take before executing the driver

  • Make sure to use the solution provided directly.
  • Make sure to add stdafx.h at the beginning to avoid cout, endl errors, std library errors.
  • We can’t build the solution at once. It will give below error as second project uses first project’s dll which is dependent in the build process. Try checking with individual project builds.
  • Make sure to set 64 bit and not 32 bit for C++ and C# projects to avoid the system exception issue as shown below.
  • Max Storage Index when buffer full is 100000.
  • Before storing data, there are a few settings to be configured in CL-Navigator. For Example, selecting OUT values to be stored. By default, no OUT is selected. So, storage won’t be started even you get success response. (Go to tools à Data storage in CL navigator for settings).

TESTING AND DEBUGGING

There are two types of error codes

  1. Return codes returned by the communication library
  2. Return codes returned from the controller

Return codes returned by the communication library

Specifically, these codes are returned when the library fails to communicate with the controller or when processing could not be completed due to a state dependency in the communication library.

Error Definition Error Code Description
CL3IF_RC_OK Err-0 Success
CL3IF_RC_ERR_INITIALIZE Err-100 Failed to initialize the communication library
CL3IF_RC_ERR_NOT_PARAM Err-100 A parameter is abnormal
CL3IF_RC_ERR_USB Err-102 A USB error occurred
CL3IF_RC_ERR_ETHERNET Err-103 An Ethernet error occurred
CL3IF_RC_ERR_CONNECT Err-105 An Ethernet communication error occurred
CL3IF_RC_ERR_TIMEOUT Err-106 A timeout error occurred
CL3IF_RC_ERR_CHECKSUM Err-110 A checksum error occurred
CL3IF_RC_ERR_LIMIT_CONTROL_ERROR Err-120 An error occurred due to export controls between the DLL and the connected device
CL3IF_RC_ERR_UNKNOWN Err-127 An unknown error occurred

Return codes returned from the controller

Return codes are returned when communication with the controller is successful but the controller cannot process the command (or other similar situations).

Setting error

Error Definition Error Code Error Description
Command format error Err-71 The command length or format is incorrect
Timeout error Err-72 5 seconds passed for the receive interval per character of the ASCII command
Command length error Err-73 The command length of the communication command is invalid
Undefined command error Err-74 An undefined command was received
Status error Err-81 The controller can not receive communication commands
Parameter count error Err-82 The parameter count of the communication command is invalid
Parameter range error Err-83 The setting value is outside the permitted range
Command-specific error Err-84 or higher A command-specific error has occurred
The storage start/stop signal has been assigned to an input terminal Err-84
The storage buffer is full Err-85

System error

Error Definition Error Code Error Description
Head 01 to Head 06 error Err-01 to 06 Failed to communicate with the optical unit for Head n (n: Head No.)
Head not connected error Err-11 No optical unit is found
Connected head count error Err-13 Number of connected optical units has exceeded the maximum connection limit
Add-on unit error Err-16 to 17 Failed to communicate with the add-on unit (such as the encoder unit)
Connected expansion unit count error Err-19 Number of connected expansion units has exceeded the maximum connection limit
Same expansion unit type error Err-20 TThe same type of the expansion unit is connected
Controller device error Err-21 An error has occurred in the internal device of the controller
Controller memory error Err-22 to 25 An error has occurred in the internal memory of the controller
Combination model mismatch error Err-27 The optical unit (CL-***N (end is “N”)) can be connected only to the CL-3000 controller. It does not work with a controller of a different model
Controller error Err-31 to 33, Err-35 An operational error has occurred in the controller
Ethernet communication error Err-36 An error has occurred in the Ethernet communication device of the controller
USB communication error Err-37 An error has occurred in the USB communication device of the controller
RS-232C communication error Err-38 An error has occurred in the RS-232C communication device of the controller

Measurement Value Info

Code Description
0 Valid data
1 Judgment standby
2 Invalid data
3 Outside of display range (+)
4 Outside of display range (−)

Judgement Info

Code Description
0 Judgment standby
1 Higher than the tolerance upper limit
2 Within the tolerance range
4 Lower than tolerance lower limit
5 Invalid data

System configuration info

Code Description
0 Device Type: Invalid
1 Device Type: Controller
17 Device Type: Optical Unit 1
18 Device Type: Optical Unit 2
19 Device Type: Optical Unit 3
20 Device Type: Optical Unit 4
21 Device Type: Optical Unit 5
22 Device Type: Optical Unit 6
65 Device Type: Expansion Unit 1
46 Device Type: Expansion Unit 2

RESOURCES AND LINKS

  • Website Links: https://www.keyence.com/products/measure/laser-1d/cl-3000/downloads/?mode=ma&modelId=PM_2613000
  • Download page: https://www.keyence.com/products/measure/laser-1d/cl-3000/downloads/?mode=so&modelId=PM_2613000
  • Youtube videos: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=_sJS675jfv0&list=PLhvuOR396FzvaE_3PW0feh_Mxd9xaQxxm

GLOSSARY

Here's a glossary of terms related to the CL3000 device:

  • Confocal Displacement Sensor: A type of sensor that measures the distance or displacement of an object by using confocal microscopy principles, typically employing laser light to achieve high precision.
  • Ultra-compact Coaxial Laser Displacement Sensor: The CL3000 is described as an ultra-compact coaxial laser displacement sensor, indicating its small size and the use of coaxial laser technology for displacement measurement.
  • High Precision Measurement: Refers to the accuracy and repeatability of measurements provided by the CL3000 sensor, indicating its capability to measure distances or displacements with great accuracy.
  • Manufacturing Challenges: Refers to obstacles or difficulties faced in the manufacturing process, such as ensuring product quality, preventing defects, and increasing production efficiency.
  • Heat and Electrical Noise: Environmental factors that can affect measurement accuracy, with the CL3000 claimed to be unaffected by such influences due to its design and construction.
  • Multi-color Confocal Method: A confocal measurement technique that uses multiple colors of light to improve measurement performance and stability.
  • Operation Indicator: A visual indicator on the CL3000 sensor that provides feedback on its operational status, designed to be visible even from a distance.
  • Optical Unit: The part of the sensor that contains optical components such as lenses and light sources, designed to be minimally impacted by external factors.
  • Fixture for Thickness Measurement: An adjustable fixture used for measuring the thickness of objects, designed to ensure accurate and precise measurements.
  • Integration with Robots: The capability of the CL3000 sensor to be easily mounted on robotic systems for automated measurement tasks.
  • LPD Light Source: Stands for "Low Power Density" light source, used in the CL3000 sensor to generate stable and bright multi-color light for measurement purposes.
  • Non-contact Measurement: Refers to the CL3000's ability to measure distances or displacements without physically touching the target object, enabling measurement on delicate or sensitive surfaces.
  • WOW64: Stands for "Windows 32-bit on Windows 64-bit," a subsystem of the Windows operating system that allows 32-bit applications to run on 64-bit versions of Windows.

Animatic motor driver document

Introduction

Brief overview of the project

This project focuses on developing drivers for animatic smart motors (sm23165d-cds7) to be utilized in automation applications, with a particular emphasis on integrating them with a user interface (UI) application for future use. The project aims to create software components that enable seamless communication between the animatic motor and the UI application, allowing for intuitive control and monitoring of the motion systems. Through this integration, the project seeks to enhance the usability and functionality of animatic motors within automated processes, contributing to increased efficiency and productivity in various industrial settings.

Purpose of the document

The purpose of this document is to provide a detailed guide for developing a driver for the Animatic Motor device. The driver will enable communication between the Motor and external software applications, allowing to control speed, direction, Returning Home, and many more. It covers the software development process, including setting up the development environment, implementing the driver, testing, and debugging, and integrating the driver with the Animatic Motor.

The primary objective of the document is to provide a comprehensive guide for developed drivers for Animatic Motor(sm23165d-cds7) used in automation using a UI application. This includes detailed instructions, software installation guide, a device description with its features, and best practices to ensure the successful development and integration of drivers with the devices.

Scope and objectives

  1. Driver Development: The document focuses on the development of a driver for Animatic Motor using industry-standard protocols.
  2. Technical Information: It includes technical specifications of the device, hardware and software requirements, and information about the Software Development Kit (SDK) provided for the device.
  3. SDK Overview: Introduction to SMI Interface and its Installation.
  4. Driver Implementation: It covers the development process, including the choice of programming language, information on APIs, how to use APIs, limitations of the driver, precautions to take before execution, and the actual implementation of the driver.
  5. Testing and Debugging: scope extends to testing and debugging procedures to ensure the reliability and functionality of the driver for real-time application.
  6. Documentation and Support: Lastly, the document includes information on documentation standards and support resources available for developers.
  7. Overall, the aim is to facilitate the successful development and implementation of the Animatic Motor, ensuring it meets the required standards and serves its intended purpose effectively.

Device Overview

The Moog Animatics SmartMotor ™servo is an industrial servo motor with a motion controller integrated into a compact package. Its design is based on these objectives:

  1. Reduce development time
  2. Lower machine-production cost
  3. Simplify the machine (design, build and support)

The Class 5 Animatic Motor is a highly programmable, fully integrated servo motor system that incorporates a motor, an encoder, an amplifier, a controller, serial communication, and IOs in one compact package. They also feature fieldbus communications options and optional Combitronic™ technology, which allows a network of Smart Motors to become one, giant parallel-processing system. All D-style SmartMotor™ have a primary RS-232 communications port, 7 channels 5V TTL non-isolated I/O, optional 10 channels expanded 24 VDC isolated I/O, dedicated encoder out, Combitronic communications option, fieldbus communication options, and much more.

The Smart Motor is powerful and unique because of its ability to control an entire machine. The combination of programmability, networking, I/O and servo performance is unmatched. The Smart Motor brings savings and value to the machine builder by removing complex and costly elements in the machine design, such as PLCs, sensors, I/O blocks, cabinets, etc.

Description of the device for which the driver is being developed

The Class 5 Smart Motor is available in D-style and M-style configurations. The Moog Animatics Smart Motor is an entire servo control system built inside of a servo motor. It includes a controller, an amplifier and an encoder. All that is required for it to operate is power and either an internal program or serial commands from outside (or both). To make the Smart Motor move, the program or serial host must set a mode of operation, state a target position with/or a maximum velocity at which to travel to that target, and a maximum acceleration. After these three parameters are set, the two limit inputs are properly grounded or deactivated, and the Drive Enable input is satisfied (on M-style motors), a "Go" command starts the motion profile.

Following are the features of animatic motor

  • Full floating-point math and trigonometric functions with 32-bit precision results
  • Dual trajectory generators enabling relative and absolute position moves or velocity moves on top of gearing or camming
  • Advanced gearing allowing pre-set traverse and take-up winding parameters including dwells and wrap counts
  • Advanced camming including cubic spline interpolation and dynamic frequency and amplitude changes. Add onto gearing for complex traverse and take-up winding patterns.

  • Stand-alone, multi-axis linear interpolation with as many as 120 Smart Motors at a time
  • Virtual-axis control into camming through gearing, which enables stand-alone, multi-axis coordinated motion Programmable and non-programmable protection features (both hardware and software)

The core functional areas of the Smart Motor are:

  • Motion Control Functions (see Motion Details in the Smart Motor™ Developer's Guide)
  • System Control Functions (see Program Flow Details and see System Status in the Smart Motor™ Developer's Guide)
  • Communication Functions (see Communication Details in the SmartMotor™ Developer's Guide)
  • I/O Functions (see I/O Control in the SmartMotor™ Developer's Guide)
D-Style Motors All D-style Smart Motors have:
  • A primary RS-232 communications port
  • A secondary RS-485 communications port
  • Seven channels of 5 VDC TTL non-isolated I/O
  • Ten optional channels of expanded 24 VDC isolated I/O
  • A dedicated, single-ended encoder output

Technical Specifications of Animatic Motor(sm23165d-cds7)

Type Smart Motor
Model sm23165d-cds7
