Software Smart Motor Interface 3.0.0.77. Available for Windows

Software Overview and Requirements - Smart Motor Interface

SmartMotor Interface (SMI) Software for programming all SmartMotors Animatics’ SMI software provides an easy-to-use Microsoft Windows-compatible interface to your Animatics SmartMotor.

Using SMI, you can define multi-axis motion control for 1 to 100 SmartMotors. SMI includes a terminal program, program editor, and source level debugger.

Standard SMI features include a Tools menu to set PID tuning parameters and plot the step response, motor info and dynamic status tracking, and online help and documentation. The latest release of SMI can open multiple windows for program editing, instantly address multiple motors, and upload programs from motors. Simply write and download your application to the configured Smart Motor and reboot the motor to start your application working.

Features Of SMI

The SmartMotor™ Interface (SMI) is part of the SMI Pack, which features two programs designed to work together:

  • SMI — an interface used for communicating with SmartMotor™ servos and developing downloadable code. SMI includes many tools for diagnostics.
  • SMIEngine™ — a complementary source code module library, created as a software tool for the Windows Operating System environment. It comes free, with the installation of the SMI software.

Download SMI at no cost using the SMI Download button below and use the installation wizard to install SMI, SMIEngine™ and Coordinated Motion.

Moog Animatics’ SMI Version 3 software provides an easy-to-use Microsoft Windows compatible interface to your Moog Animatics SmartMotor™. Using SMI, you can define multi-axis motion control for 1 to 120 SmartMotor™.

SMI includes a terminal program, program editor, and source level debugger. Standard SMI features include a Tools menu to set PID tuning parameters and plot the step response, motor info and dynamic status tracking, and online help and documentation. The SMI software can also open multiple windows for program editing, instantly address multiple motors, and upload programs.

    Key Features in Version Smart Motor Interface 3.0.0.77:
  • New Program Editor includes undo/redo commands and group tabbing for more efficient programming
  • Smart Motor fieldbus network view and extended CANopen support for smoother fieldbus integration
  • Context Sensitive Help for instant access to full keyword descriptions
  • Revised help system provides documentation access when working online or offline
  • Pre-processor Extension for specifying include files, defining macros, and more, to speed up application development
  • The SMIEngine is a component library that uses the Component Object Model (COM) to define functions that perform the following tasks:
  • Configuring and communicating with Moog Animatics Smart Motors
  • Compiling/Downloading/Uploading/Debugging compiled user programs (“. smx” files)
  • Controlling the motors using Coordinated Motion (Contouring or Host Mode)
  • Creating circular and linear path coordinates used for Coordinated Motion
  • Polling Features to Monitor Functions:

The Moog Animatics Smart Motor Interface has special user-defined polling features to help you monitor important functions conveniently. Monitor different status bits, variables, and I/O from any motor in a chain, even during application execution.

    Using SMIEngine, you can perform the following tasks:
  • Configure PC serial ports
  • Address Moog Animatics SmartMotors™ through selected serial ports
  • Send commands to the motors and receive motor responses that allow you to:
    • Control and change modes of operation
    • Update or change motion parameters and variables
    • Gather real-time data from motors for online diagnostics
    • Control the motors using Coordinated Motion (Contouring or Host Mode)
    • Create circular and linear path coordinates used for Coordinated Motion
  • Work with downloadable SmartMotor code to:
    • Scan user program source files (.sms) for errors
    • Create an executable SmartMotor compiled user program file (.smx)
    • Download and upload compiled user programs to and from motors
    • Create a list of errors in a user program and provide an interface for navigating through errors

Hardware and Software Requirements

    Hardware / System Requirements:
  • Windows 10 (64 bit) or Windows 11 (64 bit)
  • PC with interface GigE
  • Intel Core i5 or higher processor
  • 8 GB RAM
  • Power supply for the camera- Power Over Ethernet
  • 5 GB of available hard disk space
    Software Requirements:
  • Smart Motor Interface Software Suite
  • Microsoft Visual Studio for C++ IDE for development
  • Additional software or libraries required by the SDK or application
    Additional Requirements:
  • This version of Microsoft Visual Studio works best with Internet Explorer 10 or higher. If Internet Explorer 10 is not installed on your computer, some features might not work as expected

Installing Smart Motor Interface Software

This topic explains how to install the Smart Motor Interface for Windows.

System Requirements

The Animatic motor Software Suite for Windows requires one of the following operating systems to be installed on computer:

  • Windows 10 (64 bit)
  • Windows 11 (64 bit)
Installation

To install the animatic motor Software Suite for Windows:

  1. Download the Smart motor interface (SMI) pack from the animatic.com
  2. Launch the downloaded installer.
  3. Follow the instructions in the setup wizard. The wizard will guide you through the installation process. During installation, you can choose the interfaces standard RS-232 serial port.

Software Development Kit

The Smart Motor Interface Software Suite also contains a powerful SDK and helps to develop any kind of smart motor application for Windows on desktop as well as on embedded systems.

With the well-designed and user-friendly API, you will need just a few lines of code to configure the run the motor.

It supports many languages like C ++, C, .NET languages (C#, VB.NET, etc.), illustrate various use cases for different grab strategies, multi-motor applications, Homing, Changing Speed and Direction and many more. Sample Programs, Development Guide can be find here

Driver Development

Users of the Smart Motor Interface Software Suite may want to build their own C++ applications without the need to purchase an integrated development environment (IDE). This application note describes an alternative way to build C++ applications using free Microsoft Visual Studio.

Microsoft stopped providing single-language programming environments. Therefore, it is necessary to install the complete edition of free Microsoft Visual Studio. This will automatically enable you to build C++ applications with .NET languages such as C# and Visual Basic (*) as well, which are also supported by the Smart Motor Interfaces Software Suite.

The following two free Microsoft Visual Studio tools are applicable to build pylon-based C++ applications:

  • Microsoft Visual Studio Express 2013 for Windows Desktop Microsoft Visual Studio Express 2013 for Windows Desktop does not provide the x64 native compiler. However, you can build 64-bit executables just fine using the x86-x64 cross compiler running on WOW64.
  • Microsoft Visual Studio Community Microsoft Visual Studio Community is the successor of the Express Edition starting with the 2015 release, but is also available in a 2013 release. It is comparable in its functionality to the full Professional Edition.

To get an overview of the Visual C++ features available in Microsoft Visual Studio, refer here

Steps To Be Carried Out

To build powerful Windows Animatic Motor applications carry out the following steps:

  1. Install the Smart Motor Interface Software Suite SDK.
  2. Install the desired free Microsoft Visual Studio tool.
  3. Prepare the C++ projects.
  4. Run the project.

Driver Implementation

  1. Get Device Details
  2. Open Device
  3. Close Device
  4. Change Alias
  5. Home the Motor
  6. Relative PTP Movement
  7. Absolute PTP Movement
  8. Set Velocity : -1953.125 to 1953.125 mm/sec
  9. Set Acceleration : 9.765625 to 24414.0625 mm/sec²
  10. Get Velocity
  11. Get Acceleration

gRPC API’s Description for Animatic motor

  1. GetDeviceDetails

    Description for GetDeviceDetails API:Retrieves detailed information about the Animatic Motor

    RPC Command : rpc GetDeviceDetails(.generic. CommandRequest) returns (.generic.GenericDeviceModel) {}

    Request:
    message CommandRequest {
    string device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    device_alias Unique alias of the device
    Request:
    message GenericDeviceModel{
    string instance_id = 1;
    string device_alias = 2;
    DeviceType device_type = 3;
    DeviceModel device_model_name = 4;
    optional DeviceStatus device_status = 5;
    string ipaddr = 6;
    string mac_addr = 7;
    google.protobuf.Value conn_handle=8;
    string port_name = 9;
    int64 port_address = 10;
    CommandResponse cmd_response = 11;
    }
    Parameter Description
    instance_id New instance for the device in the enumeration
    device_alias device_alias Unique identifier (alphanumeric) for every device in the enumeration
    device_type device_type Indicates the type of device like Motion stage, Safety Controller etc (defined below in the DeviceType enum)
    device_model_name Indicate the model name for each device (define below in the DeviceModel enum)
    device_status device_status indicate whether the device is online , offline or not reachable (define below in the device status enum)
    ipaddr indicate the ipaddress of the device
    mac_addr mac_addr indicate the mac address of the device
    Conn_handle Conn_handle Handle object to keep the device open
    port_name Port name
    port_address port_address Port address
    cmd_response cmd_response Indicates command response that describes API response code and its description (Defined below in CommandResponse)
    enum DeviceType{
    NONE = 0;
    SENSOR_3D = 1;
    MOTION_STAGE = 2;
    CAMERA = 3;
    IO_MODULE = 4;
    SAFETY_CONTROLLER = 5;
    ANIMATIC_MOTOR=6;
    }
    enum DeviceModel{
    DUMMY_MODEL = 0;
    ED527 = 1;
    ED588 = 2 ;
    JR3000 = 3;
    OPTOE = 4;
    BASLER = 5;
    SPiiPlusEC=6;
    GT6600 = 7;
    MOTOR = 8;
    }
    enum DeviceStatus{
    OFFLINE = 0;
    ONLINE = 1;
    NOT_REACHABLE =2;
    }
    message CommandResponse{
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_message = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    resp_code Unique alias of the device
    resp_message Description of the response code
    CLI Command: python animatic_motor.py GetDeviceDetails AnimaticMotor_1
    Description for CLI Command:
    • GetDeviceDetails: API called to the Animatic Motor through CLI Command
    • AnimaticMotor_1: Aliased Name for Animatic Motor

  2. OpenDevice

    Description for OpenDevice API: Establishes a connection to the Animatic Motor, Enabling Communication and Control.

    RPC Command : rpc OpenDevice(.generic.CommandIPRequest) returns(.generic.GenericDeviceModel) {}

    Request:
    message CommandIPRequest {
    string ip_address = 1;
    string com = 2;
    int64 port_address = 3;
    int32 device_id = 4;
    string file_path = 5;
    int64 device_model =6;
    optional string device_alias=7;
    int32 axis =8;
    }
    Parameter Description
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    ip_address Specifies the IP address of the device.
    com Indicates the communication protocol or interface to be used
    port_address Denotes the specific port address for the device on the communication interface.
    device_id Unique identifier for the device, used to distinguish it from other devices in the system.
    file_path The path to the file, which may include configuration, program, or data files for the device.
    device_model Represents the model number or type of the device being communicated with.
    device_alias A user-defined alias for the device, providing a more descriptive or convenient reference.
    axis Specifies the axis number (e.g., X, Y, Z) on which the command or operation will be performed.
    Response
    message GenericDeviceModel{
    string instance_id = 1;
    string device_alias = 2;
    DeviceType device_type = 3;
    DeviceModel device_model_name = 4;
    optional DeviceStatus device_status = 5;
    string ipaddr = 6;
    string mac_addr = 7;
    google.protobuf.Value conn_handle=8;
    string port_name = 9;
    int64 port_address = 10;
    CommandResponse cmd_response = 11;
    }
    Parameter Description
    instance_id instance_id New instance for the device in the enumeration
    device_alias device_alias Unique identifier (alphanumeric) for every device in the enumeration
    device_type device_type Indicates the type of device like Motion stage, Safety Controller etc (defined below in the DeviceType enum)
    device_model_name device_model_name Indicate the model name for each device (define below in the DeviceModel enum)
    device_status device_status indicate whether the device is online , offline or not reachable (define below in the device status enum)
    ipaddr ipaddr indicate the ipaddress of the device
    mac_addr mac_addr indicate the mac address of the device
    Conn_handle Conn_handle Handle object to keep the device open
    port_name Port name
    port_address Port address
    cmd_response cmd_response Indicates command response that describes API response code and its description (Defined below in CommandResponse)

    enum DeviceType{
    NONE = 0;
    SENSOR_3D = 1;
    MOTION_STAGE = 2;
    CAMERA = 3;
    IO_MODULE = 4;
    SAFETY_CONTROLLER = 5;
    ANIMATIC_MOTOR=6;
    }
    enum DeviceModel{
    DUMMY_MODEL = 0;
    ED527 = 1;
    ED588 = 2 ;
    JR3000 = 3;
    OPTOE = 4;
    BASLER = 5;
    SPiiPlusEC=6;
    GT6600 = 7;
    MOTOR = 8;
    }
    enum DeviceStatus{
    OFFLINE = 0;
    ONLINE = 1;
    NOT_REACHABLE =2;
    }
    message CommandResponse{
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_message = 2;
    }
    ParameterParameter
    resp_code resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_message resp_message Description of the response code
    CLI Command: python animatic_motor.py OpenDevice COM1 1 AnimaticMotor_1
    Description for CLI Command
    • OpenDevice: OpenDevice is the API called to the Animatic Motor through CLI Command to Connect to the Motor and Turn on the Driver
    • COM1: The communication port address for connecting to the motor.
    • 1: Represents the first motor detected at the specified COM port.
    • AnimaticMotor_1: Alias Name of Animatic Motor

  3. CloseDevice

    Description for CloseDevice API: Disconnects from the Animatic Motor, releasing all resources and deleting associated handlers to ensure a clean shutdown.

    RPC Command: rpc CloseDevice(.generic.CommandRequest) returns(.generic.CommandResponse) {}

    Request: message CommandRequest {
    string device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    device_alias Unique alias of the device
    Response: message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code
    CLI Command:python animatic_motor.py CloseDevice AnimaticMotor_1
    Description for CLI Command:
    • CloseDevice: API called to the Animatic Motor through CLI Command to Disconnect the Motor and Close the Port.
    • AnimaticMotor_1: Aliased Name for Animatic Motor

  4. ChangeAlias

    Description for ChangeAlias API: Updates the alias of the device, allowing it to be referenced by a new identifier.

    RPC Command: rpc changeAlias(ChangeAliasRequest) returns (CommandResponse) {}

    Request: message ChangeAliasRequest{
    string current_alias=1;
    string new_alias=2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    current_alias current_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    new_alias The device_alias to change to
    Response: message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code
    LI Command:python animatic_motor.py changeAlias current_alias new_alias
      Description for CLI Command:
    • ChangeAlias: API called to the Animatic Motor through CLI Command to get new alias name
    • current_alias: The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    • new_alias: The device_alias to change to

  5. ReturnHome

    Description for ReturnHome API: Moves the motor to its predefined home position by loading and executing the compiled homing program (in .smx format) on the motor controller.

    RPC Command: rpc ReturnHome(ReturnHomeRequest) returns(.generic.CommandResponse) {}

    Request: message ReturnHomeRequest{
    string command = 1;
    .generic.CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
    }
    message CommandRequest {
    string device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    command Compiled Homing Program File in. smx format is loaded into motor through command.
    device_alias Unique alias of the device obtained from enumeration API
    Response: message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code
    CLI Command:python animatic_motor.py ReturnHome AnimaticMotor_1 HOMING.smx

    Description for CLI Command:

    • ReturnHome:API called to the Animatic Motor through CLI Command to Return Home
    • AnimaticMotor_1: Aliased Name for Animatic Motor
    • HOMING.smx: Command which represents the path and file name of complied homing program

  6. AbsolutePTPMovement

    Description for AbsolutePTPMovement API: Moves the Animatic Motor to a specified absolute position (in mm) relative to the home position, which is considered the origin.

    RPC Command : rpc AbsolutePtpMovementControl(AbsolutePtpMovementControlRequest) returns(.generic. CommandResponse) {}

    7. Request: message AbsolutePtpMovementControlRequest {
    int64 position = 1;
    .generic.CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
    }
    message CommandRequest {
    string device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Parameter Description
    position Absolute position value provided in mm units to be moved by the motor.
    device_alias Unique alias of the device obtained from enumeration API
    Response: message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code
    CLI Command:python animatic_motor.py AbsolutePtpMovementControl AnimaticMotor_1 50
    Description for CLI Command:
    • AbsolutePtpMovementControl: API called to the Animatic Motor through CLI Command
    • AnimaticMotor_1: Aliased Name for Animatic Motor
    • 50: Position provided in mm.

  7. RelativePTPMovement

    Description for RelativePTPMovement API: Moves the motor to a user-specified position (in mm) relative to its current position.

    RPC Command: rpc RelativePtpMovementControl(RelativePtpMovementControlRequest) returns(.generic.CommandResponse) {}

    Request: message RelativePtpMovementControlRequest
    {
    double position = 1;
    .generic.CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
    }
    message CommandRequest {
    string device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    position Position provided in mm units to be moved by the motor Relative to current position.
    Motor Position Unit:mm
    device_alias Unique alias of the device
    Response: message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code
    CLI Command:python animatic_motor.py RelativePtpMovementControl AnimaticMotor_1 10
    Description for CLI Command:
    • RelativePtpMovementControl: API call to the Animatic Motor through CLI Command
    • AnimaticMotor_1: Aliased Name for Animatic Motor
    • 10: Relative position (in mm) specified for the motor to move.

  8. SetVelocity

    Description for SetVelocity API: Sets the velocity of the motor in mm/sec, defining the speed at which the motor operates.

    RPC Command: rpc SetVelocity(SetVelocityRequest) returns(.generic.CommandResponse) {}

    Request: message SetVelocityRequest {
    int64 velocity = 1;
    .generic.CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
    }
    message CommandRequest {
    string device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    velocity Velocity value to be set
    device_alias device_alias Unique alias of the device
    Response: message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code
    CLI Command:python animatic_motor.py SetVelocity AnimaticMotor_1 50
    • SetVelocity: API call to the Animatic Motor through CLI Command to configure velocity for motor movement.
    • AnimaticMotor_1: Aliased Name for Animatic Motor
    • 50: Sample Velocity configured in mm/sec

  9. SetAcceleration

    Description for SetAcceleration API: Sets the acceleration value for the motor in mm/sec²

    RPC Command: rpc SetAcceleration(SetAccelerationRequest) returns(.generic.CommandResponse) {}

    Request: message SetAccelerationRequest {
    int64 acceleration = 1;
    .generic.CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
    }
    message CommandRequest {
    string device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    acceleration Acceleration value to be set
    Typical Range: 9.765625 to 24414.0625 mm/sec²
    device_alias Unique alias of the device
    Response: message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code
    CLI Command: python animatic_motor.py SetAcceleration AnimaticMotor_1 100
    Description for CLI Command:
    • SetAcceleration: API called to the Animatic Motor through CLI Command to configure Acceleration for motor movement.
    • AnimaticMotor_1: Aliased Name for Animatic Motor
    • 100: Sample Acceleration Value configured in mm/sec2

  10. GetVelocity

    Description for GetVelocity API: Retrieves the current or target velocity of the motor in mm/sec.

    RPC Command: rpc GetVelocity(.generic.CommandRequest) returns(GetVelocityResponse) {}

    Request: message CommandRequest {
    string device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    Response: message GetVelocityResponse {
    float velocity = 1;
    .generic.CommandResponse cmd_response = 2
    }
    message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    velocity Current Velocity value retrived in mm/sec
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code
    CLI Command: python animatic_motor.py GetVelocity AnimaticMotor_1
    Description for CLI Command:
    • GetVelocity: API call to the Animatic Motor through CLI Command to Read current/ target velocity from the motor in mm/sec
    • AnimaticMotor_1: Aliased Name for Animatic Motor

  11. GetAcceleration

    Description for GetAcceleration API: Retrieves the current or target acceleration value of the motor in mm/sec².

    RPC Command: rpc GetAcceleration(.generic.CommandRequest) returns(GetAccelerationResponse) {}

    Request: message CommandRequest {
    string device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    Response: message GetAccelerationResponse {
    float acceleration = 1;
    .generic.CommandResponse cmd_response = 2
    }
    message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    acceleration Acceleration Value retrived from SDK in mm/sec2
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code
    CLI Command:python animatic_motor.py GetAcceleration AnimaticMotor_1
    Description for CLI Command:
    • GetAcceleration: API called to the Animatic Motor through CLI Command to Read current/ target acceleration from the motor in mm/sec2.
    • AnimaticMotor_1: Aliased Name for Animatic Motor

  12. EnableMotor

    Description for EnableMotor API: Turn on the motor driver, clear all Flags , Set Positive and Negative Limit Switch and Set Operating Mode for running all other APIs.

    RPC Command: rpc EnableMotor(.generic.CommandRequest) returns(EnableMotorResponse) {}

    Request: message CommandRequest {
    string device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    Response: message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code
    CLI Command: python animatic_motor.py EnableMotor AnimaticMotor_1
    Description for CLI Command:
    • EnableMotor: API called to the Animatic Motor through CLI Command to connect to the motor, turn on driver, clear all flags and set limit switches for executing other APIs
    • AnimaticMotor_1: Aliased Name for Animatic Motor.

GetCurrentPosition

Description for GetCurrentPosition API: Retrieves the Current Position of the motor in mm

RPC Command: rpc GetCurrentPosition(.generic.CommandRequest) returns(CurrentPositionResponse) {}

Request: message CommandRequest {
string device_alias = 1;
}
Parameter Description
device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
Response: message CurrentPositionResponse {
float current_position = 1;
.generic.CommandResponse cmd_response = 2
}
message CommandResponse {
int32 resp_code = 1;
string resp_description = 2;
}
Parameter Description
current_position Current Position of the motor retrived from SDK in mm
resp_code Response code from the device API
resp_description Description of the response code
CLI Command:python animatic_motor.py GetCurrentPosition AnimaticMotor_1
Description for CLI Command:
  • GetCurrentPosition: API called to the Animatic Motor through CLI Command to retrive current position the motor in mm
  • AnimaticMotor_1: Aliased Name for Animatic Motor

Limitations of the driver

  • Compatibility: The driver may only be compatible with sm23165d-cds7 versions of Animatic motors, limiting its use with other devices.
  • Integration:Integrating the driver with other systems or software may pose challenges, especially if there are compatibility issues or dependencies.

Precautions to take before executing the driver

  • Ensure that positions are within the valid range to avoid triggering the hardware limit switches (positive and negative switches), which would require the motor to return home.
  • Ensure to provide velocity and acceleration with the limit to avoid physical damage of the hardware

TESTING AND DEBUGING:

Following are the Error Types with Description for Animatic motor
Type Code Item Description Troubleshooting
FA1 EID_CX FA1 EID_CX A C/C++ exception occurred in the engine! Check the communications port driver. Please report it to Moog Animatics. Check the communications port driver. Please report it to Moog Animatics.
Ser. Com. FA2 EID_OPEN Cannot open a serial portthe ! Make sure:
- The specified communications port, exists on your computer.
- The port is not already open by another application, and it is not used by the serial mouse driver.
Ser. Com. FA3 EID_SETTIMEOUT Cannot set the timeout for the serial port! Check:
- The serial port driver.
- The serial connection to the motors.
- The power supply to the motors.
FA4 EID_CONNECTION Cannot establish a link to the motors! Check:
- The communications connection to the motors.
- The power supply to the motor.
- To see if there are more motors in the chain than are specified in the property ISMIComm::MaxMotors.
Ser., Eth., USB, CAN Com. FA5 EID_TIMEOUT No response was received! Check:
- The communications connection to the motors.
- The power supply to the motors.
Ser., USB Com. FA6 EID_ECHOTIMEOUT No echo response was received! Check:
- The communications connection to the motors.
- The power supply to the motors.
Ser., USB Com. FA7 EID_BADECHO Invalid echo response was received! Check:
- The communications connection to the motors.
- The power supply to the motors.
Other Com. FA8 EID_PORTNOTOPEN The communication port is not open! Open the communications port before using methods and properties.
Ser. Com. FA9 EID_OVERRUN A character-buffer overrun was detected! Check:
- The serial port driver.
- The serial connection to the motors.
- The power supply to the motors.
Ser. Com. FAA EID_RXOVER An input buffer overflow has occurred! Check:
- The serial connection to the motors.
- The power supply to the motors.
Ser. Com. FAB EID_RXPARITY The hardware detected a parity error! Check the serial connection to the motors.
Ser. Com. FAC EID_FRAME The hardware detected a framing error! Check:
- That the bit rates of Host and motors to match.
- The serial connection to the motors.
- The power supply to the motors.
Ser. Com. FAD EID_BREAK The hardware detected a break condition! Check:
- That the bit rates of Host and motors to match.
- The serial connection to the motors.
- The power supply to the motors.
Ser. Com. FAE EID_IOE An I/O error occurred! Check:
- The serial port driver.
- The serial connection to the motors.
- The power supply to the motors.
Ser. Com. FAF EID_TXFULL Output buffer overflowed! Check:
- The serial port driver.
- The serial connection to the motors.
- The power supply to the motors.
Ser. Com. FB0 EID_COMMUNKNOWN An unknown communication error occurred! Check:
- The serial port driver.
- The serial connection to the motors.
- The power supply to the motors.
Ser., USB Com. FB1 EID_READ Error reading from communications port! Check:
- The communication port driver.
- The communication connection to the motors.
- The power supply to the motors.
Ser., USB Com. FB2 EID_WRITE Error writing to the communications port! Check:
- The communication port driver.
- The communication connection to the motors.
- The power supply to the motors.
FB3 EID_INVALIDDATA Invalid data! -Check the data passed to the method or property.
FB4 EID_INVALIDTIME Invalid time delta! Check the Time values passed to the methods in the ISMICMotion Interface. For Class 4, also see ISMICMotion::WriteClock. For Class 5, 6 or 9, also see ISMICMotion::WriteSegmentTime.
Get Status FB5 EID_INVALIDTIMEDELTA Motor(x): Invalid time delta! Check the Time values passed to the methods in the ISMICMotion Interface. For Class 4, also see ISMICMotion::WriteClock. For Class 5, 6 or 9, also see ISMICMotion::WriteSegmentTime.
Get Status FB6 EID_INVALIDPOSDELTA Motor(x): Invalid Position Delta! Check the position values passed to the methods in the ISMICMotion Interface. Also see ISMICMotion::WritePosition.
Get Status FB7 EID_INTDATASPACE Motor(x): Invalid data space! Check the program in the SmartMotor.
Get Status FB8 EID_BUFFOVERFLOW Motor(x): Buffer overflow! Do not send data continually faster than the time delta.
Get Status FB9 EID_BUFFUNDERFLOW Motor(x): Buffer underflow! Try a larger Time Delta. Shut down non-essential tasks and applications and try again.
Get Status FBA EID_HMFAILED Motor(x): Host Mode failed! Check and make sure that the specified motor's shaft can move and it is not overloaded.
Get Status FBB EID_GETSTATUS Motor(x): Cannot get status! Check:
- Serial connection to the motors.
- Power supply to the motors.
FBC EID_SAMPLERATES The motors have different sample rates! Replace with compatible SmartMotor.
FBD EID_NOTSUPPORTED Motor(x): Host Mode not supported! Replace the specified SmartMotor with a newer version supporting Host Mode. Make sure all motors are the same class.
FBE EID_NOTINIT Host Mode not initialized! Initialize the Host Mode and ISMICMotion Interface using the ISMICMotion::Initialize method before using any other method or property.
FBF EID_NOMEM Out of memory! Check the available memory. Shut down non-essential tasks and applications and try again.
FC0 EID_GETALL Cannot get data from more than one motor! Make sure the address of the SMIMotor object is not zero. Make sure you are not writing data over CAN to address zero. This is due to the handshaking required.
FC1 EID_NOMORE No more errors/warnings! Check the values of ISMIErrors::NoOfErrors and ISMIErrors::NoOfWarnings.
FC2 EID_OPENFILE Cannot open the file specified! Check the existence of the specified file.
FC3 EID_OPENFILEWRITE Cannot open the file to write! Make sure the file is not open and locked by other application. Make sure there is enough space on the destination disk.
FC4 EID_NOEEPROM The motor has no EEPROM! Check the SmartMotor EEPROM.
FC5 EID_INVALIDMODE Invalid operation mode! Check the usage of ISMICMotion::EndHostMode method.
- For Class 4, make sure in all previous calls to the ISMICMotion::WriteClock method, the address is zero.
- For Class 5, 6 or 9, make sure in all previous calls to the ISMICMotion::WriteSegmentTimemethod, the address is zero.
FC7 EID_FILETOOLONG File too long! Reduce the compiled user program size.
FC9 EID_DOWNLOADON Cannot download programs while motor is on! Turn off the motor before attempting to download or set the flag MDF_TURNOFF.
FCA EID_VERSIONMISMATCH File version has a major difference with motor version! Compile the program using the correct language file.
Eth. Com. FCB EID_SOCKET Error communicating over the network! Try opening the Ethernet port again.
FCC EID_DOWNLOADRCKS The program was NOT downloaded successfully! Download the program again. A problem occurred during the download.
Eth. Com. FCD EID_NETERROR A network error occurred! Verify the selected Ethernet adapter is the desired one.
NOTE: Only when opening the port.
If a network communication error is detected.
Can occur due to these reasons:
- using a specified adapter with a bad IP address format
- not able to open a UDP socket for transmitting or receiving
- setting the socket as non blocking
- sending a broadcast out socket, unable to open the detected IP address
USB Com. FCE EID_USBERROR Cannot communicate with any USB motor! -Try opening the USB port again.
-Verify motor has a flashing green LED near the USB connector.
-Try unplugging and plugging in the USB cable to the PC again.
Ser. Com. FCF EID_BIGADDRESS The address of some motors is bigger than the specified Max. Motor Address. Increase the Max Motor Address for the selected Port.
Ser. Com. FD0 EID_CALWARNING The motor (x) has not finished calibration successfully. Please double click here to Verify Calibration or Recalibrate the motor. Recalibrate the motor.
Ser. Com. FD2 EID_SOMEADDRESSED Some motors are not addressed in their user program. Assign addresses to the motors in their user program.
Ser. Com. FD4 EID_DUPLICATEADDR Duplicate motor addresses found. Assign unique addresses to the motors in their user program.
Ser. Com. FD5 EID_COMMRESET Cannot communicate with the motor after resetting it. Detect the motor again
FD8 EID_OPEN_LANGFILE Error opening language file! Try compiling the program again. If problem still exists reinstall SMI.
FD9 EID_INVALID_PROJ Invalid project file! Make sure the selected project file exists.
FDA EID_READFILE_PROJ Error reading project file! Unable to open the selected project. The file may be corrupted.
CAN Com. FDC EID_CANERROR Cannot open the selected CAN channel Verify the desired channel and that nothing else is using the selected channel and try opening again.
Ser. Com FDE EID_ACKNOTRECEIVED Did not receive correct handshake from motor! Try downloading again.
Try a slower baud rate when downloading.
FDF EID_NOMODBUSDWLD Cannot download through the Modbus port! Select a different protocol to download.
FE0 EID_INCORRECTFIRMWARE Firmware not correct for this motor! Verify the firmware is correct for the motor. The file may be corrupt; obtain another one.
FE1 EID_FIRMFILEFORMAT Invalid File Format! The firmware file may be corrupt obtain another one.
FE2 EID_FIRMBUFFEREXCEED Hex file: buffer size exceeded! The firmware file may be corrupt obtain another one.
FE3 EID_FIRMCHECKSUM Hex file: Bad hex file checksum! The firmware file may be corrupt obtain another one.
FE4 EID_FIRMADDRESS Hex file: Bad address! The firmware file may be corrupt obtain another one.
FE5 EID_FIRMTYPE Hex file: Bad line type! The firmware file may be corrupt obtain another one.
FE6 EID_FIRMDATAINSERT Hex file: Could not insert data! The firmware file may be corrupt obtain another one.
FE7 EID_CMDNOSUPPORT Motor does not support this command! Use the correct property or method for the desired version of motor.
FE8 EID_NOTIMEDELTA SegmentTime not set! Set the segment before writing a position in host mode.
FE9 EID_SETINVALIDTIME TimeDelta not valid! SegmentTime * SampleTime must be a whole number! Write a segment time that when multiplied times the sample time is a whole number.
Get Status FEA EID_VOLTAGEFAULT Motor(x): Bus Voltage Fault! Check servo bus voltage. If motor uses the DE power option, ensure that both drive and control power are connected.
Get Status FEB EID_EXCESSIVETEMP Motor(x): Excessive Temperature Fault! Motor may be undersized or ambient temperature is too high. Consider adding heat sinks or forced air cooling to the system.
Get Status FEC EID_EXCESSIVEPOS Motor(x): Excessive Position Fault! Increase error limit(EL), decrease load or make movement less aggressive.
Get Status FED EID_VELOCITYLIMIT Motor(x): Velocity Limit! Increase the velocity limit(VL) or decrease the delta between commanded positions or increase the segment time.
Get Status FEE EID_DEDTLIMIT Motor(x): DE/DT Limit! Increase the derivative error limit(DEL).
Get Status FEF EID_HWPOSLIMIT Motor(x): Historical Positive H/W Limit! Verify wiring and location of limit. If limit is not used change I/O to general input.
Get Status FF0 EID_HWNEGLIMIT Motor(x): Historical Negative H/W Limit! Verify wiring and location of limit. If limit is not used change I/O to general input.
Get Status FF1 EID_SWPOSLIMIT Motor(x): Historical Positive S/W Limit! Increase the software limit(SLP) or disable the software limits(SLD).
Get Status FF2 EID_SWNEGLIMIT Motor(x): Historical Negative S/W Limit! Decrease the software limit(SLN) or disable the software limits(SLD).
FF3 EID_FIRMVERMISSMATCH File version does not match Motor version! Cycle motor power. Verify the firmware is correct for the motor.
FF4 EID_BADMODEL Invalid model format! Enter a valid model.
CAN Com. FF5 EID_DRVNOTREADY Drive not ready. Make sure the drive ready input is connected.

Warning 226F WR_PRINTTOOLONG PRINT Command exceeds 63 characters.
Fatal Error 22C4 FER_2MANYERRORS Too many Errors.
Fatal Error 22C5 FER_2MANYWARNINGS Too many Warnings.
Fatal Error 22C6 FER_NESTING Too many nested keywords. Cannot continue!
Fatal Error 22C7 FER_2MANY_LINES Too many lines. Cannot continue!

Custom Error Codes
0 Operation Successful
5 Invalid Handler
1 General Error
7 One of the Limit Switch is asserted. Cannot Continue

TROUBLE SHOOTING

This Section Provides Troubleshooting Information For Common Problems. For Additional Support Resources,

ISSUE CAUSE SOLUTION
Motor control power light does not illuminate. Control power is off, disconnected or incorrectly wired. Check that control power is connected to the proper pins and turned on.
Motor has routed drive power through drive-enable pins. Ensure cabling is correct and drive power is not being delivered through the 15-pin connector.
Motor is equipped with the DE option. To energize control power, apply 24-48 VDC to pin 15 and ground to pin 14.
Motor does not communicate with SMI. Transmit, receive or ground pins are not connected correctly. Ensure that transmit, receive and ground are all connected properly to the host PC.
Motor program is stuck in a continuous loop or is disabling communications To Motor disconnects from SMI sporadically. the program from running on power up, use the Communications Lockup Wizard located on the SMI software Communications menu.
Motor disconnects from SMI sporadically. COM port buffer settings are too high. Adjust the COM port buffer settings to their lowest values. This is done In the Windows Device Manager> Advanced Settings dialog box for the associated COM port driver
Poor connection on cable from motor to PC. Check the cable connections and/or replace it.
Power supply unit (PSU) brownout. PSU may be undersized for the application, which causes it to brown-out during motion. Make moves less aggressive, increase PSU size or change to a linear unregulated power supply.
Motor stops communicating after power reset, requires redetection. Motor does not have its address set in the user program. NOTE: Serial addresses are lost when motor power is off or reset. Use the SADDR or ADDR= command within the program to set the motor address. If there is more than one motor in a serial daisy chain, ensure the ECHO command is in the downloaded program.
Red PWR SERVO light illuminated. Red LED indicates the drive stage is OFF. This may be due to never having been turned on yet, or a critical shaft protection fault. To discover the source of the fault, use the Motor View tool located on the SMI software Tools menu.
Motor doesn't turn. Faults not cleared and/or drive enable not satisfied. Clear faults (see Checking and Clearing the Status Bits on page 57). Satisfy the drive enable input (see M-Style Drive Enable Power on page 33).
Bus voltage fault. Bus voltage fault. Bus voltage is too high for operation. Check servo bus voltage. Check for excessive regenerative energy from motor due to no/insufficient shunt resistor.
Bus voltage is too low for operation. If motor uses the DE power option (separate drive and control power supplies), ensure that both power supplies are connected and are sized correctly for the motor.
Overcurrent occurred. Motor intermittently drew more than its rated level of current. Does not cease motion. Consider making motion less abrupt with softer tuning parameters or lower acceleration profiles. Excessive temperature fault.
Excessive temperature fault. Motor has exceeded internal PCB temperature limit of 85°C. Motor will remain unresponsive until it cools down below 80°C Motor may be undersized or ambient temperature is too high. Check motor sizing for the application in terms of continuous rating. Consider adding heat sinks or forced air cooling to the system.
Excessive position error. The motor's commanded position and actual position differ by more than the user-supplied error limit. Increase error limit, decrease load or make movement less aggressive. Also, ensure you are not voltage limited for the torque at speed required. If running from less than 48 VDC, check ratings for lower bus voltages and ensure the motor is within required torque capacity.
Motor faults on position error only after a certain amount of time. Motor sized incorrectly. Check motor sizing for the application in terms of continuous rating. Also, ensure you are not voltage limited for the torque at speed required. If running from less than 48 VDC, check ratings for lower bus voltages and ensure the motor is within required torque capacity.
Motor is not accurately corresponding to trajectory.
Historical positive/negative hardware limit faults. A limit switch was tripped in the past. Clear errors with the ZS command.
Motor does not have limit switches attached. Configure the motor to be used without limit switches by setting their inputs as general use.
No "Drive Ready" state. Absolute Encoder Battery fault. Check Status Word 6, bit 12.

Programming and SMI Issues
Several commands not recognized during compiling. Compiler default firmware version set incorrectly. Use the Compiler default firmware version option in the SMI software Compile menu to select a default firmware version closest to the motor's firmware version. In the SMI software, view the motor's firmware version by right-clicking the motor and selecting Motor Properties.

RESOURCES AND LINKS

  • Animatic motor products: https://www.animatics.com/products/smartmotor/class-5-d-style/sm23165d/
  • Installation Guide:https://www.animatics.com/support/downloads/software/smiengine-installation/
  • Manuals: https://www.animatics.com/support/downloads/manuals/
  • Developer’s Guide: https://www.animatics.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/Moog-Animatics-SmartMotor-DevelopersGuide-Manual-en.pdf
  • Datasheet: https://www.animatics.com/wp-content/uploads/2023/09/Moog-Animatics-SmartMotor-Class5InstallationandStartupGuide-Manual-en.pdf

GLOSSARY

  • Animatic Motor: A type of motor produced by Animatics Corporation, known for its integrated servo motor and controller design.
  • Servo Motor: A motor that uses feedback to control its speed and position precisely.
  • Controller: The electronic component that manages and controls the operation of the servo motor.
  • Encoder: A device used to measure the position or speed of a motor shaft and provide feedback to the controller.
  • Driver: A component that amplifies the control signals from the controller to the motor.
  • Motion Profile/PTP Movement: A predefined pattern of motion used to control the movement of the motor.
  • Acceleration: The rate of change of velocity of the motor.
  • Deceleration: The rate at which the motor slows down.
  • Torque: The rotational force produced by the motor.
  • Feedback: Information about the motor's performance that is fed back to the controller for adjustment.
  • Position Control: The ability to control the motor's position accurately.
  • Speed Control: The ability to control the motor's speed accurately.
  • Motion Control: The ability to control the motor's motion, including speed, position, and acceleration.
  • Integration: The process of incorporating the motor into a larger system or machine.
  • Communication Protocol: The rules and conventions for communication between the motor and other devices systems.
  • EtherCAT: A real-time Ethernet fieldbus system used for communication in industrial automation.
  • CANopen: A communication protocol based on the Controller Area Network (CAN) bus standard.
  • Modbus: A communication protocol commonly used in industrial automation systems.
  • PLC (Programmable Logic Controller): A digital computer used for automation of electromechanical processes.
  • HMI (Human Machine Interface): A device or software that allows users to interact with the motor or control system.

Denso driver document

Introduction

Brief overview of the project

This project aims to develop drivers for the Denso 6-axis robot, tailored for automation applications, with a focus on integrating them into a user interface (UI) application for enhanced usability. The goal is to create software components that facilitate seamless communication between the Denso 6-axis robot and the UI, enabling intuitive control and real-time monitoring of motion systems. By achieving this integration, the project seeks to enhance the functionality and usability of the Denso robot within automated processes, ultimately improving efficiency and productivity across various industrial settings.

Purpose of the document

The purpose of this document is to provide a detailed guide for developing a driver for the Denso robot device. The driver will enable communication between the Robot and external software applications, allowing to control speed, direction, returning home and many more. It covers the software development process, including setting up the development environment, implementing the driver, testing and debugging, and integrating the driver with the Denso robot.

The primary objective of the document is to provide a comprehensive guide for developed drivers for Denso Robo used in automation using a UI application. This includes detailed instructions, software installation guide, a device description with its features, and best practices to ensure the successful development and integration of drivers with the devices.

Scope and objectives

  1. Driver Development: The document focuses on the development of a driver for denso robot using industry-standard protocols.
  2. Technical Information: It includes technical specifications of the device, hardware and software requirements, and information about the Software Development Kit (SDK) provided for the device.
  3. SDK Overview: Introduction to Orin II Interface and its Installation.
  4. Driver Implementation: It covers the development process, including the choice of programming language, information on APIs, how to use APIs, limitations of the driver, precautions to take before execution, and the actual implementation of the driver.
  5. Testing and Debugging: The scope extends to testing and debugging procedures to ensure the reliability and functionality of the driver for real-time application
  6. Documentation and Support: Lastly, the document includes information on documentation standards and support resources available for developers.

Overall, the aim is to facilitate the successful development and implementation of the Denso robot, ensuring it meets the required standards and serves its intended purpose effectively.

Device Overview

Description of the device for which the driver is being developed

The Denso VP-6242 is a compact 6-axis articulated robot designed for high-precision tasks such as assembly, handling, and inspection. With a total arm length of 420 mm, the VP-6242 has segments of 210 mm for each of the first two joints and an additional 75 mm offset on Joint 3, allowing for a versatile range of motion. Equipped with absolute encoders, this robot eliminates the need for homing at startup, enhancing positional accuracy, and its AC servomotors provide smooth, precise control with brakes on each joint for added safety. Capable of handling a maximum payload of 2.5 kg, it is optimized for speed with a high composite speed and short cycle time, making it suitable for applications requiring consistent accuracy. The robot's built-in user air piping and signal lines simplify integration with pneumatic tools, sensors, and other end-effectors, while its compact footprint allows for easy installation in confined spaces. Its low noise operation makes it suitable for quieter environments, and its robust design supports repetitive tasks across various industries, including electronics, automotive, and medical.

Technical Specifications of Denso

Type Denso Robot
Model VP-6242
Axes 6
Position Detection Absolute Encoder
Driver Motor and Brake AC Servo motors for all Joints, Brakes for all Joints
Maximum Motion Area 432
Motion Range J1 = + or - 160
J2 = + or - 120
J3 = + or - 160, + 29
J4 = + or - 160
J5 = + or - 120
J6 = + or - 360
Maximum Payload 2.5(Wrist downward movement is within +- 45 deg)
Weight Aprox. 15

Hardware and software requirements

Denso Specifications are as shown below:

Windows 7/8/10.

CPU Pentium III 1GHz or Faster, Memory 512MB or more, HDD 500MB or more.

ORiN2 Software Development Kit (ver2.1.21)

Microsoft Visual Studio for C++ IDE for development

Additional software or libraries required by the SDK or application

Additional Requirements:

This version of Microsoft Visual Studio works best with Internet Explorer 10 or higher. If Internet Explorer 10 is not installed on your computer, some features might not work as expected

SDK OVERVIEW

ORiN is a middleware that offers a standard interface of various resources, like various Factory Automation (FA) equipment and databases, etc. including robots. By using ORiN, applications can be developed without depending on the manufacturer or the model type.

ORiN2 is composed of the following three basic technologies,

• CAO (Controller Access Object)

• CRD (Controller Resource Definition)

• CAP (Controller Access Protocol)

CAO is "Standard program interface" to access robots controller from client applications. CAO is developed based on the distributed object technology, and it is applied not only to the industrial robots but also PLC (Programmable Logic Controller) and the NC machine tool, etc. CAO has expanded the range of its application.

CRD is "Standard Data Schema" to share robot controller's resource information without depending on the robot manufacture, and uses XML files. CAO is a common API, and CRD is a common data expression. CRD is developed based on the XML technology, and can express various types of data, which differ in each robot manufacturer, by single CRD schema. Just like CAO, application field of the CRD basic data schema is not limited to the robot, but "Production information" etc. also can be expressed.

CAP is "Communication protocol for the Internet" to access CAO provider over the Internet. CAP is developed based on the SOAP (Simple Object Access Protocol) technology, and offers the function to access remote controllers without forcing ORiN application developer considering the Internet.

DRIVER DEVELOPMENT

Introduction to driver development for the device

Users of the ORiN Suite may want to build their own C++ applications without the need to purchase an integrated development environment (IDE). This application note describes an alternative way to build C++ applications using free Microsoft Visual Studio.

Microsoft stopped providing single-language programming environments. Therefore, it is necessary to install the complete edition of free Microsoft Visual Studio. This will automatically enable you to build C++ applications with .NET languages such as C# and Visual Basic (*) as well, which are also supported by the Denso Interfaces Software Suite.

The following two free Microsoft Visual Studio tools are applicable to build pylon-based C++ applications:

Microsoft Visual Studio Express 2013 for Windows Desktop Microsoft Visual Studio Express 2013 for Windows Desktop does not provide the x64 native compiler. However, you can build 64-bit executables just fine using the x86-x64 cross compiler running on WOW64.

Microsoft Visual Studio Community Microsoft Visual Studio Community is the successor of the Express Edition starting with the 2015 release, but is also available in a 2013 release. It is comparable in its functionality to the full Professional Edition.

To get an overview of the Visual C++ features available in Microsoft Visual Studio.

Steps to be Carried out

To build powerful Windows Animatic Motor applications carry out the following steps:

1. Install the ORiN SDK.

2. Install the desired free Microsoft Visual Studio tool.

3. Prepare the C++ projects.

4. Run the project.

gRPC API’s Description for Denso

  1. OpenDevice

    Description for OpenDevice API: Establishes a connection to the Denso 6-axis Robot, initializing communication for further operations.

    RPC Command : rpc OpenDevice(.generic.CommandIPRequest) returns(.generic.GenericDeviceModel) {}
    Request:
    message CommandIPRequest{
    string ip_address = 1;
    int64 port_address=3;
    int32 device_id = 4;
    string file_path = 5;
    int64 device_model =6;
    optional string device_alias=7;
    int32 axis =8;
    }
    Parameter Description
    ip_address ip_address IP Address of the Device
    Model Model number of the device.
    port_address Port address of the device with serial communication (ex. 1)
    Response
    message GenericDeviceModel{
    string instance_id = 1;
    string device_alias = 2;
    DeviceType device_type = 3;
    DeviceModel device_model_name = 4;
    optional DeviceStatus device_status = 5;
    string ipaddr = 6;
    string mac_addr = 7;
    google.protobuf.Value conn_handle=8;
    string port_name = 9;
    int64 port_address = 10;
    CommandResponse cmd_response = 11;
    }
    Parameter Description
    instance_id New instance for the device in the enumeration
    device_alias Unique identifier (alphanumeric) for every device in the enumeration
    device_type Indicates the type of device like Motion stage, Safety Controller etc (defined below in the DeviceType enum)
    device_model_name Indicate the model name for each device (define below in the DeviceModel enum)
    device_status Indicate whether the device is online , offline or not reachable (define below in the device status enum)
    ipaddr Indicate the ipaddress of the device
    mac_addr Indicate the mac address of the device
    Conn_handle Handle object to keep the device open
    port_name Port name
    port_address Port address
    cmd_response Indicates command response that describes API response code and its description (Defined below in CommandResponse)

    enum DeviceType{
    NONE = 0;
    SENSOR_3D = 1;
    MOTION_STAGE = 2;
    CAMERA = 3;
    IO_MODULE = 4;
    SAFETY_CONTROLLER = 5;
    ANIMATIC_MOTOR=6;
    }
    enum DeviceModel{
    DUMMY_MODEL = 0;
    ED527 = 1;
    ED588 = 2 ;
    JR3000 = 3;
    OPTOE = 4;
    BASLER = 5;
    SPiiPlusEC=6;
    GT6600 = 7;
    MOTOR = 8;
    }
    enum DeviceStatus{
    OFFLINE = 0;
    ONLINE = 1;
    NOT_REACHABLE =2;
    }
    message CommandResponse{
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_message = 2;
    }
    ParameterDescription
    resp_code resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_message resp_message Description of the response code

    CLI Command: python denso.py OpenDevice 192.168.1.21 Denso

    Description for CLI Command
    • OpenDevice: API called to Denso 6-axis robot through CLI Command to connect and initialize all resources
    • 192.168.1.21: IP Address of the device
    • Denso Alias name of the device

  2. CloseDevice

    Description for CloseDevice API: Disconnects from the Denso 6-axis robot, releasing all resources and deleting associated handlers to ensure a clean shutdown.
    RPC Command: rpc CloseDevice(.generic.CommandRequest) returns(.generic.CommandResponse) {}
    Request: message CommandRequest {
    string device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    device_alias Unique alias of the device
    Response: message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code

    CLI Command: python denso.py CloseDevice Denso

    Description for CLI Command:
    • CloseDevice: API called to Denso 6-axis robot through CLI Command
    • Denso: Aliased Name for Denso

  3. GetDeviceDetails

    Description for GetDeviceDetails API:Retrieves detailed information about the connected Desno 6-axis robot, including its configuration and status.

    RPC Command : rpc GetDeviceDetails(.generic. CommandRequest) returns (.generic.GenericDeviceModel) {}

    Request:
    message CommandRequest {
    string device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    device_alias Unique alias of the device
    Response:
    message GenericDeviceModel{
    string instance_id = 1;
    string device_alias = 2;
    DeviceType device_type = 3;
    DeviceModel device_model_name = 4;
    optional DeviceStatus device_status = 5;
    string ipaddr = 6;
    string mac_addr = 7;
    google.protobuf.Value conn_handle=8;
    string port_name = 9;
    int64 port_address = 10;
    CommandResponse cmd_response = 11;
    }
    Parameter Description
    instance_id New instance for the device in the enumeration
    device_alias Unique identifier (alphanumeric) for every device in the enumeration
    device_type Indicates the type of device like Motion stage, Safety Controller etc (defined below in the DeviceType enum)
    device_model_name Indicate the model name for each device (define below in the DeviceModel enum)
    device_status Indicate whether the device is online , offline or not reachable (define below in the device status enum)
    ipaddr Indicate the ipaddress of the device
    mac_addr Indicate the mac address of the device
    Conn_handle Handle object to keep the device open
    port_name Port name
    port_address Port address
    cmd_response Indicates command response that describes API response code and its description (Defined below in CommandResponse)
    enum DeviceType{
    NONE = 0;
    SENSOR_3D = 1;
    MOTION_STAGE = 2;
    CAMERA = 3;
    IO_MODULE = 4;
    SAFETY_CONTROLLER = 5;
    ANIMATIC_MOTOR=6;
    }
    enum DeviceModel{
    DUMMY_MODEL = 0;
    ED527 = 1;
    ED588 = 2 ;
    JR3000 = 3;
    OPTOE = 4;
    BASLER = 5;
    SPiiPlusEC=6;
    GT6600 = 7;
    MOTOR = 8;
    }
    enum DeviceStatus{
    OFFLINE = 0;
    ONLINE = 1;
    NOT_REACHABLE =2;
    }
    message CommandResponse{
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_message = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_message Description of the response code

    CLI Command: python denso.py GetDeviceDetails Denso

    Description for CLI Command:
    • GetDeviceDetails: API called to Denso 6-axis robot through CLI Command
    • Denso: Aliased Name for Denso

  4. ChangeAlias

    Description for ChangeAlias API: Updates the alias of the device, allowing it to be referenced by a new identifier.
    RPC Command: rpc changeAlias(ChangeAliasRequest) returns (CommandResponse) {} Request: message ChangeAliasRequest{
    string current_alias=1;
    string new_alias=2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    current_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    new_alias The device_alias to change to
    Response: message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code

    CLI Command: python denso.py ChangeAlias DENSO_1 DENSO_2

    Description for CLI Command:
    • ChangeAlias: API called to the Denso 6-axis through CLI Command to get new alias name
    • current_alias: The current device_alias used to refer to the device
    • new_alias: The device_alias to change to

  5. ListProgram

    Description of the API: API to retrieve a list of all available tasks (programs) stored on the Denso controller.
    RPC Command: rpc ListProgram(generic.CommandRequest) returns(ListPorgramResponse) {}
    Request: message CommandRequest {
    string device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    Response: message ListProgramResponse {
    ListProgram list_program = 1;
    CommandResponse cmd_response = 2;
    }
    message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code
    list_program Retrived task name stored here

    CLI Command: python denso.py ListPrograms Denso

    Description for CLI Command:
    • ListPrograms:API called to the Denso 6-axis through CLI Command
    • Denso: Aliased name of the Device

  6. SelectProgram

    Description of the API: API to select a task(program) in the controller.
    RPC Command: rpc SelectProgram(SelectProgramRequest) returns(CommandResponse) {}
    Request: message SelectProgramRequest {
    string name = 1;
    CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
    }
     message CommandRequest {
    string device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    name Program name to be select.
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    Response: message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code

    CLI Command: python denso.py SelectProgram Denso ROBSLAVE

    Description for CLI Command:
    • SelectProgram:API called to the Denso 6-axis through CLI Command
    • Denso: Aliased name of the Device
    • ROBSLAVE Name of the Task(program)to be selected

  7. RunProgram

    Description of the API: API used to execute a specific task (program) on the Denso controller
    RPC Command: rpc RunProgram(RunProgramRequest) returns(CommandResponse) {}
    Request: message RunProgramRequest {
    int mode = 1;
    CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
    }
     message CommandRequest {
    string device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    mode Program mode to start or stop
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    Response: message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code

    CLI Command: python denso.py RunProgram Denso 1

    Description for CLI Command:
    • RunProgram: API called to the Denso 6-axis through CLI Command
    • Denso: Aliased name of the Device
    • 1: Task to be executed in the controller

  8. AbsolutePtpMovementControl

    Description of the API: API designed to execute absolute point-to-point (PTP) movement of a robot or motor to specified coordinates.
    RPC Command: rpc PtpMovementControl(PtpMovementControlRequest) returns(.generic.CommandResponse) {}
    Request: message PtpMovementControlRequest {
    float x_coordinate = 1;
    float y_coordinate = 2;
    float z_coordinate = 3;
    float rx_coordinate = 4;
    float ry_coordinate = 5;
    float rz_coordinate = 6;
    float fig_value = 7;
    .generic.CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
    }
     message CommandRequest {
    string device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    x_coordinate X co-ordinate for PTP movement, units in mm
    y_coordinate Y co-ordinate for PTP movement, units in mm
    z_coordinate Z co-ordinate for PTP movement, units in mm
    rx_coordinate RX co-ordinate for PTP movement, units in mm
    ry_coordinate RY co-ordinate for PTP movement, units in mm
    fig_value Figure of Denso 6-axis Robot/td>
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    Response: message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code

    CLI Command: python denso.py AbsolutePtpMovementControl Denso 404 12 11 122 32 0 5

    Description for CLI Command:
    • AbsolutePtpMovementControl:API called to the Denso 6-axis through CLI Command
    • Denso: Alias of the Device
    • 404: X co-ordinate for PTP movement, move to specified mm from origin
    • 12: Y co-ordinate for PTP movement, move to specified mm from origin
    • 11: Z co-ordinate for PTP movement, move to specified mm from origin
    • 122: RX co-ordinate for PTP movement, move to specified mm from origin
    • 32: RY co-ordinate for PTP movement, move to specified mm from origin
    • 0: RZ co-ordinate for PTP movement, move to specified mm from origin
    • 5: FIG value of the robot.

  9. RelativePtpMovementControl

    Description of the API: API designed to execute relative point-to-point (PTP) movement of a robot or motor,relative to current coordinates.
    RPC Command: rpc PtpMovementControl(RelativePtpMovementControlRequest) returns (CommandResponse) {}
    Request: message PtpMovementControlRequest {
    float x_coordinate = 1;
    float y_coordinate = 2;
    float z_coordinate = 3;
    float rx_coordinate = 4;
    float ry_coordinate = 5;
    float rz_coordinate = 6;
    float fig_value = 7;
    .generic.CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
    }
     message CommandRequest {
    string device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    x_coordinate X co-ordinate for PTP movement, units in mm
    y_coordinate Y co-ordinate for PTP movement, units in mm
    z_coordinate Z co-ordinate for PTP movement, units in mm
    r_coordinate R co-ordinate for PTP movement, units in mm
    rx_coordinate RX co-ordinate for PTP movement, units in mm
    ry_coordinate RY co-ordinate for PTP movement, units in mm
    fig_value Figure of Denso 6-axis Robot/td>
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    Response: message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code

    CLI Command: python denso.py RelativePtpMovementControl Denso 10 0 0 0 0 0 0

    Description for CLI Command:
    • RelativePtpMovementControl:API called to the Denso 6-axis through CLI Command
    • Denso: Aliased Name of the Device
    • 10: X co-ordinate for PTP movement, move to 10 mm from current position.
    • 0:Y co-ordinate for PTP movement, move to 0 mm from current position
    • 0: Z co-ordinate for PTP movement, move 0 mm for current position
    • 0: RX co-ordinate for PTP movement, move 0 mm for current position
    • 0: RY co-ordinate for PTP movement, move 0 mm for current position
    • 0: RZ co-ordinate for PTP movement, move 0 mm for current position
    • 0: Fig value will add the current fig

  10. SetPtpVelocity

    Description of the API: API to configure velocity for PTP movement
    RPC Command: rpc SetSpeed(SetSpeedRequest) returns(.generic.CommandResponse) {}
    Request: message SetPtpVelocityRequest {
    int64 axis = 1;
    float spd = 2;
    CommandRequest cmd_request = 3;
    }
     message CommandRequest {
    string device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    axis Represents tool axis or All Axis. -1 represents tool axis and 0 for all axis
    spd Velocity to be configured for the robot in m/s.
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    Response: message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code

    CLI Command: python denso.py SetVelocity Denso -1 50

    Description for CLI Command:
    • SetVelocity: API called to the Denso 6-axis through CLI Command
    • Denso: Aliased name of the Device
    • -1: -1 represents tool axis and 0 for all axis
    • 40: Percentage of velocity to be set for robot

  11. SetPtpAcceleration

    Description of the API: To configure acceleration for PTP movement.
    RPC Command: rpc SetPtpAcceleration(SetPtpAccelerationRequest) returns (CommandResponse) {}.
    Request: message SetPtpAccelerationRequest {
    int64 axis = 1;
    float accel = 2;
    CommandRequest cmd_request = 5;
    }
     message CommandRequest {
    string device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    axis Represents tool axis or all axis(-1 for tool axis and 0 for all axis)
    acceleration Acceleration to be set for the robot. Range is 1-100 m/s
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    Response: message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code

    CLI Command: python denso.py SetAcceleration Denso -1 50

    Description for CLI Command:
    • SetPtpAcceleration: API called to the Denso 6-axis through CLI Command
    • Denso: Aliased name of the Device
    • -1: Tool axis is selected
    • 50: Pecentage of the acceleration to be configured.

  12. EnableMotor

    Description of the API: API to turn on or turn off the motor power.
    RPC Command: rpc EnableMotor(MotorRequest) returns(.generic.CommandResponse) {}
    Request: message MotorRequest {
    string state = 1;
    .generic.CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
    }
     message CommandRequest {
    string device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    state Status of the motor.(0 means turn off the motor and 1 means turn on the motor)
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    Response: message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code

    CLI Command: python denso.py EnableMotor Denso 0

    Description for CLI Command:
    • EnableMotor: API called to the Denso 6-axis through CLI Command
    • Denso: Aliased name of the Device
    • 1: Status of the motor.

  13. UploadProgram

    Description of the API: API to upload .pac program to the robot.
    RPC Command: rpc UploadProgram(UploadProgramRequest) returns(.generic.CommandResponse) {}
    Request: message UploadProgramRequest {
    string filename = 1;
    bytes file_data = 2;
    CommandRequest cmd_request = 3;
    }
    message CommandRequest {
    int64 device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    filename The name of the file to be uploaded.
    file_data The file data to be sent to the controller.
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    Response: message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code

    CLI Command: python denso.py UploadProgram Denso ROBSLAVE.pac

    Description for CLI Command:
    • UploadProgram: API called to the Denso 6-axis through CLI Command
    • Denso: Aliased name of the Device
    • ROBSLAVE.pac pac program(file name) to be uploded to the contoller

  14. ReadAllInputs

    Description of the API: API to read the current status of all input pins of the controller.
    RPC Command: rpc ReadAllInputs(CommandRequest) returns(ReadDensoInputResponse) {}
    Request: message CommandRequest {
    int64 device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    Response: message ReadDensoInputResponse {
    int32 num_of_ios = 1;
    repeated HandleInputPin handle_input_pin = 2;
    repeated UserInputPin user_input_pin = 3;
    CommandResponse cmd_response = 4;
    }
     message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    num_of_ios Total number of input pins in Denso
    handle_input_pin Total number of hand input pins. Hand Input Ports/Pins are 48 to 55
    user_input_pin Total number of user or mini input pins. User Input Ports/Pins are 8 to 15
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code

    CLI Command: python denso.py ReadAllInputs Denso

    Description for CLI Command:
    • ReadAllInputs: API called to the Denso 6-axis through CLI Command
    • Denso: Aliased name of the device

  15. ReadAllOutputs

    Description of the API: API to read current status of all output ports/pins of the controller.
    RPC Command: rpc ReadAllOutputs(CommandRequest) returns(ReadDensoOutputResponse) {}
    Request: message CommandRequest {
    int64 device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    Response: message ReadDensoOutputResponse {
    int32 num_of_ios = 1
    repeated HandleInputPin handle_output_pin = 2;
    repeated UserInputPin user_output_pin = 3;
    CommandResponse cmd_response = 4;
    }
     message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    num_of_ios Total number of Output Pins
    handle_output_pin Status of hand output Pins
    user_output_pin Status of user output Pins
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code

    CLI Command: python denso.py ReadAllOutputs Denso

    Description for CLI Command:
    • ReadAllOutputs: API called to the Denso 6-axis through CLI Command
    • Denso: Aliased name of the Device

  16. SetIO

    Description of the API: API to set or reset any particular output pin of the controller.
    RPC Command: rpc SetIo(SetIoRequest) returns(CommandResponse) {}
    Request: message SetIoRequest {
    int64 io_typevalue = 1;
    bool state = 2;
    CommandRequest cmd_request = 3;
    }
     message CommandRequest {
    int64 device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    io_typevalue Represents Output type. Hand or User Output Port
    state Represtes the state weather set(1) or reset(0).
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    Response: message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code

    CLI Command: python denso.py SetIo den 1 1

    Description for CLI Command:
    • SetIo:API called to the Denso 6-axis through CLI CommandI
    • den: Aliased Name of the Device
    • 1: Type of Output Port(Hand or User)/li>
    • 1: Output Pin/Port Number to be Set or Reset

  17. ReturnHome

    Description of the API: API to move the robot to his home position. We have considered P10 variable for as Home Position.
    RPC Command: rpc ReturnHome(CommandRequest) returns (CommandResponse) {}
    Request: message CommandRequest {
    int64 device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    Response: message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code

    CLI Command: : python denso.py ReturnHome Denso

    Description for CLI Command:
    • ReturnHome:API called to the Denso 6-axis through CLI Command
    • Denso: Aliased Name for the device

  18. ClearError

    Description of the API: API to clear any pendant error.
    RPC Command: : rpc ClearError(generic.CommandRequest) returns(.generic.CommandResponse) {}
    Request: message CommandRequest {
    int64 device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    Response: message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description

    resp_description Description of the response code

    • Denso: Aliased Name of the Device

  19. ReadError

    Description of the API: API to Read Current Error of the pendant.
    RPC Command: rpc ReadError(generic.CommandRequest) returns(ReadErrorResponse) {}
    Request: message CommandRequest {
    int64 device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    Response: message ReadErrorResponse {
    string errorDescription = 1;
    CommandResponse cmd_response = 2;
    }
     message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    errorDescription Description of the error.
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code
