  20. GetAllFiles

    Description of the API: API to read all available files in the controller.
    RPC Command: rpc ListProgram(generic.CommandRequest) returns(FileResponse) {}
    Request: message CommandRequest {
    int64 device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    Response: message FileResponse {
    repeated string file_names = 1;
    CommandResponse cmd_response = 2;
    }
     message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    File_names Retrived file names from the controller.
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code

    CLI Command: : python denso.py GetAllFiles Denso

    Description for CLI Command:
    • GetAllFiles: API called to the Denso 6-axis through CLI Command
    • Denso: Aliased name of the device

  21. GetPosition

    Description of the API: API retrieves the current position of the robot in all defined coordinates, including Cartesian (X, Y, Z) and rotational axes (roll, pitch, yaw, or equivalent).
    RPC Command: rpc GetPosition(generic.CommandRequest) returns(GetPositionResponse) {}
    Request: message CommandRequest {
    int64 device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    Response: message GetPositionResponse
    {
    optional float x_coordinate = 1;
    optional float y_coordinate = 2;
    optional float z_coordinate = 3;
    optional float rx_coordinate = 4;
    optional float ry_coordinate = 5;
    optional float rz_coordinate = 6;
    optional float fig_coordinate = 7;
    .generic.CommandResponse cmd_response = 8;
    }
     message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    x_coordinate X- co-ordinate position in mm
    y_coordinate Y- co-ordinate position in mm
    z_coordinate Z- co-ordinate position in mm
    rx_coordinate RX- co-ordinate position in mm
    ry_coordinate RY- co-ordinate position in mm
    rz_coordinate RZ- co-ordinate position in mm
    fig Fig value of the robot.
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code

    CLI Command: python denso.py GetPosition Denso

    Description for CLI Command:
    • GetPosition: API called to the Denso 6-axis through CLI Command
    • Denso: Aliased name of the device

  22. GetAcceleration

    Description of the API: To retrive the current acceleration of the device.
    RPC Command: rpc GetAcceleration(.generic.CommandRequest) returns(GetAccelerationResponse) {}
    Request: message CommandRequest {
    int64 device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    Response: message GetAccelerationResponse {
    float acceleration = 1;
    CommandResponse cmd_response = 2;
    }
     message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description

    resp_code Response code from the device API

    }

    float velocity = 1;

  24. SaveProgram

    Description of the API: API to save a program from controller to PC
    RPC Command: rpc SaveProgram(SaveProgramRequest) returns(SaveProgramResponse) {}
    Request: message SaveProgramRequest {
    string filename = 1;
    CommandResponse cmd_response = 2;
    }
     message CommandRequest {
    int64 device_alias = 1;
    }
    Parameter Description
    file_nmae Name of the file to be saved to PC.
    device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
    Response: message SaveProgramResponse {
    optional bytes config_data = 1;
    optional string file_name = 2;
    optional int64 file_size = 3;
    CommandResponse cmd_response = 4;
    }
     message CommandResponse {
    int32 resp_code = 1;
    string resp_description = 2;
    }
    Parameter Description
    config_data Inidicates the file content received from the server.
    File_name Indicates Configuration file name received from the server.
    file_size Indicate size of the configuration file received from the server.
    resp_code Response code from the device API
    resp_description Description of the response code

    CLI Command: python denso.py SaveProgram Denso robslave.pac

    Description for CLI Command:
    • SaveProgram: API called to the Denso 6-axis through CLI Command
    • Denso: Aliased name of the device
    • robslave.pac File name to be saved

Limitations of the driver

One limitation of the Denso driver may lie in its compatibility with certain operating systems or hardware configurations. While efforts are made to ensure broad compatibility, there may be instances where the driver does not fully function or is not supported on all platforms. Additionally, given the complexity of robotic systems and the variety of tasks they may perform, the Denso driver may not cover every possible use case or scenario. Certain advanced functionalities or specialized operations may not be fully supported by the driver. Furthermore, as with any software development project, the Denso driver may encounter bugs, glitches, or compatibility issues with other software components. These issues could potentially impact the reliability or performance of the driver in certain situations.
Compatibility:The driver will work only the WipCaps should be run in background or else it will throw license error.
Integration:Integrating the driver with other systems or software may pose challenges, especially if there are compatibility issues or dependencies.

Precautions to take before executing the driver

  • Ensure that no error should be in the Pendant.
  • Ensure the program is in task list, while doing Select Program or Run Program.
  • Ensure to provide correct value in PTP movement.
  • Ensure to provide velocity and acceleration with the limit to avoid physical damage of the hardware.

TESTING AND DEBUGGING

Response Codes :

Error code Error Name Explanations
0x00000000 S_OK Normal finish (0x0) with returning logical TRUE.
0x00000001 S_FALSE Normal finish (0x1) with returning logical FALSE.
0x8000FFFF E_UNEXPECTED Catastrophic failure.
0x80004001 E_NOTIMPL Not implemented.
0x8007000E E_OUTOFMEMORY Ran out of memory.
0x80070057 E_INVALIDARG One or more arguments are invalid.
0x80004003 E_POINTER Invalid pointer.
0x80070006 E_HANDLE Invalid handle.
0x80004004 E_ABORT Operation aborted.
0x80004005 E_FAIL Unspecified error.
0x80070005 E_ACCESSDENIED General access denied error.
0x8007xxxx E_FAIL Unspecified error.
0x80000200 E_CAO_SEM_CREATE It failed in the generation of the synchronous semaphore.
0x80000201 E_CAO_PROV_INVALID The CAO access provider name is invalid.
0x80000202 E_CAO_COMPUTER_NAME The computer name can not be acquired.
0x80000203 E_CAO_VARIANT_TYPE_NOSUPPORT The VARIANT type which isn't supported was handed over.
0x80000204 E_CAO_OBJECT_NOTFOUND A corresponding object isn't found out.
0x80000205 E_CAO_COLLECTION_REGISTERED Unspecified error.
0x80000207 E_CAO_THREAD_CREATE It failed in the generation of the work thread.
0x80000208 E_CAO_REMOTE_ENGINE Can not access the remote CAO server.
0x80000209 E_CAO_REMOTE_PROVIDER Can not access the remote CAO's provider.
0x8000020a E_CAO_NOT_WRITABLE Can not write a data.
0x8000020b E_CAO_CMD_EXECUTE A command is under execution.
0x8000020c E_CAO_CMD_EXECUTE A command is under execution.
0x8000020d E_CAO_PRELOAD Failed CRD preload.
0x8000020e E_CAO_TEMP_REGISTERED Temporarily registered in the collection.
0x8000020f E_CAO_NO_PARENT Improper CRD file
0x80000400 E_CRDIMPL It is an invalid system variable name.
0x80000401 E_CAOP_SYSTEMNAME_INVALID It is an invalid system variable name.
0x80000402 E_CANCEL The command was canceled.
0x80000403 E_CANCEL The command was canceled.
0x80000404 E_CAOP_NOT_WRITABLE It is read-only parameter.
0x80000900 E_TIMEOUT Timeout
0ｘ80000901 E_NO_LICENSE No license.
0x80000902 E_NOT_CONNECTED Connection is not established.
0x80000903 E_NOT_USE It is not used.
0x80000904 E_INVALID_CMD_NAME It is illegal command.
0x80000904 E_INVALID_CMD_NAME It is illegal command.
0x80000905 E_INVALID_CMD_NAME Exceeded the number of creatable object limit.
0x80000906 E_OVERLOADING The setting is duplicated..
0x80000907 E_NONE_CONNECT_OPTION Connection option is not found.
0x80000908 E_ALREADY_REGISTER The name you have entered has already used.
0x80000909 E_TOO_MUCH_DATA Data size is too large.
0x8000090a E_FAILED_ALLOC Failed to secure buffer.
0x8000090b E_MAX_CONNECT Exceeded the number of connection count limit.
0x8000090c E_CONVERT_CHAR_CODE Failed to convert character code.
0x8091xxxx E_WINSOCK_MASK Windows winsock error codes

Debugging Procedure

ISSUE CAUSE SOLUTION
Unable to start the PTP Movement. Motor power is off Check the motor power and if its off state turn the motor.
Robslave program not be running in the controller. Check the Robslave task status,if its not running run the ROBSLAVE task.
Emergency button may pressed. Check the emergency button released or not, if its in press stated release that.
May pendant have some issue. Check the pendant error, if that having some issue clear the error.
Unable to Set Velocity and Acceleration. Robslave program not be running in the controller. Check the pendant error, if that having some issue clear the error.
May pendant have some issue. Check the Robslave task status,if its not running run the ROBSLAVE task.
Unable to Run ROBSLAVE Check the robslave is there is in the controller. Upload the Robslave program and run.
May pendant have some issue. Add the task in the controller using select program then run.
Robslave not added in the Controller. Check the Robslave task status,if its not running run the ROBSLAVE task.
Unable to SetIO or Read Output May pendant have some issue. Check the pendant error, if that having some issue clear the error.
Unable Read Input. May pendant have some issue. Check the pendant error, if that having some issue clear the error.
Unable to upload program May pendant have some issue. Check the pendant error, if that having some issue clear the error.
Motor power is on. Check the motor state if its in on turn of the motor.
Unable perform run any API. May Wincaps not in open in the system. Check the wincaps opened or not if not open the wincaps.
IP address might changed. Check the ip address if its changed recorrect Ip address.
Motor does not have limit switches attached. Configure the motor to be used without limit switches by setting their inputs as general use.

DOCUMENTATION AND SUPPORT

  • ORIN2 OVERVIEW
  • RC Controller User Manual
  • VP 6242 User Manual
  • PAC Program Manuals
  • PAC Program Guide

    • GLOSSARY

    When developing a Denso driver, it's helpful to have a glossary of terms to ensure clarity and consistency in communication. Here's a glossary of terms commonly used in Denso driver development:

    • Denso Driver: Software module or library responsible for interfacing with Denso robotic systems, facilitating communication and control.
    • Robot Controller: Device or software component that manages the operation of a Denso robot, including motion control, program execution, and I/O handling.
    • API (Application Programming Interface): Set of protocols, tools, and definitions that allow software applications to communicate and interact with the Denso driver.
    • Command: Instruction or directive sent to a Denso robot through the driver to perform specific actions such as movement, I/O control, or program execution.
    • Response: Feedback or acknowledgment received from the Denso robot after executing a command, indicating the success or failure of the operation and providing relevant information or data.
    • Motion Control: Functionality within the Denso driver responsible for controlling the movement of the robot, including linear motion, joint motion, and velocity control.
    • I/O (Input/Output): Interface for interacting with external devices or sensors connected to the Denso robot, allowing the driver to read inputs and control outputs.
    • Program Execution: Process of running predefined motion sequences or routines on the Denso robot, typically stored in the robot controller's memory or loaded from external sources.
    • Configuration: Settings and parameters that can be adjusted or customized within the Denso driver to tailor its behavior to specific requirements or environments.
    • Error Handling: Mechanism for detecting, reporting, and managing errors or exceptions that occur during interaction with the Denso robot, ensuring robustness and reliability.
    • Coordinate System: Reference frame used to specify the position and orientation of the Denso robot's end-effector or individual joints, facilitating precise motion control and trajectory planning.
    • Velocity: Speed at which the Denso robot's end-effector or joints move during motion, typically measured in units per second (e.g., millimeters per second or degrees per second).
    • Acceleration: Rate of change of velocity over time, determining how quickly the Denso robot can accelerate or decelerate during motion, influencing performance and efficiency.
    • Positioning: Process of accurately locating and orienting the Denso robot's end-effector or individual joints at specific coordinates within its workspace, essential for precise manipulation tasks.
    • Feedback: Information provided by sensors or encoders on the Denso robot, used to monitor its state, verify motion accuracy, and adjust control parameters in real-time.
    • Interpolation: Algorithm used by the Denso driver to generate smooth and continuous motion trajectories between discrete points, ensuring seamless movement and avoiding jerky motion.
    • ORIN2:ORiN2 is a middleware platform designed to enable the integration and communication between various industrial devices.

    Keyence LJV7020 driver document

    Introduction

    Brief overview of the project

    This project focuses on developing drivers for LJV 7020 to be utilized in automation applications, with a particular emphasis on integrating them with a user interface (UI) application for future use. The project aims to create software components that enable seamless communication between LJV 7020 and the UI application, allowing fast, accurate, and reliable measurements for various surfaces and materials, making it suitable for applications such as quality control, dimensional measurement, and object detection and In-line measurements. Through this integration, the project seeks to enhance the usability and functionality of LJV 7020 within automated processes, contributing to increased efficiency and productivity in various industrial settings.

    Purpose of the document

    The purpose of this document is to provide a detailed guide for developing a driver for the LJV 7020 device. The driver will enable communication between the 3D Sensor and external software applications, allowing to Get Raw data, Load and Save program, Start and Stop torage and many more. It covers the software development process, including setting up the development environment, implementing the driver, testing and debugging, and integrating the driver with the LJV 7020.

    The primary objective of the document is to provide a comprehensive guide for developed drivers LJV 7020 used in automation using a UI application. This includes detailed instructions, software installation guide, a device description with its features, and best practices to ensure the successful development and integration of drivers with the devices.

    Scope and objectives

    1. Driver Development: The document focuses on the development of a driver for LJV 7020 using industry-standard protocols.
    2. Technical Information: It includes technical specifications of the device, hardware and software requirements, and information about the Software Development Kit (SDK) provided for the device.
    3. SDK Overview: Introduction to SMI Interface and its Installation.
    4. Driver Implementation: It covers the development process, including the choice of programming language, information on APIs, how to use APIs, limitations of the driver, precautions to take before execution, and the actual implementation of the driver.
    5. Testing and Debugging: The scope extends to testing and debugging procedures to ensure the reliability and functionality of the driver for real-time application.
    6. Documentation and Support: Lastly, the document includes information on documentation standards and support resources available for developers.

    Overall, the aim is to facilitate the successful development and implementation of the LJV7020, ensuring it meets the required standards and serves its intended purpose effectively.

    Device Overview

    Laser profilers are laser displacement sensors that collect height data across a laser line rather than a single point. This enables 2D/3D measurements such as height difference, width, or angle to be performed using a single sensor. In addition to height data, KEYENCE profile sensors also collect intensity data to provide a stable solution for inline measurement and inspection. The line-up includes a wide range of sensors to support a variety of applications and industries. The World’s Fastest At 64,000 Profiles/Sec. Speed that makes the measurement of any product and of any shape a reality!

    Description of the device for which the driver is being developed

    LJV 7020 sensor is used for 3D measurement and inspection in line.

    Following are the features of LJV 7020 :

    • Ultra-high-speed sampling the LJ-V Series is the fastest 2D laser measuring instrument in the world. This makes it possible to measure parts moving at extremely high speeds, in high definition, without missing a single one.
    • Profiles are accurately measured even in cases where black surfaces, inclines with low reflectivity and metallic surfaces with high reflectivity are mixed together under the same optical axis. Newly developed HSE3 -CMOS wide dynamic range has provided the LJ-V Series with improvements in both speed and detection stability Advanced gearing allowing pre-set traverse and take-up winding parameters including dwells and wrap counts.
    • The LJ-V Series is able to perform any measurement thanks to a variety of head variations and measurement modes, as well as 3D inspection when connected to an image processing system. In addition, the automatic setting optimization function makes operation easy for any user. Stand-alone, multi-axis linear interpolation with as many as 120 Smart Motors at a time.
    • Virtual-axis control into camming through gearing, which enables stand-alone, multi-axis coordinated motion Programmable and non-programmable protection features (both hardware and software).
    • Corrects positional misalignment of the target, eliminating errors in the measurement results due to target tilt. Accurate measurements are possible even in cases where the target is moving at random or when it is difficult to perform positioning.
    • The LJ-V7000 Series is equipped with a new function that makes it possible to individually set corrections on two separate features. This is effective when measuring gaps, angles, or height differences of two targets that move independently.
    • By understanding the positional relationship of both heads, it is possible to match the θ adjustment for both heads. Even when measuring targets with variation or incline changes, it is possible to measure the correct points.

    Technical Specifications of LJV

    Type 3D Sensor
    Model LJ-V7020
    Reference Condition 20 mm
    Spot size (reference distance) Approx. 14 mm × 35 µm
    Linearity Z-axis (height)
    Profile data interval X-axis (width)
    Temperature characteristics 0.01% of F.S./°C
    Sampling cycle (trigger interval) Top speed: 16 µs (high-speed mode), Top speed: 32 µs (advanced function mode)
    Peak Torque

    4.00 in-lb

    64 oz-in

    0.45 N-m
    Measurement range Z-axis (height)

    ±2.6 mm

    (F.S.=5.2 mm)
    X-axis (width) NEAR side 6.5 mm
    Reference distance 7 mm
    Far side 7.5 mm
    Light source Type Blue semiconductor laser
    Wavelength 405 nm (visible beam)
    Laser class Class 2M Laser Product (IEC60825-1, FDA(CDRH) Part 1040.10)
    Output 10 mW

    Software Overview and Requirements – LJ Navigator 2

    LJ-Navigator 2 developed by keyence is a sophisticated software suite developed by KEYENCE Corporation to interface with and manage their advanced lineup of laser displacement sensors, particularly the LJ series. This software provides users with an intuitive environment to configure, monitor, and analyze data from these high-precision sensors, making it a vital tool in various industrial and research applications.

    System Requirements

    • Windows 11 Pro, Windows 10, Windows 7 (SP1 or later), Windows Vista (SP2 or later), Windows XP (SP3 or later), Windows 10 (64 bit) or Windows 11 (64 bit)
    • Core i3 2.3GHz or faster
    • Memory capacity 2GB or more
    • L2 cache memory 2MB or more
    • Available hard disk space 10GB or more
    • Interface – USB 2.0/1.1 or Ethernet 1000BASE-T/100BASE-TX

    Additional Requirements:

    This version of Microsoft Visual Studio works best with Internet Explorer 10 or higher. If Internet Explorer 10 is not installed on your computer, some features might not work as expected

    Installing LJ-Navigator 2

    This topic explains how to install the LJ-Navigator 2 for Windows.

    System Requirements

    The LJ-navigator Software Suite for Windows requires one of the following operating systems to be installed on computer:

    • Windows 10 (64 bit)
    • Windows 11 (64 bit)
    • Windows 7 (SP1 or later)
    • Windows Vista (SP2 or later)
    • Windows XP (SP3 or later)
    • Windows 10 (64 bit) or Windows 11 (64 bit)

    Installation

    To install the LJ- Navigator 2 Suite for Windows: Insert the Hard Disk which includes LJ Navigator 2 Software and all supported resources. Follow the instructions.

    DRIVER DEVELOPMENT

    Introduction to driver development for the device

    The LJ-V7000 Series communication library provides a communication interface for controlling the LJ-V7000 Series from a user application (Win32 DLL). For specific ways to use the communication library, refer to the sample program.

    Execution environment

    This section describes the necessary environment to execute applications that use the LJ-V7000 Series communication library.

    • Microsoft C runtime library The Microsoft C runtime library is required for the DLL to operate. Run vcredist_x86.exe included on the installation media to install the library.
    • Microsoft .NET Framework The Microsoft .NET Framework is required to run the sample application. Run NetFx20SP2_x86.exe included on the installation media to install the library.

    Incorporating the Libraries

    The files required at execution are listed below. Place these folders/files in the same folder as the executable file.

    • LJV7_IF.dll

    Linking

    • C++: Linking The library can be linked implicitly or explicitly. To implicitly link the library, link with "LJV7_IF.lib". * "LJV7_IF.lib" was built with Visual C++ 2008 SP1.
    • Include files Include the following header files in the necessary source files.
    • LJV7_IF.h
    • LJV7_ErrorCode.h
    • C#/VB.NET Call each interface using the DllImport attribute. When passing a structure as an interface argument, specify the StructLayout attribute and pass a structure of the same memory structure as the DLL.

    Steps To Be Carried Out

    To build powerful Windows ljv 7020 applications carry out the following steps:

    1. Install the LJ-Navigator 2 Software Suite SDK.
    2. Install the desired free Microsoft Visual Studio tool.
    3. Prepare the C++ projects.
    4. Run the project.

    Driver Implementation

    The following drivers or APIs are developed and tested

    1. Open Device
    2. GetDeviceDetails
    3. Change Alias
    4. CloseDevice
    5. LoadProgram
    6. SelectProgram
    7. SaveProgram
    8. StartStorage
    9. StopStorage
    10. Clear storage
    11. GetStorageData
    12. GetRawProfileData
    13. GetJudgementOutput

    gRPC API’s Description for LJV 7020

    1. OpenDevice

      Description for OpenDevice API: Establishes a connection to the LJV Device, initializing communication for further operations.

      RPC Command : rpc OpenDevice(.generic.CommandIPRequest) returns(.generic.GenericDeviceModel) {}
      Request:
      message CommandIPRequest{
      string ip_address = 1;
      string com=2;
      int64 port_address=3;
      int32 device_id = 4;
      string file_path = 5;
      int64 device_model =6;
      optional string device_alias=7;
      int32 axis =8;
      }
      Parameter Description
      ip_address ip_address IP Address of the Device
      com COM Port Address of the Device with serial communication(ex. COM1)
      port_address Port address of the device with serial communication (ex. 1)
      Response
      message GenericDeviceModel{
      string instance_id = 1;
      string device_alias = 2;
      DeviceType device_type = 3;
      DeviceModel device_model_name = 4;
      optional DeviceStatus device_status = 5;
      string ipaddr = 6;
      string mac_addr = 7;
      google.protobuf.Value conn_handle=8;
      string port_name = 9;
      int64 port_address = 10;
      CommandResponse cmd_response = 11;
      }
      Parameter Description
      instance_id New instance for the device in the enumeration
      device_alias Unique identifier (alphanumeric) for every device in the enumeration
      device_type Indicates the type of device like Motion stage, Safety Controller etc (defined below in the DeviceType enum)
      device_model_name Indicate the model name for each device (define below in the DeviceModel enum)
      device_status Indicate whether the device is online , offline or not reachable (define below in the device status enum)
      ipaddr Indicate the ipaddress of the device
      mac_addr Indicate the mac address of the device
      Conn_handle Handle object to keep the device open
      port_name Port name
      port_address Port address
      cmd_response Indicates command response that describes API response code and its description (Defined below in CommandResponse)

      enum DeviceType{
      NONE = 0;
      SENSOR_3D = 1;
      MOTION_STAGE = 2;
      CAMERA = 3;
      IO_MODULE = 4;
      SAFETY_CONTROLLER = 5;
      ANIMATIC_MOTOR=6;
      }
      enum DeviceModel{
      DUMMY_MODEL = 0;
      ED527 = 1;
      ED588 = 2 ;
      JR3000 = 3;
      OPTOE = 4;
      BASLER = 5;
      SPiiPlusEC=6;
      GT6600 = 7;
      MOTOR = 8;
      }
      enum DeviceStatus{
      OFFLINE = 0;
      ONLINE = 1;
      NOT_REACHABLE =2;
      }
      message CommandResponse{
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_message = 2;
      }
      ParameterDescription
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_message Response message

      CLI Command:python3 ljv_7020.py OpenDevice 192.168.1.10 LJV7020_1

      Description for CLI Command
      • OpenDevice: OpenDevice is the API called to the ljv through CLI Command to Connect to the Motor and Turn on the Driver
      • 192.168.1.10: IP Address of the device
      • LJV7020_1: Aliased name of LJV

    2. CloseDevice

      Description for CloseDevice API: Disconnects the LJV, releasing all resources and deleting associated handlers to ensure a clean shutdown.
      RPC Command: rpc CloseDevice(.generic.CommandRequest) returns(.generic.CommandResponse) {}
      Request: message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias Unique alias of the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code

      CLI Command:python3 ljv_7020.py CloseDevice LJV7020_1

      Description for CLI Command:
      • CloseDevice: CloseDevice is the API called to the LJV through CLI Command to Disconnect the LJV.
      • LJV7020_1: Aliased Name for LJV

    3. GetDeviceDetails

      Description for GetDeviceDetails API: Retrieves detailed information about the connected LJV, including its configuration and status

      RPC Command : rpc GetDeviceDetails(CommandRequest) returns (GenericDeviceModel) {}

      Request:
      message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias Unique alias of the device
      Response:
      message GenericDeviceModel{
      string instance_id = 1;
      string device_alias = 2;
      DeviceType device_type = 3;
      DeviceModel device_model_name = 4;
      optional DeviceStatus device_status = 5;
      string ipaddr = 6;
      string mac_addr = 7;
      google.protobuf.Value conn_handle=8;
      string port_name = 9;
      int64 port_address = 10;
      CommandResponse cmd_response = 11;
      }
      Parameter Description
      instance_id New instance for the device in the enumeration
      device_alias Unique identifier (alphanumeric) for every device in the enumeration
      device_type Indicates the type of device like Motion stage, Safety Controller etc (defined below in the DeviceType enum)
      device_model_name Indicate the model name for each device (define below in the DeviceModel enum)
      device_status Indicate whether the device is online , offline or not reachable (define below in the device status enum)
      ipaddr Indicate the ipaddress of the device
      mac_addr Indicate the mac address of the device
      Conn_handle Handle object to keep the device open
      port_name Port name
      port_address Port address
      cmd_response Indicates command response that describes API response code and its description (Defined below in CommandResponse)
      enum DeviceType{
      NONE = 0;
      SENSOR_3D = 1;
      MOTION_STAGE = 2;
      CAMERA = 3;
      IO_MODULE = 4;
      SAFETY_CONTROLLER = 5;
      ANIMATIC_MOTOR=6;
      }
      enum DeviceModel{
      DUMMY_MODEL = 0;
      ED527 = 1;
      ED588 = 2 ;
      JR3000 = 3;
      OPTOE = 4;
      BASLER = 5;
      SPiiPlusEC=6;
      GT6600 = 7;
      MOTOR = 8;
      }
      enum DeviceStatus{
      OFFLINE = 0;
      ONLINE = 1;
      NOT_REACHABLE =2;
      }
      message CommandResponse{
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_message = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_message Response message

      CLI Command: python ljv_7020.py GetDeviceDetails LJV_7020_1

      Description for CLI Command:
      • GetDeviceDetails: API called to the LJV through CLI Command
      • LJV_7020_1: Alias name of the LJV device

    4. ChangeAlias

      Description for ChangeAlias API: Updates the alias of the device, allowing it to be referenced by a new identifier.
      RPC Command: rpc ChangeAlias (ChangeAliasRequest request) returns (Command_Response) {} Request: message ChangeAliasRequest{
      string current_alias=1;
      string new_alias=2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      current_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      new_alias The device_alias to change to
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_message = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_message Response message

      CLI Command:python3 ljv_7020.py ChangeAlias current_alias new_alias

      Description for CLI Command:
      • ChangeAlias: API called to the LJV through CLI Command to get new alias name
      • current_alias: The current device_alias used to refer to the device
      • new_alias: The device_alias to change to

    5. Start Storage

      Description of the API: Starts storing the measurement data on the LJV sensor
      RPC Command: rpc StartStorage(.generic.CommandRequest) returns (.generic.CommandResponse) {}
      Request: message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_message = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_message Response message

      CLI Command:python ljv7020.py StartStorage LJV7020_1

      Description for CLI Command:
      • StartStorage: API called to the LJV through CLI Command
      • LJV7020_1: Alias of the Device

    6. Stop Storage

      Description of the API: Stop the storage(To be run after StartStorage API)
      RPC Command: rpc StopStorage(.generic.CommandRequest) returns (.generic.CommandResponse) {}
      Request: message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_message = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_message Response message

      CLI Command:python ljv7020.py StopStorage LJV7020_1

      Description for CLI Command:
      • StopStorage: API called to the LJV through CLI Command
      • LJV7020_1: Alias of the Device

    7. Clear Storage

      Description of the API: Clears all the files on the device storage.
      RPC Command: rpc ClearStorage (.generic.CommandRequest) returns (.generic.CommandResponse) {}
      Request: message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_message = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_message Response message

      CLI Command:python3 ljv7020.py ClearStorage LJV7020_1

      Description for CLI Command:
      • ClearStorage: API called to the LJV through CLI Command
      • LJV7020_1: Alias of the Device

    8. Get Stored Values

      Description of the API: Gets the stored data from the device and streams over gRPC.
      RPC Command: rpc GetStorageData(.generic.CommandRequest) returns (GetStorageDataResponse) {}
      Request: message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message GetStorageDataResponse {
      LJV7IFMeasureDataList measure_data_list = 1;
      .generic.CommandResponse cmd_response = 2;
      }
       message LJV7IFMeasureDataList {
      repeated LJV7020DecisionModel mesaure_data = 1;
      }
       message LJV7020DecisionModel {
      optional int32 by_data_info = 1;
      int32 by_judge = 2;
      bytes reserve = 3;
      float f_value = 4;
      }
      Parameter Description
      measure_data_list Measurment data list
      mesaure_data Measurement data in a list
      by_data_info Measurement result information
      by_judge Tolerance judgment result
      reserve Reserved
      f_value Measurement value
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_message Response message

      CLI Command:python ljv7020.py GetStorageData LJV7020_1

      Description for CLI Command:
      • GetStorageData: API called to the LJV through CLI Command
      • LJV7020_1: Alias of the Device

    9. Get Judgement Output

      Description of the API: Gets the judgement data
      RPC Command: rpc GetJudgementOutput(.generic.CommandRequest) returns (JudgementDataResponse) {}
      Request: message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message LJV7020DecisionList {
      repeated LJV7020DecisionModel LJV7020_decision_models = 1;
      }
       message LJV7020DecisionModel {
      optional int32 by_data_info = 1;
      int32 by_judge = 2;
      bytes reserve = 3;
      float f_value = 4;
      }
       message JudgementDataResponse {
      LJV7020DecisionList LJV7020_decision_list = 1;
      .generic.CommandResponse cmd_response = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      LJV7020_decision_list The Judgement data in a list
      by_data_info Measurement result information
      by_judge Tolerance judgment result
      reserve Reserved
      f_value Measurement value
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_message Response message

      CLI Command:python3 ljv7020.py GetJudgementData LJV7020_1

      Description for CLI Command:

      • GetJudgementData: API called to the LJV through CLI Command
      • LJV7020_1: Alias of the Device

    10. LoadProgram

      Description of the API: Loads the specified program onto the LJV7020 sensor and makes it the defaultsprogram.
      RPC Command: rpc LoadProgram(stream LoadProgramCommandRequest) returns (.generic.CommandResponse) {}
      Request: message LoadProgramCommandRequest {
      bytes data = 1;
      int32 program_no = 2;
      string file_name = 3;
      commandRequest cmd_request = 4;
      }
      Parameter Description
      data This denotes the file contents
      program_no Program number to be selected to the device.
      file_name Name of the job to load.
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_message = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_message Response message

      CLI Command:python3 ljv7020.py LoadProgram LJV7020_1 2 savedjob.bin

      Description for CLI Command:

      • LoadProgram: API called to the LJV through CLI Command
      • LJV7020_1: Alias of the Device
      • 2: Program number
      • savejob.bin: File Name

    11. SelectProgram

      Description of the API: Selects the specified program already present on LJV7020 as the active program.
      RPC Command: rpc SelectProgram(SelectProgramCommandRequest) returns (.generic.CommandResponse) {}
      Request: message SelectProgramCommandRequest {
      int32 program_no = 1;
      commandRequest cmd_request = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      program_no Program number to be selected to the device.
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_message = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_message Response message

      CLI Command: python3 ljv7020.py SelectProgram LJV7020_1 3

      Description for CLI Command:

      • LoadProgram: API called to the LJV through CLI Command
      • LJV7020_1: Alias of the Device
      • 2: Program number

    12. SaveProgram

      Description of the API: Retrives the current live program and stream it on gRPC.
      RPC Command: rpc SaveProgram(SaveProgramCommandRequest) returns (stream SaveProgramCommandResponse) {}
      Request: message SaveProgramCommandRequest {
      string file_name = 1;
      int32 program_no = 2;
      commandRequest cmd_request = 3;
      }
      Parameter Description
      file_name file name to be store
      program_no Program number to be selected to the device.
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message SaveProgramCommandResponse {
      bytes data = 1;
      string file_name = 2;
      int64 file_size = 3;
      .generic.CommandResponse cmd_response = 4;
      }
      Parameter Description
      data file contents
      file_name name of the job file
      file_size job file size
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_message Response message

      CLI Command:python3 ljv7020.py SaveProgram LJV7020_1 2 savedjob.bin

      Description for CLI Command:

      • SaveProgram: API called to the LJV through CLI Command
      • LJV7020_1: Alias of the Device
      • 2: Program number
      • savedjob.bin: job file name

    13. GetRawProfileData

      Description of the API: Get raw profile data
      RPC Command: rpc GetRawProfileData(.generic.CommandRequest) returns (stream RawDataResponse) {}
      Request: message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message RawDataResponse {
      bytes data = 1;
      string file_name = 2;
      int64 file_size = 3;
      .generic.CommandResponse cmd_response = 4;
      }
      Parameter Description
      data file contents
      file_name name of the job file
      file_size job file size
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_message Response message

      CLI Command:python3 ljv7020.py GetRawProfileData LJV7020_1

      Description for CLI Command:

      • GetRawProfileData: API called to the LJV through CLI Command
      • LJV7020_1: Alias of the Device

    Limitations of the driver

    • Compatibility : The driver may only be compatible with Keyence LJV7020. limiting its use with other devices.
    • Integration : Integrating the driver with other systems or software may pose challenges, especially if there are compatibility issues or dependencies.

    TESTING AND DEBUGGING

    Following are the Error Codes with Description for LJV :

    Code Description
    0 Normal termination
    1 Failure
    1000 Failed to open the communication path
    1001 The communication path was not established
    1002 Failed to send the command.
    1003 Failed to receive a response.
    1004 A timeout occurred while waiting for the response.
    1005 Failed to allocate memory.
    1006 An invalid parameter was passed.
    1007 The received response data was invalid
    1009 High-speed communication initialization could not be performed.
    100A High-speed communication was initialized.
    100B Error already occurred during high-speed communication (for high-speed communication)
    100C The buffer size passed as an argument is insufficient
    100D The operation mode is advanced (with OUT measurement)
    8081 Batch measurements on and profile compression (time axis) off
    80A0 No profile data.
    8041 Status error (when a system error has occurred).
    8042 Parameter error (when an invalid parameter was set).
    1000 Failed to open the communication path.
    1001 The communication path was not established.
    1002 Failed to send the command.

    GLOSSARY

    • 3D Laser Profiler : A device used for measuring surface profiles and shapes in three dimensions using laser technology.
    • LJ-V Series : A series of 3D laser profilers manufactured by Keyence, including models like LJ-V7000, LJ-V7300, LJ-V7500, etc.
    • Profile : A cross-sectional view of the surface of an object captured by the 3D laser profiler, showing height or depth information.
    • Measurement Range : The distance over which the 3D laser profiler can accurately measure surfaces.
    • Resolution : The smallest change in height or depth that the 3D laser profiler can detect.
    • Repeatability : The ability of the 3D laser profiler to produce consistent results when measuring the same object multiple times.
    • Sampling Interval : The distance between individual measurement points along the profile.
    • Point Cloud : A set of data points in three-dimensional space representing the surface of an object, captured by the 3D laser profiler.
    • Calibration : The process of adjusting the settings of the 3D laser profiler to ensure accurate measurements.
    • Alignment : The process of positioning the 3D laser profiler relative to the object being measured to obtain the desired measurement results.
    • Ethernet/IP : A communication protocol used for connecting the 3D laser profiler to other devices or systems in an industrial automation environment.
    • Measurement Tools : Software features of the 3D laser profiler used for analyzing profiles, such as height measurements, area calculations, and defect detection.
    • Stable Run : A mode in which the 3D laser profiler continuously monitors and adjusts its settings to maintain stable and accurate measurements.
    • Trigger Mode : A mode in which the 3D laser profiler captures a profile only when triggered by an external signal, allowing for precise control of measurement timing.
    • Surface Flatness : A measurement of how flat or smooth a surface is, typically expressed as a deviation from a perfectly flat plane.
    • Height Deviation : The difference in height between a point on the surface and a reference plane, used to assess surface roughness or profile irregularities.
    • Dynamic Range : The range of surface heights that the 3D laser profiler can measure, from the lowest to the highest point.
    • Deflection : The bending or deformation of an object's surface, measured by comparing its profile to a reference profile.

    Basler Camera driver document

    Introduction

    Brief overview of the driver

    This project focuses on developing drivers for Basler Camera (ace2 a2A1920-51gcBAS) to be utilized in automation applications, with a particular emphasis on integrating them with a user interface (UI) application for future use. The project aims to create software components that enable seamless communication between Basler Camera and the UI application, allowing for the camera settings, capture of images, and streaming of data. Through this integration, the project seeks to enhance the usability and functionality of Basler Camera within automated processes, contributing to increased efficiency and productivity in various industrial settings.

    Purpose of the document

    The purpose of this document is to provide a detailed guide for developing a driver for the Basler Camera (ace2 a2A1920-51gcBAS). The driver will enable communication between the Camera and external software application(pylon viewer), allowing to capture an Image, Live Streaming change camera settings like pixel format, exposure time, gain and many more. It covers the software development process, including setting up the development environment, implementing the driver, testing and debugging, and integrating the driver with the Basler Camera.

    The primary objective of the document is to provide a comprehensive guide for developed drivers for Basler Camera (ace2 a2A1920-51gcBAS) used in automation using a UI application. This includes detailed instructions, software installation guide, a device description with its features, and best practices to ensure the successful development and integration of drivers with the devices.

    Scope and objectives

    1. Driver Development: The document focuses on the development of a driver for Basler Camera using industry-standard protocols.
    2. Technical Information: It includes technical specifications of the device, hardware and software requirements, and information about the Software Development Kit (SDK) provided for the device.
    3. SDK Overview: Introduction to Pylon Viewer and its Installation.
    4. Driver Implementation: It covers the development process, including the choice of programming language, information on APIs, how to use APIs, limitations of the driver, precautions to take before execution, and the actual implementation of the driver.
    5. Testing and Debugging: The scope extends to testing and debugging procedures to ensure the reliability and functionality of the driver for real-time application
    6. Documentation and Support: : Lastly, the document includes information on documentation standards and support resources available for developers.

    Overall, the aim is to facilitate the successful development and implementation of the Basler Camera, ensuring it meets the required standards and serves its intended purpose effectively.

    Device Overview

    Description of the device for which the driver is being developed

    Basler offers unmatched camera performance at very competitive prices, without compensating at the expense of quality. The hardware is an important element for your machine vision and computer vision projects, but the Basler camera software suite (Pylon) with the SDK (Software Development Kit) also contributes to high user satisfaction. Basler’s ace is currently the smallest GigE camera in its class with Power over Ethernet (PoE).

    Features are capabilities of Basler cameras and camera modules that can be controlled by configuring firmware parameters.

    All Feature lists of Basler cameras can be accessed here .

    Technical Specifications of Basler

    Type Area Scan Camera
    Model Basler ace2 a2A1920-51gcBAS
    Resolution (H x V Pixels)

    1936 x 1216 (full resolution)

    1920 x 1200 (default resolution)
    Resolution 2.3 MP
    Sensor Type

    Sony IMX392LQR-C

    Progressive scan CMOS

    Global shutter
    Sensor Format 1/2.3"
    Effective Sensor Diagonal 7.9 mm
    Pixel Size (H x V) 3.45 x 3.45 µm
    Frame Rate (at Default Settings) 51 fps
    Product Family ace 2 R
    Mono / Colour Mono
    Image Data Interface

    Fast Ethernet (100 Mbit/s)

    Gigabit Ethernet (1000 Mbit/s)
    Pixel Formats Mono 8, Mono12, Mono12Packed
    Gain 0 – 63 decibels
    Synchronization

    Via hardware trigger

    Via software trigger

    Via free run
    Exposure Time Control

    Via hardware trigger

    Programmable via the camera API
    Camera Power Requirements

    ≈4.4 W (typical) when using Power over Ethernet

    ≈3.1 W (typical) @ 12–24 VDC when supplied via I/O connector
    I/O Lines

    1 opto-coupled input line

    2 general purpose I/O (GPIO) lines
    Lens Mount C-mount
    Size (L x W x H)

    48.9 x 29 x 29 mm (without lens mount or connectors)

    62.2 x 29 x 29 mm (with lens mount and connectors)
    Weight 100 g
    Conformity

    CE (includes RoHS), EAC, UL Listed, FCC, KC, GenICam, GigE Vision, IP30, IEEE

    802.3af (PoE)

    Certificates for your camera model

    For more information, see the Compliance section of the Basler website.
    Software

    Basler pylon Camera Software Suite (version 6.0 or higher)

    Available for Windows, Linux x86, Linux ARM, macOS, and Android

    Software Overview and Requirements – Basler Pylon Viewer

    The pylon Camera Software Suite is a collection of drivers and tools for operating any Basler camera with a Windows, macOS, Android or Linux PC or embedded processing board. As it is based on GenICam technology, it offers barrier-free access to the newest camera models and the latest features. Making changes to an existing camera device in your application essentially becomes a plug and play process.

    Features of Basler Camera Pylon Viewer

    • The pylon Viewer is a versatile application for testing and evaluating Basler cameras.
    • The tree structure of the viewer’s graphical user interface lets you easily find the best camera parameter setup, adjust image quality, and control advanced camera features.
    • Use predefined use cases to easily find any related parameters for your application use case, e.g. check whether the application is losing image data. The pylon Viewer and APIs allow for camera images to be recorded to video files (MP4 or AVI) or into a sequence of single images.
    • The new Data Processing C++ API extends the existing, powerful C++ API for camera configuration and image acquisition, and allows for rapid application development.
    • With the well-designed and user-friendly API you will need just a few lines of code to configure the camera and to grab and process images. The Instant Camera Class takes care of device lifetime and buffer management, as well as setting up a grab loop and handling camera events.
    • Documentation and Samples Comprehensive documentation, plus a collection of programming samples for C ++, C, .NET languages (C#, VB.NET, etc.), illustrate various use cases for different grab strategies, multi-camera applications, recording video files, apply image processing, and many more.

    Hardware and Software requirements

    Hardware / System Requirements:

    • Windows 10 (64 bit) or Windows 11 (64 bit)
    • PC with interface GigE
    • Intel Core i5 or higher processor
    • 8 GB RAM
    • Power supply for the camera- Power Over Ethernet
    • 5 GB of available hard disk space
    • 5400 RPM hard drive
    • DirectX 9-capable video card running at 1024 x 768 or higher display resolution

    Software Requirements:

    • Basler Pylon Camera Software Suite
    • Microsoft Visual Studio for C++ and python IDE for development
    • Additional software or libraries required by the SDK or application

    Additional Requirements

    This version of Microsoft Visual Studio works best with Internet Explorer 10 or higher. If Internet Explorer 10 is not installed on your computer, some features might not work as expected

    Installing Basler Pylon Viewer

    This topic tells you how to install the Basler pylon Camera Software Suite for Windows .

    DRIVER DEVELOPMENT

    Installing the Basler Pylon Camera Software Suite SDK

    Download the desired or current version of the Basler pylon Camera Software Suite from the Basler website:

    www.baslerweb.com

    • Basler pylon 5 Camera Software Suite for Windows

    Install the Basler pylon Camera Software Suite.

    Installing the Desired Free Microsoft Visual Studio Tool

    1. Be ready to have a Microsoft account registration (email address and password).

      The Free Microsoft Studio IDE applications are free developer tools for single users and small commercial teams. To download and use them longer than the trial period, a Microsoft account is requested that is easily and free available through registration with a valid email address.

    2. Download the desired free Microsoft Visual Studio tool:
      • Microsoft Visual Studio Express 2013 for Windows Desktop
      • Microsoft Visual Studio Community

    Driver Implementation

    The following drivers or APIs are developed and tested

    1. Open Device
    2. Close Device
    3. Get Device Details
    4. Set Exposure Time – (Max: 999985 micro seconds. Min: 35 micro seconds)
    5. Set Pixel Format – (Mono 8, Mono 12, Mono12 Packed)
    6. Set Gain – (0 to 63db)
    7. Save Current Configuration Parameters
    8. Load Current Configuration Parameters
    9. Get Image File - (.jpeg, png, bmp, tiff, .bmp)
    10. Single Trigger
    11. Live Streaming

    gRPC API’s Description for Basler Camera

    1. OpenDevice

      Description for OpenDevice API: Establishes a connection to the Basler Camera, initializing communication for further operations.

      RPC Command :rpc OpenDevice(.generic.CommandIPRequest) returns(.generic.GenericDeviceModel) {}

      Request:
      message CommandIPRequest {
      string ip_address = 1;
      string com = 2;
      int64 port_address = 3;
      int32 device_id = 4;
      string file_path = 5;
      int64 device_model =6;
      optional string device_alias=7;
      int32 axis =8;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      ip_address Specifies the IP address of the device.
      com Indicates the communication protocol or interface to be used
      port_address Denotes the specific port address for the device on the communication interface.
      device_id Unique identifier for the device, used to distinguish it from other devices in the system.
      file_path The path to the file, which may include configuration, program, or data files for the device.
      device_model Represents the model number or type of the device being communicated with.
      device_alias A user-defined alias for the device, providing a more descriptive or convenient reference.
      axis Specifies the axis number (e.g., X, Y, Z) on which the command or operation will be performed.
      enum DeviceType{
      NONE = 0;
      SENSOR_3D = 1;
      MOTION_STAGE = 2;
      CAMERA = 3;
      IO_MODULE = 4;
      SAFETY_CONTROLLER = 5;
      ANIMATIC_MOTOR=6;
      }
      enum DeviceModel{
      DUMMY_MODEL = 0;
      ED527 = 1;
      ED588 = 2 ;
      JR3000 = 3;
      OPTOE = 4;
      BASLER = 5;
      SPiiPlusEC=6;
      GT6600 = 7;
      MOTOR = 8;
      }
      enum DeviceStatus{
      OFFLINE = 0;
      ONLINE = 1;
      NOT_REACHABLE =2;
      }
      message CommandResponse{
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_message = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_message Response message code
      CLI Command: python baslercamera.py OpenDevice 192.168.4.20 Basler_1
      Description for CLI Command
      • OpenDevice: API called to the Basler Camera through CLI Command to connect and initialize all resources
      • 192.168.4.20: IP Address of the device
      • Basler_1: Aliased Name for Basler Camera

    2. CloseDevice

      Description for CloseDevice API: Disconnects from the Basler Camera, releasing all resources and deleting associated handlers to ensure a clean shutdown.

      RPC Command: rpc CloseDevice(.generic.CommandRequest) returns(.generic.CommandResponse) {}

      Request: message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias Unique alias of the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python baslercamera.py CloseDevice Basler_1
      Description for CLI Command:
      • CloseDevice: API called to the Basler Camera through CLI Command to Close Camera Connection
      • Basler_1: Aliased Name for device

    3. GetDeviceDetails

      Description for GetDeviceDetails API: Retrieves detailed information about the connected Basler Camera, including its configuration and status.

      RPC Command : rpc GetDeviceDetails(.generic. CommandRequest) returns (.generic.GenericDeviceModel) {}

      Request:
      message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias Unique alias of the device
      Response:
      message GenericDeviceModel{
      string instance_id = 1;
      string device_alias = 2;
      DeviceType device_type = 3;
      DeviceModel device_model_name = 4;
      optional DeviceStatus device_status = 5;
      string ipaddr = 6;
      string mac_addr = 7;
      google.protobuf.Value conn_handle=8;
      string port_name = 9;
      int64 port_address = 10;
      CommandResponse cmd_response = 11;
      }
      Parameter Description
      instance_id New instance for the device in the enumeration
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      device_type Indicates the type of device like Motion stage, Safety Controller etc (defined below in the DeviceType enum)
      device_model_name Indicate the model name for each device (define below in the DeviceModel enum)
      device_status Indicate whether the device is online , offline or not reachable (define below in the device status enum)
      ipaddr Indicate the ipaddress of the device
      mac_addr Indicate the mac address of the device
      Conn_handle Handle object to keep the device open
      port_name Port name
      port_address Port address
      cmd_response Indicates command response that describes API response code and its description (Defined below in CommandResponse)
      enum DeviceType{
      NONE = 0;
      SENSOR_3D = 1;
      MOTION_STAGE = 2;
      CAMERA = 3;
      IO_MODULE = 4;
      SAFETY_CONTROLLER = 5;
      ANIMATIC_MOTOR=6;
      }
      enum DeviceModel{
      DUMMY_MODEL = 0;
      ED527 = 1;
      ED588 = 2 ;
      JR3000 = 3;
      OPTOE = 4;
      BASLER = 5;
      SPiiPlusEC=6;
      GT6600 = 7;
      MOTOR = 8;
      }
      enum DeviceStatus{
      OFFLINE = 0;
      ONLINE = 1;
      NOT_REACHABLE =2;
      }
      message CommandResponse{
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_message = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_message Response Message
      CLI Command: python baslercamera.py GetDeviceDetails Basler_1
      Description for CLI Command:
      • GetDeviceDetails: API called to the Basler Camera through CLI Command
      • Basler_1: Aliased Name for device

    4. ChangeAlias

      Description for ChangeAlias API: Updates the alias of the device, allowing it to be referenced by a new identifier.

      RPC Command: rpc changeAlias(ChangeAliasRequest) returns (CommandResponse) {}

      Request: message ChangeAliasRequest{
      string current_alias=1;
      string new_alias=2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      current_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      new_alias The device_alias to change to
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python baslercamera.py changeAlias current_alias new_alias
        Description for CLI Command:
      • ChangeAlias: API called to the Basler Camera through CLI Command to get new alias name
      • current_alias: The current device_alias used to refer to the device
      • new_alias: The device_alias to change to

    5. SetExposureTime

      Description of the API: Sets the exposure time for the Basler Camera to control the amount of light captured during image acquisition.

      RPC Command: rpc SetExposureTime(SetExposureTimeBaslerCameraRequest) returns(.generic.CommandResponse) {}

      Request: message SetExposureTimeBaslerCameraRequest {
      float time_value = 1;
      CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
      }
       message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      time_value Time to be set in float. Max : 999985 micro seconds. Min: 35 micro seconds
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python baslercamera.py SetExposureTime Basler_1 5000

      Description for CLI Command:

      • SetExposureTime: API called to the Basler Camera through CLI Command
      • Basler_1: Alias of the Device
      • 5000: Sample Exposure Time value Configured in millisecond

    6. SetPixelFormat

      Description of the API: Configures the pixel format of the Basler Camera for image capture.

      RPC Command: rpc SetPixelFormat(SetPixelBaslerCameraRequest) returns(.generic.CommandResponse) {}

      Request: message SetPixelBaslerCameraRequest {
      string pixel_format = 1;
      CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
      }
       message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      pixel_format Pixel Format to be configured. "PixelFormat_Mono12", "PixelFormat_Mono12Packed" or "PixelFormat_Mono8" Formats are supported
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python baslercamera.py SetPixelFormat Basler_1 PixelFormat_Mono12

      Description for CLI Command:

      • SetPixelFormat: API called to the Basler Camera through CLI Command
      • Basler_1: Alias of the Device
      • PixelFormat_Mono12: Setting Pixel Format as Mono12

    7. SetGain

      Description of the API: Configures the gain setting for the basler Camera.

      RPC Command: rpc SetGain(SetGainBaslerCameraRequest) returns(.generic.CommandResponse) {}

      Request: message SetGainBaslerCameraRequest {
      float gain_value = 1;
      CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
      }
       message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      gain_value Gain value to be Set in decibles. 0-63 decibles will be the range
      device_alias Unique alias of the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python baslercamera.py SetGain Basler_1 40

      Description for CLI Command:

      • SetGain: API called to the Basler Camera through CLI Command
      • Basler_1: Alias of the Device
      • 40: Gain to be configured

    8. LoadCameraConfig

      Description of the API: Loads the camera's configuration from a pre-existing .pfs feature file.

      RPC Command: rpc LoadCameraConfig(stream LoadConfigBaslerCameraRequest) returns(.generic.CommandResponse) {}

      Request: message LoadConfigBaslerCameraRequest {
      string file_name = 1;
      bytes config_data = 2;
      CommandRequest cmd_request = 3;
      }
       message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      file_name indicates pre-existing configuration file (.pfs format) to be loaded to the camera
      config_data Represents camera features data like Gain, Time, Resolution, fps etc
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python baslercamera.py LoadCameraConfig Basler_1 BaslerCameraConfig.pfs

      Description for CLI Command:

      • LoadCameraConfig: API called to the Basler Camera through CLI Command to Load Camera features.
      • Basler_1 : Alias of the Device
      • BaslerCameraConfig.pfs: Camera Features File to be Loaded to Camera

    9. SaveCameraConfig

      Description of the API: Saves Camera's Configuration in .pfs file

      RPC Command: rpc SaveCameraConfig(SaveConfigBaslerCameraRequest) returns(stream SaveConfigBaslerCameraResponse) {}

      Request: message SaveConfigBaslerCameraRequest {
      string file_name = 1;
      CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
      }
       message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      file_name User defined .pfs file name to be provided to save camera’s features.
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message SaveConfigBaslerCameraResponse {
      optional bytes config_data = 1;
      optional string file_name = 2;
      optional int64 file_size = 3;
      CommandResponse cmd_response = 4;
      }
       message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      config_data Camera’s Features like fps, gain, time , height , etc
      file_name Name of File under which camera’s Configurations are saved
      file_size Indicates the size of the configuration file name received from the server
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python baslercamera.py SaveCameraConfig Basler_1 BaslerCameraConfig.pfs

      Description for CLI Command:

      • SaveCameraConfig: API called to the Basler Camera through CLI Command to Save Camera Features.
      • Basler_1: Alias of the Device
      • BaslerCameraConfig.pfs: User Defined file name in .pfs format

    10. GetImage

      Description of the API: To Capture Single Image with user defined name and Format

      RPC Command: rpc GetImage(GetImageFileBaslerCameraRequest) returns(stream GetImageFileBaslerCameraResponse) {}

      Request: message GetImageFileBaslerCameraRequest {
      string file_name = 1;
      }
       message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message GetImageFileBaslerCameraResponse {
      optional bytes image_data = 1;
      optional string file_name = 2;
      optional int64 file_size = 3;
      .generic.CommandResponse cmd_response = 4;
      }
       message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      image_data Indicates image data
      file_name Name of the image file with format. Supported file format are .jpeg , .png , .tif and .bmp
      file_size Size of the captured image file
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python baslercamera.py GetImageFile Basler_1 image.jpeg

      Description for CLI Command:

      • GetImageFile: API called to the Basler Camera through CLI Command to Capture and Save Image
      • Basler_1: Alias of the Device
      • image.jpeg: User Defined name with Format.

    11. SingleTrigger

      Description of the API: Captures a single image and streams it over grpc server

      RPC Command: rpc SingleTrigger(.generic.CommandRequest) returns(stream SingleTriggerBaslerCameraResponse) {}

      Request: message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message ImageMetaData {
      int32 image_width = 1;
      int32 image_height = 2;
      PixelFormat image_format = 3;
      }       message SingleTriggerBaslerCameraResponse {
      optional ImageMetaData image_data = 1;
      optional string file_name = 2;
      optional int64 file_size = 3;
      optional bytes buffer = 4;
      .generic.CommandResponse cmd_response = 5;
      }
       message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      image_data Image data representing, its height, width and pixel format
      file_name Name of the image file streamed along with extension.
      file_size Size of the image file streamed
      buffer Buffer which contain image bytes
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python baslercamera.py SingleTrigger Basler_1

      Description for CLI Command:

      • SingleTrigger: API called to the Basler Camera through CLI Command to Capture a Single Live Image and Stream over grpc
      • Basler_1: Alias of the Device

    12. LiveStreaming

      Description of the API: To Stream Continuous Live Images through Start and Stop APIs

      RPC Command: rpc StartLiveStreaming(stream BaslerCamLiveStream) returns(stream BaslerCamLiveStream) {}

      rpc StopLiveStreaming(.generic.CommandRequest) returns(.generic.CommandResponse) {}
      Request message FrameModel {
      int64 frame_size = 1;
      bytes frame_data = 2;
      }
       message BaslerCamLiveStream {
      FrameModel frame_model = 1;
      .generic.CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
      }
       message CommandRequest {
      int64 device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      frame_size Indicates size of the frame to be captured in terms of height and width
      frame_data Indicates frame or image data
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response message FrameModel {
      int64 frame_size = 1;
      bytes frame_data = 2;
      }
       message BaslerCamLiveStream {
      FrameModel frame_model = 1;
      .generic.CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
      }
       message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python baslercamera.py StartLiveStreaming Basler_1

      python baslercamera.py StopLiveStreaming Basler_1

      Description for CLI Command:
      • StartLiveStreaming: API called to the Basler Camera through CLI Command to Capture Continuous Images and Stream over grpc
      • StopLiveStreaming:API called to the Basler Camera through CLI Command to Stop Capturing Continuous Images.
      • Basler_1: Alias of the Device

    Limitations of the driver

    1. Compatibility: The driver may only be compatible with ace2 a2A1920-51gcBAS versions of Basler Camera, limiting its use with other devices.
    2. Integration: Integrating the driver with other systems or software may pose challenges, especially if there are compatibility issues or dependencies.
    3. Modifying Environment(Pylon Viewer) may affect Live Streaming.

    Precautions to take before executing the driver

    Ensure to load good configuration file through LoadConfig API to overcome any issues with driver.

    TESTING AND DEBUGGING

    Error Types and codes with Description for Basler Camera

    Error Type Error Code Error Description
    GENAPI_E_OK 0 Operation completed successfully
    GENAPI_E_FAIL C2000001 Unspecified error occurred. Call GenApiGetLastErrorDetail() for more information about the error
    GENAPI_E_INVALID_ARG C2000002 Function called with invalid argument
    GENAPI_E_INSUFFICIENT_BUFFER C2000003 Buffer size passed is less than required.
    GENAPI_E_INVALID_NODEMAPHANDLE C2000004 An invalid node map handle has been passed.
    GENAPI_E_NODE_NOT_FOUND C2000005 Specified node not found in node map.
    GENAPI_E_INVALID_NODEHANDLE C2000006 An invalid node handle has been passed
    GENAPI_E_RESULT_RANGE_EXCEEDED C2000007 A 64 bit result will be truncated if returned as a 32 bit value.
    GENAPI_E_LIMITS_EXCEEDED C2000008 The value exceeds the valid range.
    GENAPI_E_PROPERTY_ERROR C2000009 Generic GenICam property error occurred. Call GenApiGetLastErrorDetail() for more information about the error
    GENAPI_E_TIMEOUT C200000A Timeout expired.
    GENAPI_E_TYPE_ERROR C200000B Expression has wrong type.
    GENAPI_E_INDEX_ERROR C200000C An index is out of range.
    GENAPI_E_OBJECT_ILLEGAL_STATE C200000E Object state illegal for operation. Call GenApiGetLastErrorDetail() for more information about the error
    GENAPI_E_INVALID_NODECALLBACKHANDLE C200000F An invalid callback handle has been passed.
    GENAPI_E_LOGICAL_ERROR C2000010 Program logic error. Call GenApiGetLastErrorDetail() for more information about the error.
    GENAPI_E_INVALID_FILEHANDLE C2000011 An invalid file handle has been passed.
    PYLON_E_INVALID_DEVICEHANDLE C3000001 An invalid Device handle has been passed.
    PYLON_E_INVALID_DEVICEINFOHANDLE C3000002 An invalid DeviceInfo handle has been passed.
    PYLON_E_INVALID_DEVICEINFO_PROPERTY C3000003 An invalid DeviceInfoProperty handle has been passed.
    PYLON_E_INVALID_STREAMGRABBERHANDLE C3000004 An invalid StreamGrabber handle has been passed.
    PYLON_E_INVALID_CHUNKPARSERHANDLE C3000005 An invalid ChunkParser handle has been passed.
    PYLON_E_INVALID_WAITOBJECTHANDLE C3000006 An invalid WaitObject handle has been passed.
    PYLON_E_INVALID_EVENTGRABBERHANDLE C3000007 An invalid EventGrabber handle has been passed.
    PYLON_E_INVALID_EVENTADAPTERHANDLE C3000008 An invalid EventAdapter handle has been passed.
    PYLON_E_INVALID_CONVERTERHANDLE C3000009 An invalid Converter handle has been passed.
    PYLON_E_INVALID_WAITOBJECTSHANDLE C300000A An invalid WaitObjects handle has been passed.
    PYLON_E_INVALID_INTERFACEHANDLE C300000C An invalid Interface handle has been passed.
    PYLON_E_INVALID_INTERFACEINFOHANDLE C300000D An invalid InterfaceInfo handle has been passed.
    PYLON_E_INVALID_DECOMPRESSORHANDLE C300000E An invalid decompressor handle has been passed.

    Custom Error Codes

    Error Code Error Description
    3 File Format is not supported, Please Provide Correct File Format
    4 Provided Pixel Format is Not Supported, Please Provide Correct Pixel Format
    5 Invalid handle or camera not initialized

    RESOURCES AND LINKS

    • Pylon Deployment Guide: : pylon Deployment Guide | Basler Product Documentation (baslerweb.com)
    • Pylon SDK Sample Manual: pylon SDK Samples Manual | Basler Product Documentation (baslerweb.com)
    • Pylon C++ Programmer’s Guide: pylon C++ Programmer's Guide | Basler Product Documentation (baslerweb.com) , Programmer's Guide | Basler Product Documentation (baslerweb.com)
    • Basler Product Documentation: https://www2.baslerweb.com/en/downloads/document-downloads/basler-product-documentation-offline-version

    GLOSSARY

    Glossary of Terms for Basler Camera:

    • Driver: A software component that enables communication between the operating system and a hardware device, in this case, a camera.
    • SDK (Software Development Kit): A set of tools, libraries, and documentation that developers use to create software applications for a specific platform or framework.
    • API (Application Programming Interface): A set of rules and protocols that allow different software applications to communicate with each other.
    • Firmware: Software that is embedded into a hardware device, such as a camera, to control its operation.
    • Resolution: The number of pixels in an image, typically measured in megapixels (MP), that determines the level of detail and clarity in the image.
    • Frame Rate: The number of frames or images displayed or processed per second, often measured in frames per second (fps).
    • Gain: Gain in the context of a camera refers to the amplification of the signal from the camera sensor. However, increasing the gain too much can introduce noise into the image, reducing its quality. Gain is usually measured in decibels (dB).
    • Exposure Time: : The amount of light that reaches the camera sensor, controlled by settings such as shutter speed, and aperture.
    • Pixel: The smallest unit of a digital image, representing a single point of color.
    • Buffer: A temporary storage area in memory used to hold data, such as images, before it is processed or transferred.
    • Streaming: The process of continuously transmitting data, such as video, over a network in real-time.

    Janome driver document

    Introduction

    Brief overview of the project

    This project centers on developing robust drivers for Janome robots, specifically the JR3403 (3-axis) and JR3304 (4-axis) models, to enhance their application in automation processes. A unified driver is being created to support both models, with a focus on integrating these robots with a user-friendly UI application for seamless control and monitoring.

    The project's primary objective is to establish smooth communication between Janome robots and external systems, enabling operators to intuitively manage and monitor robotic operations. This integration aims to improve usability, streamline automated workflows, and boost productivity across industrial applications.

    Purpose of the document
