    The purpose of this document is to provide a detailed guide for developing a driver for the Janome device. The driver will enable communication between the robot and external software applications. It covers the software development process, including setting up the development environment, implementing the driver, testing and debugging, and integrating the driver with the Janome device.

    The primary objective of the document is to provide a comprehensive guide for developed drivers for Janome robot used in automation using a UI application. This includes detailed instructions, code examples, and best practices to ensure the successful development and integration of drivers with the devices.

    Scope and objectives

    1. Driver Development: he document focuses on the development of a driver for SC10 using industry-standard protocols.
    2. Technical Information: It includes technical specifications of the device, hardware and software requirements,Approach used for driver development.
    3. Driver Implementation: It covers the development process, including the choice of programming language, information on APIs, how to use APIs, limitations of the driver, precautions to take before execution, and the actual implementation of the driver.
    4. Testing and Debugging: The scope extends to testing and debugging procedures to ensure the reliability and functionality of the driver.
    5. Documentation and Support: The document also includes information on documentation standards and support resources available for developers.

    Overall, the aim is to facilitate the successful development and implementation of the Janome driver, ensuring it meets the required standards and serves its intended purpose effectively.

    Device Overview

    Description of the device for which the driver is being developed

    The Janome Desktop Robot JR3000 Series represents a new generation of robots characterized by their affordability, efficiency, and functionality. These robots have been engineered to offer high performance at a low cost. One of the key achievements of this project is the successful reduction of price without compromising on essential functionalities.

    A notable feature of these robots is the utilization of stepping motors in conjunction with specialized micro step driving circuits. This innovative combination serves to conserve energy and minimize the required installation space. By leveraging advanced technologies and optimization strategies, the JR3000 Series delivers optimal performance while remaining cost-effective and versatile.

    Some of the applications of the Janome robot includes:

    • Liquid dispensing
    • Screw tightening and loosening
    • Automatic Tool Bit Replacement
    • Depaneling
    • Pick and place

    Technical Specifications of Janome

    LAN Communication Settings (IP Address Settings)

    The settable items consist of the following three types:

    • IP Address
    • Subnet Mask
    • Default Gateway

    The following values are set to the robot by default:

    • IP Address: 192.168.200.180
    • Subnet Mask: 255.255.255. 0
    • Default Gateway: 0. 0. 0. 0

    COM Communication Settings

    The settable items consist of the following

    • Baud rate: 2400/4800/9600/19200/38400/57600/76800/115200
    • Character length: 8 bit/7 bit
    • Stop bit: 1 bit/2 bit
    • Parity: None/Even parity/ Odd parity

    The default values for the communication settings are as follows:

    • Baud rate 9600
    • Character length 8 bit
    • Stop bit 1 bit
    • Parity None

    Max Length = 1024 bytes

    Header Data(ASCII Data) Sum Value Footer
    Item Details Reference
    Header An identifier to determine the frame head. Fixed as $(dollar).
    Data The transferred data. ASCII data. This is called "ASCII data" in this manual.
    Sum Value The sum value (2 lines) to determine the data area validity.
    Footer An identifier to determine the frame end. Fixed as CR (carriage return).

    Ethernet Communication Settings

    Max Length = 2044 bytes

    Data Length Fixed Identifier (0x0303) Data (ASCII data)
    Item Content Reference
    Data Length The transfer data total length (un-signed 4 byte length) Maximum 65535 bytes
    Fixed Identifier The identifier for performing a general classification of the data (2 bytes) Fixed with the value 0x0303
    Data The transferred data. ASCII data. This is referred to as "ASCII data" from here onwards in this manual

    Janome JR3403 Specifications are as shown below:

    Operating Range X & Y Axis 400 x 400 mm
    Z Axis 150 mm
    Maximum Portable Load X Axis (Workpiece) 15 kg
    Y Axis (Tool) 7 kg
    Maximum Speed (PTP Drive) = Settable Speed Range X & Y Axis 900 mm/sec [9-900 mm/sec]
    Z Axis 400 mm/sec [4-400 mm/sec]
    Maximum Speed (CP Drive) = Settable Speed Range X, Y, Z Combined 850 mm/sec [0.1-850 mm/sec]
    Repeatability X & Y Axis ±0.007 mm
    Z Axis ±0.007 mm
    External Dimensions W x D x H 584 x 631 x 807 mm
    Robot Weight 42 kg
    Drive Method 5 Phase Pulse Motor (optional encoder attachment)
    Control Method PTP Control, CP Control
    External Input I/O-SYS 16 Inputs
    I/O-1 8 Inputs
    External Output I/O-SYS 16 Outputs
    I/O-1 8 Outputs (including 4 relay outputs)
    Power Source AC 90 - 125V / AC 180 - 240V (single phase)
    Power Consumption 200 W

    Janome JR3304 Specifications are as shown below:

    Operating Range X & Y Axis 300 x 320 mm
    Z Axis 100 mm
    R Axis ±360°
    Maximum Portable Load Workpiece 15 kg
    Tool 7 kg
    Maximum Speed (PTP Drive) = Settable Speed Range X & Y Axis 900 mm/sec [9-900 mm/sec]
    Z Axis 400 mm/sec [4-400 mm/sec]
    R Axis 900°/s (8～900)
    Maximum Speed (CP Drive) = Settable Speed Range X, Y, Z Combined 850 mm/sec [0.1-850 mm/sec]
    Repeatability X & Y Axis ±0.001 mm
    Z Axis ±0.001 mm
    R Axis ±0.008
    External Dimensions W x D x H 584 x 631 x 894 mm
    Robot Weight 46 kg
    Drive Method 5 Phase Pulse Motor (optional encoder attachment)
    Control Method PTP Control, CP Control
    External Input I/O-SYS 16 Inputs
    I/O-1 8 Inputs
    External Output I/O-SYS 16 Outputs
    I/O-1 8 Outputs (including 4 relay outputs)
    Power Source AC 90 - 125V / AC 180 - 240V (single phase)
    Power Consumption 200 W

    Hardware and Software requirements

    “JR C-Points II” is an application software with which we can create, edit and save teaching and customizing data all on the PC. It is available in 4 languages, English, Germain, Chinese and Japanese. JR C-Points II is available for Screw Tightening, Dispensing and Standard specification robots.

    The following system configurations are necessary to run the software JR C-Points II :

    Computer APC capable of running Windows® 7/8.1/10
    Memory capacity 512 MB or more
    Os

    Microsoft Windows® 7/8.1/10

    NOTE: compatible with both 32bit/64bit systems
    Hard disk capacity After installing Windows® 7/8.1/10 a minimum of 2 GB of open hard disk space is required
    Video Card

    Capable of displaying 32 bit color with a resolution of 1280x800 or 1366x768

    However, we recommend a video card with a resolution of 1920x1080 if displaying images using a robot with the USB camera (optional)
    LAN (Ethernet)

    To connect to the robot, a LAN cable with the following specifications are required:

    • Straight cable (CAT5)

    The connectable Ethernet specifications (on the PC side) are as follows:

    • 10BASE-T/100BASE-TX
    • LAN Port: RJ-45

    DRIVER DEVELOPMENT

    Introduction to driver development for the device

    • Janome_merge.py: JanomeDriverAPIs.py serves as the core interface, offering APIs that encapsulate the minimum functionalities required by Janome devices, as specified by Waymo. These APIs enable developers to interact with Janome devices programmatically, accessing essential functionalities with ease.
    • JanomeProtocol.py: JanomeProtocol.py plays a crucial role in establishing communication between the software and Janome devices. It provides APIs to connect to the device, send and receive packets, and encode/decode data according to the Janome protocol. This component ensures reliable and efficient data transmission, facilitating seamless interaction between the software and Janome devices.
    • JanomeData.py: JanomeData.py serves as a repository for storing all device-related details, including IP addresses, ports, and data commands. This centralized storage ensures that essential device information is readily accessible to the software, streamlining the development process and enhancing overall system efficiency.

    Choice of programming language (Python or C++)

    For developing the driver we have used Python.

    Driver Impementation

    1. OpenDevice
    2. CloseDevice
    3. GetDeviceDetails
    4. ChangeAlias
    5. ListProgram
    6. SelectProgram
    7. RunProgram
    8. AbsolutePtpMovementControl
    9. RelativePtpMovementControl
    10. SetPtpVelocity
    11. SetPtpAcceleration
    12. AddPositions
    13. SaveData
    14. ReadIo
    15. ReadAllIO
    16. SetIO
    17. ReturnHome
    18. GetStatus
    19. MechanicalInitialization
    20. GetPosition

    gRPC API’s Description for Janome

    1. OpenDevice

      Description for OpenDevice API: Establishes a connection to the Janome, initializing communication for further operations.

      RPC Command : rpc OpenDevice(.generic.CommandIPRequest) returns(.generic.GenericDeviceModel) {}
      Request:
      message CommandIPRequest{
      string ip_address = 1;
      int model=2;
      int64 port_address=3;
      int32 device_id = 4;
      string file_path = 5;
      int64 device_model =6;
      optional string device_alias=7;
      int32 axis =8;
      }
      Parameter Description
      ip_address ip_address IP Address of the Device
      Model Model number of the device.
      port_address Port address of the device with serial communication (ex. 1)
      Response
      message GenericDeviceModel{
      string instance_id = 1;
      string device_alias = 2;
      DeviceType device_type = 3;
      DeviceModel device_model_name = 4;
      optional DeviceStatus device_status = 5;
      string ipaddr = 6;
      string mac_addr = 7;
      google.protobuf.Value conn_handle=8;
      string port_name = 9;
      int64 port_address = 10;
      CommandResponse cmd_response = 11;
      }
      Parameter Description
      instance_id New instance for the device in the enumeration
      device_alias Unique identifier (alphanumeric) for every device in the enumeration
      device_type Indicates the type of device like Motion stage, Safety Controller etc (defined below in the DeviceType enum)
      device_model_name Indicate the model name for each device (define below in the DeviceModel enum)
      device_status Indicate whether the device is online , offline or not reachable (define below in the device status enum)
      ipaddr Indicate the ipaddress of the device
      mac_addr Indicate the mac address of the device
      Conn_handle Handle object to keep the device open
      port_name Port name
      port_address Port address
      cmd_response Indicates command response that describes API response code and its description (Defined below in CommandResponse)

      enum DeviceType{
      NONE = 0;
      SENSOR_3D = 1;
      MOTION_STAGE = 2;
      CAMERA = 3;
      IO_MODULE = 4;
      SAFETY_CONTROLLER = 5;
      ANIMATIC_MOTOR=6;
      }
      enum DeviceModel{
      DUMMY_MODEL = 0;
      ED527 = 1;
      ED588 = 2 ;
      JR3000 = 3;
      OPTOE = 4;
      BASLER = 5;
      SPiiPlusEC=6;
      GT6600 = 7;
      MOTOR = 8;
      }
      enum DeviceStatus{
      OFFLINE = 0;
      ONLINE = 1;
      NOT_REACHABLE =2;
      }
      message CommandResponse{
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_message = 2;
      }
      ParameterDescription
      resp_code resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_message resp_message Description of the response code

      CLI Command for JR3403: python janome.py OpenDevice 192.168.200.100 Janome_1 10031 17

      CLI Command for JR3304: python janome.py OpenDevice 192.168.200.101 Janome_1 10031 3

      Description for CLI Command
      • OpenDevice: API called to the Janome through CLI Command to connect and initialize all resources
      • 192.168.0.4: IP Address of the device
      • Janome_1 Aliased name of the device
      • 10031 Port number of the device.
      • 3 Enum Value:3 will be considered for 3304 and 17 will be considerd for 3403.

    2. CloseDevice

      Description for CloseDevice API: Disconnects from the COnnected Janome, releasing all resources and deleting associated handlers to ensure a clean shutdown.
      RPC Command: rpc CloseDevice(.generic.CommandRequest) returns(.generic.CommandResponse) {}
      Request: message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias Unique alias of the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code

      CLI Command for JR3403: python janome.py CloseDevice JANOME_1 3

      CLI Command for JR3304: python janome.py CloseDevice JANOME_1 17

      Description for CLI Command:
      • CloseDevice: API called to the Janome through CLI Command
      • JANOME_1: Aliased Name for Janome

    3. GetDeviceDetails

      Description for GetDeviceDetails API: Retrieves detailed information about the connected Janome, including its configuration and status.

      RPC Command : rpc GetDeviceDetails(.generic. CommandRequest) returns (.generic.GenericDeviceModel) {}

      Request:
      message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias Unique alias of the device
      Response:
      message GenericDeviceModel{
      string instance_id = 1;
      string device_alias = 2;
      DeviceType device_type = 3;
      DeviceModel device_model_name = 4;
      optional DeviceStatus device_status = 5;
      string ipaddr = 6;
      string mac_addr = 7;
      google.protobuf.Value conn_handle=8;
      string port_name = 9;
      int64 port_address = 10;
      CommandResponse cmd_response = 11;
      }
      Parameter Description
      instance_id New instance for the device in the enumeration
      device_alias Unique identifier (alphanumeric) for every device in the enumeration
      device_type Indicates the type of device like Motion stage, Safety Controller etc (defined below in the DeviceType enum)
      device_model_name Indicate the model name for each device (define below in the DeviceModel enum)
      device_status Indicate whether the device is online , offline or not reachable (define below in the device status enum)
      ipaddr Indicate the ipaddress of the device
      mac_addr Indicate the mac address of the device
      Conn_handle Handle object to keep the device open
      port_name Port name
      port_address Port address
      cmd_response Indicates command response that describes API response code and its description (Defined below in CommandResponse)
      enum DeviceType{
      NONE = 0;
      SENSOR_3D = 1;
      MOTION_STAGE = 2;
      CAMERA = 3;
      IO_MODULE = 4;
      SAFETY_CONTROLLER = 5;
      ANIMATIC_MOTOR=6;
      }
      enum DeviceModel{
      DUMMY_MODEL = 0;
      ED527 = 1;
      ED588 = 2 ;
      JR3000 = 3;
      OPTOE = 4;
      BASLER = 5;
      SPiiPlusEC=6;
      GT6600 = 7;
      MOTOR = 8;
      }
      enum DeviceStatus{
      OFFLINE = 0;
      ONLINE = 1;
      NOT_REACHABLE =2;
      }
      message CommandResponse{
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_message = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_message Description of the response code

      CLI Command: python3 janome.py GetDeviceDetails JANOME_1
      Note:CLI Command same for both Janome.

      Description for CLI Command:
      • GetDeviceDetails: API called to the Janome through CLI Command
      • JANOME_1: Aliased Name for Janome

    4. ChangeAlias

      Description for ChangeAlias API: Updates the alias of the device, allowing it to be referenced by a new identifier.
      RPC Command: rpc changeAlias(ChangeAliasRequest) returns (CommandResponse) {} Request: message ChangeAliasRequest{
      string current_alias=1;
      string new_alias=2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      current_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      new_alias The device_alias to change to
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code

      CLI Command: python janome.py ChangeAlias JANOME_1 JANOME_2
      Note:CLI Command same for both Janome JR3304 and JR3303.

      Description for CLI Command:
      • ChangeAlias: API called to the Janome through CLI Command
      • JANOME_1: The current device_alias used to refer to the device
      • JANOME_2: The device_alias to change to

    5. List the programs

      Description of the API: API to list the available programs in the uploaded C&T Data
      RPC Command: rpc ListPrograms(CommandRequest) returns (ListofProgramsResponse) {}
      Request: message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code

      CLI Command: python janome.py ListPrograms JANOME_1
      Note:CLI Command same for both Janome.

      Description for CLI Command:
      • ListPrograms: API called to the Janome through CLI Command
      • JANOME_1: Aliased name of the Device

    6. SelectProgram

      Description of the API: API to select the program which is available in C&T data
      RPC Command: rpc SelectProgram(SelectProgramsRequest) returns (CommandResponse) {}
      Request: message SelectProgramsRequest {
      int64 program_number = 1;
      CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
      }
       message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      program_number Program number to be changed (Ranges 0 to 999)
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code

      CLI Command: python janome.py SelectProgram JANOME_1 1
      Note:CLI Command same for both Janome.

      Description for CLI Command:
      • SelectProgram: API called to the Janome through CLI Command
      • JANOME_1: Aliased name of the Device
      • 1: Number of the Program that needs to be selected

    7. RunProgram

      Description of the API: API designed to initiate the execution of a specified program stored within the C&T (Control & Teach) data of the Janome
      RPC Command: rpc RunProgram(RunProgramRequest) returns (CommandResponse) {}
      Request: message RunProgramRequest {
      int64 program_number = 1;
      CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
      }
       message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      program_number Program number to be exectued (Ranges 0 to 999)
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code

      CLI Command: python janome.py RunProgram JANOME_1 1
      Note:CLI Command same for both Janome.

      Description for CLI Command:
      • RunProgram: API called to the Janome through CLI Command
      • JANOME_1: Aliased Name of the Device
      • 1: Number of the Program to be executed

    8. AbsolutePtpMovementControl

      Description of the API: API to execute Absolute PTP movement of the specified co-ordinates
      RPC Command: rpc AbsolutePtpMovementControl(AbsolutePtpMovementControlRequest) returns (CommandResponse) {}
      Request: message AbsolutePtpMovementControlRequest {
      int64 x_coordinate = 1;
      int64 y_coordinate = 2;
      int64 z_coordinate = 3;
      int64 r_coordinate = 3;
      CommandRequest cmd_request = 4;
      }
       message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      x_coordinate X co-ordinate for PTP movement, units in mm
      y_coordinate Y co-ordinate for PTP movement, units in mm
      z_coordinate Z co-ordinate for PTP movement, units in mm
      r_coordinate R co-ordinate for PTP movement, units in mm
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code

      CLI Command for JR3304: python janome.py AbsolutePtpMovementControl JANOME_1 40 40 30 10
      CLI Command for JR3403: python janome.py AbsolutePtpMovementControl JANOME_1 40 40 30

      Description for CLI Command:
      • AbsolutePtpMovementControl: API called to the Janome through CLI Command
      • JANOME_1: Aliased name of the Device
      • 40: X co-ordinate for PTP movement, move to 40 mm from origin
      • 40:Y co-ordinate for PTP movement, move to 40 mm from origin
      • 30: Z co-ordinate for PTP movement, move 0 mm for origin
      • 10: R co-ordinate for PTP movement, move 0 mm for origin(Applicable for only JR3403 model)

    9. RelativePtpMovementControl

      Description of the API: API execute Relative PTP movement of the specified co-ordinates, relative to the current position.
      RPC Command: rpc PtpMovementControl(RelativePtpMovementControlRequest) returns (CommandResponse) {}
      Request: message RelativePtpMovementControlRequest {
      int64 x_coordinate = 1;
      int64 y_coordinate = 2;
      int64 z_coordinate = 3;
      int64 r_coordinate = 3;
      CommandRequest cmd_request = 4;
      }
       message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      x_coordinate X co-ordinate for PTP movement, units in mm
      y_coordinate Y co-ordinate for PTP movement, units in mm
      z_coordinate Z co-ordinate for PTP movement, units in mm
      r_coordinate R co-ordinate for PTP movement, units in mm
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code

      CLI Command for JR3304: python janome.py RelativePtpMovementControl JANOME_1 40 40 0 10

      CLI Command for JR3403: python janome.py RelativePtpMovementControl JANOME_1 40 40 5

      Description for CLI Command:
      • PtpMovementControl: API called to the Janome through CLI Command
      • JANOME_1: Aliased name of the Device
      • 40: X co-ordinate for PTP movement, move to 40 mm from origin
      • 40:Y co-ordinate for PTP movement, move to 40 mm from origin
      • 0: Z co-ordinate for PTP movement, move 0 mm for origin
      • 10: R co-ordinate for PTP movement, move 0 mm for origin(Applicable for only JR3403)

    10. SetPtpVelocity

      Description of the API: API to set the velocity parameter for PTP movement
      RPC Command: rpc SetPtpVelocity(SetPtpVelocityRequest) returns (CommandResponse) {}
      Request: message SetPtpVelocityRequest {
      int64 program_number = 1;
      int64 x_velocity = 2;
      int64 y_velocity = 3;
      int64 z_velocity = 4;
      int64 r_velocity = 4;
      CommandRequest cmd_request = 5;
      }
       message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      program_number Program number to which velocity needs to be configured
      x_velocity Velocity to be set for X- axis movement (In %)
      y_velocity Velocity to be set for Y- axis movement (In %)
      z_velocity Velocity to be set for Z- axis movement (In %)
      r_velocity Velocity to be set for R- axis movement (In %)
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code

      CLI Command for JR3304: python janome.py SetPtpVelocity JANOME_1 1 40 40 40 40
      CLI Command for JR3403: python janome.py SetPtpVelocity JANOME_1 1 40 40 40

      Description for CLI Command:
      • SetPtpVelocity:API called to the Janome through CLI Command
      • JANOME_1: Aliased name of the Device
      • 1: Program Number for which velocity needs to be configured
      • 40: Percentage of velocity to be set for X- axis movement
      • 40: Percentage of velocity to be set for Y- axis movement
      • 40: Percentage of velocity to be set for Z- axis movement
      • 40: Percentage of velocity to be set for R- axis movement(Applicable for only JR3304)

    11. SetPtpAcceleration

      Description of the API: API to set the acceleration for PTP movement
      RPC Command: rpc SetPtpAcceleration(SetPtpAccelerationRequest) returns (CommandResponse) {}
      Request: message SetPtpAccelerationRequest {
      int64 program_number = 1;
      int64 x_accel = 2;
      int64 y_accel = 3;
      int64 z_accel = 4;
      int64 r_accel = 4;
      CommandRequest cmd_request = 5;
      }
       message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      program_number Program number to which acceleration needs to be configured
      x_accel Acceleration to be set for X- axis movement (In %)
      y_accel Acceleration to be set for Y- axis movement (In %)
      z_accel Acceleration to be set for Z- axis movement (In %)
      r_accel Acceleration to be set for R- axis movement (In %)
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code

      CLI Command for JR3304: python janome.py SetPtpAcceleration JANOME_1 1 40 40 40 40
      CLI Command for JR3403: python janome.py SetPtpAcceleration JANOME_1 1 40 40 40

      Description for CLI Command:
      • SetPtpAcceleration: API called to the Janome through CLI Command
      • JANOME_1: Aliased name of the Device
      • 40: Percentage of Acceleration to be set for X- axis movement
      • 40: Percentage of Acceleration to be set for Y- axis movement
      • 40: Percentage of Acceleration to be set for Z- axis movement
      • 40: Percentage of Acceleration to be set for R- axis movement(Applicable for only JR3304)

    12. AddPositions

      Description of the API: API to add a position to the specifed program
      RPC Command: rpc AddPositions(AddPositionsRequest) returns (CommandResponse) {}
      Request: message AddPositionsRequest {
      int64 program_number = 1;
      int64 point_number = 2;
      int64 point_type = 3;
      int64 x_coordinate = 4;
      int64 y_coordinate = 5;
      int64 z_coordinate = 6;
      int64 r_coordinate = 7;
      int64 line_speed = 8;
      .generic.CommandRequest cmd_request = 9;
      }
       message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      program_number Number of the program to which point to be added
      point_number Number of the point
      point_type Decimal representation of type of point to be added (PTP, CP etc) check below image for point types and corresponding values
      x_coordinate X-Coordinate of the point to be added
      y_coordinate Y-Coordiante of the point to be added
      z_coordinate Z-Coordiante of the point to be added
      line_speed Line speed for the point
      r_coordinate R-Coordiante of the point to be added
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code

      CLI Command for JR3304: python janome.py AddPositions JANOME_1 1 2 33 10 50 50 30 20
      CLI Command for JR3403: python janome.py AddPositions JANOME_1 1 2 33 10 50 50 30

      Description for CLI Command:
      • AddPositions: API called to the Janome through CLI Command
      • JANOME_1: Aliased name of the Device
      • 1: Number of the program to which point to be added
      • 2: Point
      • 33: Type of point to be added (PTP, CP etc) (33 is decimal representation of 21, which is PTP)
      • 10: Line speed for the point
      • 50: X-Coordiante point to be added
      • 50: Y-Coordiante point to be added
      • 30: Z-Coordiante point to be added
      • 20: R-Coordiante point to be added (Applicable for only JR3304)

    13. SaveData

      Description of the API: API to save C&T data from the host controller to the robot
      RPC Command: rpc SaveData(CommandRequest) returns (CommandResponse) {}
      Request: message CommandRequest {
      int64 device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code

      CLI Command: python janome.py SaveData JANOME_1
      Note:Same CLI Command for both Janome

      Description for CLI Command:
      • SaveData: API called to the Janome through CLI Command
      • JANOME_1: Aliased name of the Device

    14. ReadIO

      Description of the API: API to Read the specified I/O state
      RPC Command: rpc ReadIO(ReadIoRequest) returns (ReadIoResponse) {}
      Request: message ReadIoRequest {
      int64 io_typevalue = 1;
      int64 io_number = 2;
      CommandRequest cmd_request = 3;
      }
       message CommandRequest {
      int64 device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      io_typevalue Type of I/O to be read(Hand Input , Hand Output , System Input and System Output)
      io_number Pin Number of I/O to be read
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message ReadIoResponse {
      string io_type = 1;
      int32 io_number = 2;
      CommandResponse cmd_response = 3;
      }
       message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      io_type type of I/O to be read
      io_number number of I/O to be read
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code

      CLI Command: python janome.py ReadIo JANOME_1 3 4
      Note:Same CLI Command for both Janome

      Description for CLI Command:
      • ReadIo: API called to the Janome through CLI Command
      • JANOME_1: Aliased name of the Device
      • 3: Type of I/O to be read
      • 4: Pin Number of I/O to be read

    15. ReadAllIO

      Description of the API: API to Read status of all I/O of Janome
      RPC Command: rpc ReadIO(ReadAllIoRequest) returns (ReadAllOutputResponse) {}
      Request: message ReadAllIoRequest {
      int64 io_typevalue = 1;
      CommandRequest cmd_request = 3;
      }
       message CommandRequest {
      int64 device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      io_typevalue Type of I/O to be read
      io_number Pin number of I/O to be read
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message ReadAllOutputResponse {
      sint32 num_of_ios = 1;
      repeated Pin pin = 2;
      CommandResponse cmd_response = 3;
      }
       message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      num_of_ios number of states of All IO
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code

      CLI Command: python janome.py ReadAllIo JANOME_1 3
      Note:Same CLI Command for both Janome

      Description for CLI Command:
      • ReadIo: API called to the Janome through CLI Command
      • JANOME_1: Aliased name of the Device
      • 3: Type of I/O to be read

    16. SetIO

      Description of the API: API to Set or Reset the specified I/O pin
      RPC Command: rpc SetIO(SetIoRequest) returns (SetIoResponse) {}
      Request: message SetIoRequest {
      int64 io_typevalue = 1;
      int64 io_number = 2;
      int64 io_value = 3;
      CommandRequest cmd_request = 3;
      }
       message CommandRequest {
      int64 device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      io_typevalue type of I/O
      io_number number of I/O
      io_value value to be set
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message SetIoResponse {
      string io_type = 1;
      int32 io_number = 2;
      CommandResponse cmd_response = 3;
      }
       message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      io_type type of I/O
      io_number number of I/O
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code

      CLI Command: python janome.py SetIo JANOME_1 3 4 1
      Note:bSame CLI Command for both Janome

      Description for CLI Command:
      • SetIo:API called to the Janome through CLI Command
      • JANOME_1: Aliased of the Device
      • 3: Type of I/O
      • 4: Pin number of I/O
      • 1: Value to be set(0 to reset and 1 to Set)

    17. ReturnHome

      Description of the API: API to return janome to its home location
      RPC Command: rpc ReturnHome(CommandRequest) returns (CommandResponse) {}
      Request: message CommandRequest {
      int64 device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code

      CLI Command: : python janome.py ReturnHome JANOME_2
      Note:Same CLI Command for both Janome

      Description for CLI Command:
      • ReturnHome: API called to the Janome through CLI CommandI
      • JANOME_2: Aliased Name for Janome

    18. GetStatus

      Description of the API: API to retrive the current status of Janome.
      RPC Command: rpc GetStatus(CommandRequest) returns (CommandResponse) {}
      Request: message CommandRequest {
      int64 device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code

      CLI Command: : python janome.py GetStatus JANOME_1
      Note:Same CLI Command for both Janome

      Description for CLI Command:
      • GetStatus:API called to the Janome through CLI Command
      • JANOME_1: Aliased name of the device

    19. MechanicalInitialization

      Description of the API: APi for Mechanical Initialization of Janome after reboot
      RPC Command: rpc MechanicalInitialization(CommandRequest) returns (CommandResponse) {}
      Request: message CommandRequest {
      int64 device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code

      CLI Command:python janome.py MechanicalInitialization JANOME_1
      Note:Same CLI Command for both Janome

      Description for CLI Command:
      • MechanicalInitialization:API called to the Janome through CLI Command
      • JANOME_1: Aliased name of Janome

    20. GetPosition

      Description of the API: API to retrive the current co-ordinates of the janome
      RPC Command: rpc GetPosition(CommandRequest) returns (GetPositionResponse) {}
      Request: message CommandRequest {
      int64 device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message GetPositionResponse {
      optional float x_coordinate = 1;
      optional float y_coordinate = 2;
      optional float z_coordinate = 3;
      optional float r_coordinate = 3;
      CommandResponse cmd_response = 4;
      }
       message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      x_coordinate X- co-ordinate
      y_coordinate Y- co-ordinate
      z_coordinate Z- co-ordinate
      r_coordinate R- co-ordinate
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code

      CLI Command: python janome.py GetPosition JANOME_1
      Note:Same CLI Command for both Janome

      Description for CLI Command:
      • GetPosition:API called to the Janome through CLI Command
      • JANOME_1: Aliased name of Janome

    Limitations of the driver

    One limitation of the Janome driver may lie in its compatibility with certain operating systems or hardware configurations. While efforts are made to ensure broad compatibility, there may be instances where the driver does not fully function or is not supported on all platforms.

    Additionally, given the complexity of robotic systems and the variety of tasks they may perform, the Janome driver may not cover every possible use case or scenario. Certain advanced functionalities or specialized operations may not be fully supported by the driver.

    Furthermore, as with any software development project, the Janome driver may encounter bugs, glitches, or compatibility issues with other software components. These issues could potentially impact the reliability or performance of the driver in certain situations.

    Precautions to take before executing the driver

    • Make sure the Janome is in external run mode
    • Make sure right C&T file is uploaded
    • To add a position to a program, the position to be added should be less than/ equal/one greater than the current position

    TESTING AND DEBUGGING

    Response Codes :

    Sr No. API Success Response Code Error Response Code Error Description
    1 getDeviceDetails b0 e1 / e2

    e1: Received Timeout

    e2: Invalid command
    2 listPrograms s7 e1 / e2

    e1: Received Timeout

    e2: Invalid command
    3 selectProgram r1 r65535/e1/e2

    r65535: Program does not exist

    e1: Received Timeout

    e2: Invalid command
    4 runProgram R r65535/e1/e2

    r65535: Program does not exist

    e1: Received Timeout

    e2: Invalid command
    5 ptpMovementControl M m65535/e1/e2

    m65535: Unable to Run PTP due to wrong coordinates range

    e1: Received Timeout

    e2: Invalid command
    6 setPTPVelocity s0 s65535/e1/e2

    s65535: Program does not exist

    e1: Received Timeout

    e2: Invalid command
    7 setPTPAcceleration s0 s65535/e1/e2

    s65535: Program does not exist

    e1: Received Timeout

    e2: Invalid command
    8 saveData t0 t65535/e1/e2

    t65535: Data save error

    e1: Received Timeout

    e2: Invalid command
    9 addPosition s0 s65535/e1/e2

    s65535: Invalid position number

    e1: Received Timeout

    e2: Invalid command
    10 readIo k e1 / e2

    e1: Received Timeout

    e2: Invalid command
    11 setIo k0 k65535/e1/e2

    k65535: unable to set IO

    e1: Received Timeout

    e2: Invalid command

    Error Codes :

    Action Command Error Code Error Type Error Description
    Generic (For any command) e1 Receive Timeout When there is more than a two-second lag between each character after receiving the start transmit code
    Generic (For any command) e2 Command (Subcommand) Code Error When the received command code is one that the robot cannot process (an invalid command is received)
    Run control commands (Select Program, Run Program) -1 Error Missed condition to perform the command
    JOG Robot Start -1 Error When the robot is in a different mode etc., it returns an error code (-1)
    JOG Moving Request m5 Error Without receiving a JOG Start command (M4), when the robot receives Moving Request, it returns an error code (m5)
    JOG End Response -1 Error The robot receives this command without receiving a start command
    Individual Program Settings (Set Velocity / Acceleration) -1 Error The corresponding program does not exist or Data Type Error
    Add Point -1 Error An error is returned if the specified program does not exist or if there is not enough available memory to add a new point data
    Save Data -1 Error No Description available
    Error Information Acquisition 001 to 100 System or Runtime errors Refer to “10. Error Message List” in the operation manual Maintenance for the JR3000 Series [Page No 81]

    We were provided with the set of manuals from the vendor.

    The operation manual CD-ROM included contains the following files :

    Explains the functions and how to use the machine. There are several manuals pertaining to these robots.

    • 170811105_JR3 JC3 JS3 Manual Communication Control.pdf
    • 170812106_JR3 JC3 JS3 Manual Functions I.pdf
    • 170813107_JR3 JC3 JS3 Manual Functions II.pdf
    • 170814108_JR3 JC3 JS3 Manual Functions III.pdf
    • 170815109_JR3 JC3 JS3 Manual Functions IV.pdf

    • 170824101_JR3 JC3 JS3 Manual Auxiliary Axis Functions.pdf

    Each application model is included with the application model operation manuals in addition to the operation manuals listed above.
    PC Software JR C-Points II Limited Edition For details regarding the operating environment and how to install the PC software, refer to the operation manual Setup
    Robot System software Used to return the internal robot system software to its factory settings. Refer to the operation manual Maintenance for details.

    The JR C-Points II CD-ROM as an optional item contains the following files:

    JR C-Points II Installation guide (PDF File) Explains the operating environment and how to install the PC Software JR C-Points II.
    PC Software JR C-Points II Explains the functions and how to use the PC Software. After installing the software, you can also view the operation manual PC Operation by clicking on the Help button on the main screen and selecting "Operation Manual".

    GLOSSARY

    When developing a Janome driver, it's helpful to have a glossary of terms to ensure clarity and consistency in communication. Here's a glossary of terms commonly used in Janome driver development:

    • Janome Driver: Software module or library responsible for interfacing with Janome robotic systems, facilitating communication and control.
    • Robot Controller: Device or software component that manages the operation of a Janome robot, including motion control, program execution, and I/O handling.
    • API (Application Programming Interface): Set of protocols, tools, and definitions that allow software applications to communicate and interact with the Janome driver.
    • Command: Instruction or directive sent to a Janome robot through the driver to perform specific actions such as movement, I/O control, or program execution.
    • Response: Feedback or acknowledgment received from the Janome robot after executing a command, indicating the success or failure of the operation and providing relevant information or data.
    • Motion Control: Functionality within the Janome driver responsible for controlling the movement of the robot, including linear motion, joint motion, and velocity control.
    • I/O (Input/Output): Interface for interacting with external devices or sensors connected to the Janome robot, allowing the driver to read inputs and control outputs.
    • Program Execution: Process of running predefined motion sequences or routines on the Janome robot, typically stored in the robot controller's memory or loaded from external sources.
    • Configuration: Settings and parameters that can be adjusted or customized within the Janome driver to tailor its behavior to specific requirements or environments.
    • Error Handling: Mechanism for detecting, reporting, and managing errors or exceptions that occur during interaction with the Janome robot, ensuring robustness and reliability.
    • Coordinate System: Reference frame used to specify the position and orientation of the Janome robot's end-effector or individual joints, facilitating precise motion control and trajectory planning.
    • Velocity: Speed at which the Janome robot's end-effector or joints move during motion, typically measured in units per second (e.g., millimeters per second or degrees per second).
    • Acceleration: Rate of change of velocity over time, determining how quickly the Janome robot can accelerate or decelerate during motion, influencing performance and efficiency.
    • Positioning: Process of accurately locating and orienting the Janome robot's end-effector or individual joints at specific coordinates within its workspace, essential for precise manipulation tasks.
    • Feedback: Information provided by sensors or encoders on the Janome robot, used to monitor its state, verify motion accuracy, and adjust control parameters in real-time.
    • Interpolation: Algorithm used by the Janome driver to generate smooth and continuous motion trajectories between discrete points, ensuring seamless movement and avoiding jerky motion.

    Opto Camera driver document

    Introduction

    Brief overview of the project

    This project focuses on developing drivers for Opto Camera (coe-050-m-poe-050ir-c) to be utilized in automation applications, with a particular emphasis on integrating them with a user interface (UI) application for future use. The project aims to create software components that enable seamless communication between Opto Camera and the UI application, allowing for the camera settings, capture of images, and streaming of data. Through this integration, the project seeks to enhance the usability and functionality of opto camera within automated processes, contributing to increased efficiency and productivity in various industrial settings.

    Purpose of the document

    The purpose of this document is to provide a detailed guide for developing a driver for the opto Camera (coe-050-m-poe-050ir-c). The driver will enable communication between the Camera and external software application (OECS Camera Suite), allowing to capture an Image, Live Streaming, change camera settings like pixel format, exposure time, gain and many more.

    It covers the software development process, including setting up the development environment, implementing the driver, testing and debugging, and integrating the driver with the opto Camera.

    The primary objective of the document is to provide a comprehensive guide for developed drivers for Opto Camera (coe-050-m-poe-050ir-c) used in automation using a UI application. This includes detailed instructions, software installation guide, a device description with its features, and best practices to ensure the successful development and integration of drivers with the devices.

    Scope and objectives

    1. Driver Development: The document focuses on the development of a driver for Opto Camera using industry-standard protocols
    2. Technical Information: It includes technical specifications of the device, hardware and software requirements, and information about the Software Development Kit (SDK) provided for the device.
    3. SDK Overview: Introduction to OECS Software Suite and its Installation.
    4. Implementation: It covers the development process, including the choice of programming language, information on APIs, how to use APIs, limitations of the driver, precautions to take before execution, and the actual implementation of the driver.
    5. Testing and Debugging: Scope extends to testing and debugging procedures to ensure the reliability and functionality of the driver for real-time application.
    6. Documentation and Support: Lastly, the document includes information on documentation standards and support resources available for developers.
      7. Overall, the aim is to facilitate the successful development and implementation of the opto Camera, ensuring it meets the required standards and serves its intended purpose effectively.

    Device Overview

    The COE-G series includes Gigabit Ethernet cameras equipped with the latest sensors, ranging from high speed VGA to the latest 12MP SONY Pregius sensor, which deliver GigE connectivity with high frame rate.

    Key Advantages of Opto Camera

    1. High quality sensors: New SONY Pregius CMOS Global shutter sensors provide high quality images.
    2. GigEVision® protocol & GenICam® standard : Standard vision SDK platform for easy integration in existing software.
    3. Full GenICam® compliant: easy to integrate GenICam® compliant SDK package provides more flexibility to Vision Systems
    4. GigE PoE compliance: With the COE-G cameras, you do not need separate cables to transfer the information to the computer and provide power to the camera.
    5. 120 MB RAM and Frame Rate up to 300fps High frame rate ideal for high speed applications. The internal memory up to 120MB guarantees no image loss and enables useful features like Record / Playback and sequence recordings.

    Description of the device for which the driver is being developed

    The Opto Engineering COE-050-M-POE-050IR-C is a compact, high-performance camera designed for industrial applications. It features a 5 MP sensor with Power over Ethernet (PoE) support, ensuring efficient power and data transmission through a single cable. The camera is equipped with an IR filter, making it suitable for precise imaging in environments with controlled lighting or infrared requirements. Its robust design ensures reliability in demanding conditions, making it ideal for machine vision, automation, and inspection tasks.

    Technical Specifications of opto Camera

    Type Area Scan Camera
    Model Opto coe-050-m-poe-050ir-c
    Resolution 5 MP
    Sensor Type

    CMOS

    Global shutter
    Sensor Format 2.3"
    Effective Sensor Diagonal 7.9 mm
    Sensor model IMX264
    Frame Rate (at Default Settings) 23.5 fps
    Serial interface No
    Power supply (V) 12V, PoE
    Image Data Interface Fast Ethernet (100 Mbit/s)
    Gigabit Ethernet (1000 Mbit/s)
    Pixel Formats

    Mono 8/10/12, RGB8, Bayer GR 8/10/10Packed/12/12Packed, YUV

    422Packed, YUV422_YUYVPacked
    Gain

    0-20.0322 db

    Synchronization

    Via hardware trigger

    Via software trigger

    Via free run
    Exposure Time Control

    Via hardware trigger

    Programmable via the camera API

    34 µs - 9999500 µs
    Operating System 32/64-bit Windows XP/7/10
    SNR (dB) 40
    Image buffer (MB) 128MB
    Chunk data Yes
    Timers/Counters 0/1
    Weight 68g
    Software OECS

    Software Overview and Requirements - OECS

    The OECS Camera Software Suite is a collection of drivers and tools for operating any OECS camera with Windows. OECS is a graphical environment which is powerful, flexible, easy to use, and are designed to quickly develop and run new vision applications without the need to write program code. Whether you are looking for a development environment suitable for integrators/automation engineers familiar with data-flow programming or software applications designed for users with no machine vision experience or any programming knowledge. Making changes to an existing camera device in your application essentially becomes a plug and play process.

    Features Of OECS

    • OECS is compatible with standard protocols such as GigEVision and USB3Vision (currently, GigEVision, USB3Vision, and CameraLink protocols are supported), which contains drive program and API functions. This SDK is used to connect and control machine vision cameras to realize the functions of image acquisition, parameter configuration, and image post-process.
    • The USB 3.0 interface provides the 3 Gbps bandwidth
    • Supports AEC (automatic exposure control), LUT, Gamma Correction, etc..
    • The color camera adopts the color interpolation algorithm to reproduce colors faithfully. It also supports automatic white balance (AWB).
    • Compatible with USB3.0 Vision Protocol, and third-party software.

    Hardware and software requirements

    Hardware / System Requirements:

    • Windows 10 (64 bit) or Windows 11 (64 bit)
    • PC with interface GigE
    • Intel Core i5 or higher processor
    • 8 GB RAM
    • Power supply for the camera- Power Over Ethernet
    • 5 GB of available hard disk space
    • 5400 RPM hard drive
    • DirectX 9-capable video card running at 1024 x 768 or higher display resolution

    Software Requirements:

    • OECS Software Suite
    • Microsoft Visual Studio for C++ and python IDE for development
    • Additional software or libraries required by the SDK or application

    Additional Requirements

      This version of Microsoft Visual Studio works best with Internet Explorer 10 or higher. If Internet Explorer 10 is not installed on your computer, some features might not work as expected

    Driver Development

    To Install the OECS Camera Software Suite for Windows:

    • Download the OECS Software Suite installer here
    • Launch the downloaded installer
    • Follow the instructions in the setup wizard. The wizard will guide you through the installation process. During installation, you can choose the interfaces of your cameras (e.g., USB or GigE) so that only the software you need is installed.

    Driver Implementation

    1. Get Device Details
    2. Open Device
    3. Close Device
    4. Change Alias
    5. Set Exposure Time- (Max: 9999500 micro seconds. Min: 34 micro seconds)
    6. Set Pixel Format-(Mono 8, Mono 10, Mono 12)
    7. Set Gain - (0 to 20.0322 db)
    8. Save Current Configuration Parameters
    9. Load Current Configuration Parameters
    10. Get Image File - (.jpeg, .png, .bmp, .tiff, .bmp)

    gRPC API’s Description for opto Camera

    1. GetDeviceDetails

      Description for GetDeviceDetails API: Retrieves detailed information about the connected Opto Camera, including its configuration and status.

      RPC Command : rpc GetDeviceDetails(.generic. CommandRequest) returns (.generic.GenericDeviceModel) {}

      Request:
      message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias Unique alias of the device
      Request:
      message GenericDeviceModel{
      string instance_id = 1;
      string device_alias = 2;
      DeviceType device_type = 3;
      DeviceModel device_model_name = 4;
      optional DeviceStatus device_status = 5;
      string ipaddr = 6;
      string mac_addr = 7;
      google.protobuf.Value conn_handle=8;
      string port_name = 9;
      int64 port_address = 10;
      CommandResponse cmd_response = 11;
      }
      Parameter Description
      instance_id New instance for the device in the enumeration
      device_alias Unique identifier (alphanumeric) for every device in the enumeration
      device_type Indicates the type of device like Motion stage, Safety Controller etc (defined below in the DeviceType enum)
      device_model_name Indicate the model name for each device (define below in the DeviceModel enum)
      device_status indicate whether the device is online , offline or not reachable (define below in the device status enum)
      ipaddr indicate the ipaddress of the device
      mac_addr indicate the mac address of the device
      Conn_handle Handle object to keep the device open
      port_name Port name of the device
      port_address Port address of the device
      cmd_response Indicates command response that describes API response code and its description (Defined below in CommandResponse)
      enum DeviceType{
      NONE = 0;
      SENSOR_3D = 1;
      MOTION_STAGE = 2;
      CAMERA = 3;
      IO_MODULE = 4;
      SAFETY_CONTROLLER = 5;
      ANIMATIC_MOTOR=6;
      }
      enum DeviceModel{
      DUMMY_MODEL = 0;
      ED527 = 1;
      ED588 = 2 ;
      JR3000 = 3;
      OPTOE = 4;
      BASLER = 5;
      SPiiPlusEC=6;
      GT6600 = 7;
      MOTOR = 8;
      }
      enum DeviceStatus{
      OFFLINE = 0;
      ONLINE = 1;
      NOT_REACHABLE =2;
      }
      message CommandResponse{
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_message = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Unique alias of the device
      resp_message Description of the response code

      CLI Command: python optocamera.py GetDeviceDetails OptoCamera1

      Description for CLI Command:
      • GetDeviceDetails: GetDeviceDetails is the API called to the Opto Camera through CLI Command
      • OptoCamera1: Aliased Name for Opto Camera

    2. OpenDevice

      Description for OpenDevice API: Establishes a connection to the Opto Camera, initializing communication for further operations.

      RPC Command :rpc OpenDevice(.generic.CommandIPRequest) returns(.generic.GenericDeviceModel) {}

      Request:
      message CommandIPRequest {
      string ip_address = 1;
      string com = 2;
      int64 port_address = 3;
      int32 device_id = 4;
      string file_path = 5;
      int64 device_model =6;
      optional string device_alias=7;
      int32 axis =8;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      ip_address Specifies the IP address of the device.
      com Indicates the communication protocol or interface to be used
      port_address Denotes the specific port address for the device on the communication interface.
      device_id Unique identifier for the device, used to distinguish it from other devices in the system.
      file_path The path to the file, which may include configuration, program, or data files for the device.
      device_model Represents the model number or type of the device being communicated with.
      device_alias A user-defined alias for the device, providing a more descriptive or convenient reference.
      axis Specifies the axis number (e.g., X, Y, Z) on which the command or operation will be performed.
      Response
      message GenericDeviceModel{
      string instance_id = 1;
      string device_alias = 2;
      DeviceType device_type = 3;
      DeviceModel device_model_name = 4;
      optional DeviceStatus device_status = 5;
      string ipaddr = 6;
      string mac_addr = 7;
      google.protobuf.Value conn_handle=8;
      string port_name = 9;
      int64 port_address = 10;
      CommandResponse cmd_response = 11;
      }
      Parameter Description
      instance_id New instance for the device in the enumeration
      device_alias Unique identifier (alphanumeric) for every device in the enumeration
      device_type Indicates the type of device like Motion stage, Safety Controller etc (defined below in the DeviceType enum)
      device_model_name Indicate the model name for each device (define below in the DeviceModel enum)
      device_status indicate whether the device is online , offline or not reachable (define below in the device status enum)
      ipaddr indicate the ipaddress of the device
      mac_addr Indicate the mac address of the device
      Conn_handle Handle object to keep the device open
      port_name Port name of the device
      port_address Port address of the device
      cmd_response Indicates command response that describes API response code and its description (Defined below in CommandResponse)

      enum DeviceType{
      NONE = 0;
      SENSOR_3D = 1;
      MOTION_STAGE = 2;
      CAMERA = 3;
      IO_MODULE = 4;
      SAFETY_CONTROLLER = 5;
      ANIMATIC_MOTOR=6;
      }
      enum DeviceModel{
      DUMMY_MODEL = 0;
      ED527 = 1;
      ED588 = 2 ;
      JR3000 = 3;
      OPTOE = 4;
      BASLER = 5;
      SPiiPlusEC=6;
      GT6600 = 7;
      MOTOR = 8;
      }
      enum DeviceStatus{
      OFFLINE = 0;
      ONLINE = 1;
      NOT_REACHABLE =2;
      }
      message CommandResponse{
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_message = 2;
      }
      ParameterParameter
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_message Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python optocamera.py OpenDevice 192.168.88.12 OptoCamera1
      Description for CLI Command
      • OpenDevice: API called to the Opto Camera through CLI Command to Connect and Initialize all Resources
      • 192.168.88.12: Ip Address of the device
      • OptoCamera1 Aliased Name for Opto Camera

    3. CloseDevice

      Description for CloseDevice API: Disconnects from the Opto Camera, releasing all resources and deleting associated handlers to ensure a clean shutdown.

      RPC Command: rpc CloseDevice(.generic.CommandRequest) returns(.generic.CommandResponse) {}

      Request: message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias Unique alias of the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python optocamera.py CloseDevice OptoCamera1
      Description for CLI Command:
      • CloseDevice: API called to the Opto Camera through CLI Command to Close Connection
      • OptoCamera1: Aliased Name for Opto Camera

    4. ChangeAlias

      Description for ChangeAlias API: Updates the alias of the device, allowing it to be referenced by a new identifier.

      RPC Command: rpc changeAlias(ChangeAliasRequest) returns (CommandResponse) {}

      Request: message ChangeAliasRequest{
      string current_alias=1;
      string new_alias=2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      current_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      new_alias The device_alias to change to
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python optocamera.py changeAlias current_alias new_alias
        Description for CLI Command:
      • ChangeAlias: API called to the Opto Camera through CLI Command to get new alias name
      • current_alias: The current device_alias used to refer to the device
      • new_alias: The device_alias to change to

    5. SetExposureTime

      Description for ReturnHome API: Sets the Exposure time for the Opto Camera to control the amount of light captured during image acquisition.

      RPC Command: rpc SetExposureTime(SetExposureTimeOptoCameraRequest) returns(.generic.CommandResponse) {}

      Request: message SetExposureTimeOptoCameraRequest{
      float time_value = 1;
      .generic.CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
      }
      message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      time_value Time to be set in float. Min : 34 micro seconds. Max: 9999500 micro seconds
      device_alias Unique alias of the device obtained from enumeration API
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command:python optocamera.py SetExposureTime OptoCamera1 5000

      Description for CLI Command:

      • SetExposureTime: SetExposureTime is the API called to the Opto Camera through CLI Command
      • OptoCamera1: Aliased Name for Opto Camera
      • 5000: Sample Exposure Time value Configured in millisecond

    6. SetPixelFormat

      Description for SetPixelFormat API: Configures the Pixel Format of the Opto Camera for image capture.

      RPC Command : SetPixelFormat(SetPixelOptoCameraRequest) returns(.generic.CommandResponse) {}

      Request: message SetPixelOptoCameraRequest {
      string pixel_format = 1;
      .generic.CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
      }
      message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Parameter Description
      Pixel_format Pixel Format to be configured. "Mono8", "Mono12" or "Mono10" are supported
      device_alias Unique alias of the device obtained from enumeration API
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command:python optocamera.py SetPixelFormat OptoCamera1 Mono12
      Description for CLI Command:
      • SetPixelFormat:SetPixelFormat is the API called to the Opto Camera through CLI Command
      • OptoCamera1: Aliased Name for Opto Camera
      • Mono12: Setting Pixel Format as Mono12

    7. SetGain

      Description for SetGain API: Configures the gain setting for the Opto Camera.

      RPC Command: SetGain(SetGainOptoCameraRequest) returns(.generic.CommandResponse) {}

      Request: message SetGainOptoCameraRequest
      {
      float gain_value = 1;
      .generic.CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
      }
      message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      gain_value Gain value to be Set in decibles. 0-20.0322 decibles will be the range
      device_alias Unique alias of the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python optocamera.py SetGain OptoCamera1 18
      Description for CLI Command:
      • SetGain: SetGain is the API called to the Opto Camera through CLI Command
      • OptoCamera1: Aliased Name for opto camera
      • 18:Gain value configured

    8. SaveCameraConfig

      Description for SaveCameraConfig API: Saves Camera's Configuration in .ini file

      RPC Command: rpc SaveCameraConfig(SaveConfigOptoCameraRequest) returns(stream SaveConfigOptoCameraResponse) {}

      Request: message SaveConfigOptoCameraRequest {
      string file_name = 1;
      .generic.CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
      }
      message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      file_name User defined .ini file name to be provided to save camera’s features.
      device_alias Unique alias of the device
      Response: message SaveConfigOptoCameraResponse {
      optional bytes config_data = 1;
      optional string file_name = 2;
      optional int64 file_size = 3;
      .generic.CommandResponse cmd_response = 4;
      }
      message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      config_data Camera’s Features like fps, gain, time , height , etc
      file name Name of File under which camera’s Configurations are saved
      file_size Size of Configuration File
      CLI Command:python optocamera.py SaveCameraConfig OptoCamera1 OptoCameraConfig.ini
        Description of the response code
      • SaveCameraConfig: API called to the Opto Camera through CLI Command to Save Camera Features.
      • OptoCamera1: Aliased Name for Opto Camera
      • OptoCameraConfig.ini: User Defined file name in .ini format

    9. LoadCameraConfig

      Description for LoadCameraConfig API: Loads the camera's configuration from an .ini feature file into the camera.

      RPC Command: rpc LoadCameraConfig(stream LoadConfigOptoCameraRequest) returns(.generic.CommandResponse) {}

      Request: message LoadConfigOptoCameraRequest {
      string file_name = 1;
      bytes config_data = 2;
      .generic.CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
      }
      message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      file_name indicates pre-existing configuration file (.ini format) to be loaded to the camera
      config_data Represents camera features data like Gain, Time, Resolution, fps etc.
      device_alias Unique alias of the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python optocamera.py LoadCameraConfig OptoCamera1 OptoCameraConfig.ini
      Description for CLI Command:
      • LoadCameraConfig: : API called to the Opto Camera through CLI Command to load camera features
      • OptoCamera1: Aliased Name for Opto Camera.
      • OptoCameraConfig.ini: File to be Loaded to Camera.

    10. GetImage

      Description for GetImage API: To Capture Single Image with user defined name and Format

      RPC Command: rpc GetImage(GetImageFileOptoCameraRequest) returns(stream GetImageFileOptoCameraResponse) {}

      Request: message GetImageFileOptoCameraRequest {
      string file_name = 1;
      .generic.CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
      }
      message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      file_name Name of the image file with format. Supported file format are .jpeg , .png , .tif and .bmp
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message GetImageFileOptoCameraResponse {
      optional bytes image_data = 1;
      optional string file_name = 2;
      optional int64 file_size = 3;
      .generic.CommandResponse cmd_response = 4;
      }
      message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      image_data Image data
      file_name Name of the image file with format. Supported file format are .jpeg , .png , .tif and .bmp
      file_size Size of the captured image file
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python optocamera.py GetImageFile OptoCamera1 image.jpeg
      Description for CLI Command:
      • GetImageFile: API called to the opto Camera through CLI Command capture image
      • OptoCamera1: Aliased Name for opto Camera
      • image.jpeg: Name of the Image File with Format

    Limitations of the driver

    • Compatibility: The driver may only be compatible with Opto-e coe-050-m-poe-050ir-c versions of Opto Camera, limiting its use with other devices.
    • Integration:Integrating the driver with other systems or software may pose challenges, especially if there are compatibility issues or dependencies.

    Precautions to take before executing the driver

    • Ensure to load good configuration file through LoadConfig API to overcome any issues with driver.

    Testing and Debugging

    Error Type Error Code Description
    MV_OK 0 Succeed, no error.
    MV_E_HANDLE 0x80000000 Error or invalid handle.
    MV_E_SUPPORT 0x80000001 Not supported function.
    MV_E_BUFOVER 0x80000002 Cache is full.
    MV_E_CALLORDER 0x80000003 Function calling order error.
    MV_E_PARAMETER 0x80000004 Incorrect parameter.
    MV_E_RESOURCE 0x80000006 Applying resource failed.
    MV_E_NODATA 0x80000007 No data.
    MV_E_PRECONDITION 0x80000008 Precondition error, or running environment changed.
    MV_E_VERSION 0x80000009 Version mismatches.
    MV_E_NOENOUGH_BUF 0x8000000A Insufficient memory.
    MV_E_ABNORMAL_IMAGE 0x8000000B Abnormal image. Incomplete image caused by packet loss.
    MV_E_LOAD_LIBRARY 0x8000000C Importing dll failed
    MV_E_NOOUTBUF 0x8000000D No buffer node can be outputted
    MV_E_UNKNOW 0x800000FF Unknown error.
    MV_E_GC_GENERIC 0x80000100 General error.
    MV_E_GC_ARGUMENT 0x80000101 Illegal parameters.
    MV_E_GC_RANGE 0x80000102 The value is out of range
    MV_E_GC_PROPERTY 0x80000103 Property
    MV_E_GC_RUNTIME 0x80000104 Running environment error.
    MV_E_GC_LOGICAL 0x80000105 Logical error
    MV_E_GC_ACCESS 0x80000106 Node accessing condition error.
    MV_E_GC_TIMEOUT 0x80000107 Timeout.
    MV_E_GC_DYNAMICCAST 0x80000108 Transformation exception.
    MV_E_NOT_IMPLEMENTED 0x80000200 The command is not supported by device.
    MV_E_INVALID_ADDRESS 0x80000201 The target address being accessed does not exist.
    MV_E_WRITE_PROTECT 0x80000202 The target address is not writable.
    MV_E_ACCESS_DENIED 0x80000203 No permission.
    MV_E_BUSY 0x80000204 Device is busy, or network disconnected.
    MV_E_PACKET 0x80000205 Network data packet error.
    MV_E_NETER 0x80000206 Network error.
    MV_E_IP_CONFLICT 0x80000221 Device IP address conflicted.
    MV_E_UPG_FILE_MISMATCH 0x80000400 Firmware mismatches.
    MV_E_UPG_LANGUSGE_MISMATCH 0x80000401 Firmware language mismatches.
    MV_E_UPG_CONFLICT 0x80000402 Upgrading conflicted (repeated upgrading requests during device upgrade).
    MV_E_UPG_INNER_ERR MV_E_UPG_INNER_ERR Camera internal error during upgrade.
    MV_E_UPG_UNKNOW 0x800004FF Unknown error during upgrade.
    MV_E_NODEV 0x8000000F No Device Found
    CUSTOM ERROR CODES 0 Operation Success
    CUSTOM ERROR CODES 1 Failure
    CUSTOM ERROR CODES 5 Invalid Handler
    CUSTOM ERROR CODES 6 Pixel Format Not Supported

    RESOURCES AND LINKS

    • OEC Firmware and Installation file: click here
    • OECS User Manual:click here

    GLOSSARY

    • Driver:A software component that enables communication between the operating system and a hardware device, in this case, a camera.
    • SDK (Software Development Kit): A set of tools, libraries, and documentation that developers use to create software applications for a specific platform or framework.
    • API (Application Programming Interface):A set of rules and protocols that allow different software applications to communicate with each other.
    • Firmware:: Software that is embedded into a hardware device, such as a camera, to control its operation.
    • Resolution: The number of pixels in an image, typically measured in megapixels (MP), that determines the level of detail and clarity in the image.
    • Frame Rate: The number of frames or images displayed or processed per second, often measured in frames per second (fps).
    • Gain: Gain in the context of a camera refers to the amplification of the signal from the camera sensor. However, increasing the gain too much can introduce noise into the image, reducing its quality. Gain is usually measured in decibels (dB).
    • Exposure Time: The amount of light that reaches the camera sensor, controlled by settings such as shutter speed, and aperture.
    • Pixel: The smallest unit of a digital image, representing a single point of color.
    • Buffer: A temporary storage area in memory used to hold data, such as images, before it is processed or transferred.
    • Streaming: The process of continuously transmitting data, such as video, over a network in real-time.

    LMI Gocator driver document

    Introduction

    Brief overview of the project

    This project aims to develop drivers for the Gocator 2530 and 3506 high-performance 3D smart sensor, integrating it with a user interface (UI) application for use in automation. The goal is to enable seamless communication between the sensor and the UI application for inline inspection tasks. This integration will allow for capturing high-resolution 3D point cloud data of the target object, facilitating detailed surface analysis and measurement. Ultimately, the project seeks to enhance the usability and functionality of the Gocator 2530 and 3506 in automated processes, leading to increased efficiency and productivity in various industrial settings.

    Purpose of the document

    The purpose of this document is to provide a detailed guide for developing a driver for the Gocator 2530 and 3506 device . The driver will enable communication between the 3d Smart Laser Line Profile Sensor and external software applications, allowing to get raw 3D data points, Load and Save programs and many more. It covers the software development process, including setting up the development environment, implementing the driver, testing and debugging, and integrating the driver with the Gocator 2530 and and 3506.

    The primary objective of the document is to provide a comprehensive guide for developed drivers Gocator 2530 and and 3506 used in automation using a UI application. This includes detailed instructions, software installation guide, a device description with its features, and best practices to ensure the successful development and integration of drivers with the devices.

    Scope and objectives

    1. Driver Development: The document focuses on the development of a driver for Gocator 2530 and and 3506 using industry-standard protocols.
    2. Technical Information: It includes technical specifications of the device, hardware and software requirements, and information about the Software Development Kit (SDK) provided for the device.
    3. SDK Overview: Introduction to GoSDK and its Installation.
    4. Driver Implementation: It covers the development process, including the choice of programming language, information on APIs, how to use APIs, limitations of the driver, precautions to take before execution, and the actual implementation of the driver.
    5. Testing and Debugging: The scope extends to testing and debugging procedures to ensure the reliability and functionality of the driver for real-time application
    6. Documentation and Support: Lastly, the document includes information on documentation standards and support resources available for developers.

    Overall, the aim is to facilitate the successful development and implementation of the Gocator 2530 and 3506, ensuring it meets the required standards and serves its intended purpose effectively.

    Device Overview

    Description of the device for which the driver is being developed
