      • DisableMotor: API called to the Alio through CLI Command to Disable the Motor of specific Axis
      • ALIO_ACS_1: Alias of the Device
      • 0: The axis for which the acceleration has to be fetched(Permitted values: x-axis - 0, y-axis - 1, rotary axis - 2) for 3 Axis Alio and (Permitted values: rotary axis -0) for Single Axis Alio.

    14. Get Current Status of the Motor

      Description of the API: Retrieve the current operational status of the motor for the specified axis

      RPC Command: rpc GetMotorStatus(AxisCommandRequest) returns (GetMotorStatusResponse) {}

      Request: message AxisCommandRequest {
      int32 axis = 1;
      CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      axis Axis for which the operation is requested
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message GetMotorStatusResponse{
      optional int32 status = 1;
      .generic.CommandResponse cmd_response = 2;
      }
       message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_message = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      status Current operational status of the motor
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_message Message response code
      CLI Command: python alioacs.py MotorState ALIO_ACS_1 0

      Description for CLI Command:

      • MotorState: API called to Alio through CLI Command to Retrive the Current Operational State of the Specified Motor
      • ALIO_ACS_1: Alias of the Device
      • 0: the axis for which the acceleration has to be fetched(Permitted values: x-axis - 0, y-axis - 1, rotary axis - 2) for 3 Axis Alio and (Permitted values: rotary axis -0) for Single Axis Alio.

    15. Commute Motor

      Description of the API: Commute the Specified Motor

      RPC Command: rpc CommuteMotor(AxisCommandRequest) returns (.generic.CommandResponse) {}

      Request: message AxisCommandRequest {
      int32 axis = 1;
      CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      axis Axis for which the operation is requested
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message GetMotorStatusResponse{
      optional int32 status = 1;
      .generic.CommandResponse cmd_response = 2;
      }
       message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_message = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      status Current operational status of the motor
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_message Message response code
      CLI Command: python alioacs.py CommuteMotor ALIO_ACS_1 0

      Description for CLI Command:

      • MotorState: API called to Alio through CLI Command to Retrive the Current Operational State of the Specified Motor
      • ALIO_ACS_1: Alias of the Device
      • 0: the axis for which the acceleration has to be fetched(Permitted values: x-axis - 0, y-axis - 1, rotary axis - 2) for 3 Axis Alio and (Permitted values: rotary axis -0) for Single Axis Alio.

    16. ACSClose

      Description of the API: Disconnects from the Alio ACS Motion Controller, releasing all resources and deleting associated handlers to ensure a clean shutdown.

      RPC Command: rpc ACSClose(.generic.CommandIPRequest) returns (.generic.CommandResponse) {}

      Request: message CommandIPRequest {
      string ip_address = 1;
      string com = 2;
      int64 port_address = 3;
      int32 device_id = 4;
      string file_path = 5;
      int64 device_model =6;
      optional string device_alias=7;
      int32 axis =8;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      ip_address Specifies the IP address of the device.
      com Indicates the communication protocol or interface to be used
      port_address Denotes the specific port address for the device on the communication interface.
      device_id Unique identifier for the device, used to distinguish it from other devices in the system.
      file_path The path to the file, which may include configuration, program, or data files for the device.
      device_model Represents the model number or type of the device being communicated with.
      device_alias A user-defined alias for the device, providing a more descriptive or convenient reference.
      axis Specifies the axis number (e.g., X, Y, Z) on which the command or operation will be performed.
      enum DeviceType{
      NONE = 0;
      SENSOR_3D = 1;
      MOTION_STAGE = 2;
      CAMERA = 3;
      IO_MODULE = 4;
      SAFETY_CONTROLLER = 5;
      ANIMATIC_MOTOR=6;
      }
      enum DeviceModel{
      DUMMY_MODEL = 0;
      ED527 = 1;
      ED588 = 2 ;
      JR3000 = 3;
      OPTOE = 4;
      BASLER = 5;
      SPiiPlusEC=6;
      GT6600 = 7;
      MOTOR = 8;
      }
      enum DeviceStatus{
      OFFLINE = 0;
      ONLINE = 1;
      NOT_REACHABLE =2;
      }
      message CommandResponse{
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_message = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_message Response message code
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_message = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_message Message response code
      CLI Command: python alioacs.py ACSClose ALIO_ACS_1 18

      Description for CLI Command:

      • ACS:API called to the Alio through CLI Command to Close Device Connection
      • ALIO_ACS_1:Alias of the Device
      • 18: enum for the device(18 for 3 Axis Alio and 6 for Single Axis)

    Limitations of the driver

    Integration: Integrating the driver with other systems or software may pose challenges, especially if there are compatibility issues or dependencies.

    TESTING AND DEBUGGING

    Following are the Error Codes with Description for Alio ACS

    Error Code Error Description
    0 General error
    1 Operation successful
    65 Asynchronous call is not supported.
    66 No such file or directory.
    67 The FW version does not support the current C Library version.
    68 Controllers reply is too long.
    6D Internal library error: Invalid file handle.
    7A Internal library error: Cannot open Log file.
    7C Too many open files.
    80 No space left on device.
    82 The controller stopped responding.
    84 Communication initialization failure.
    85 Internal library error: Creating communication object failure.
    86 Invalid communication handle.
    87 All channels are busy. The maximum number of the concurrently opened communication channels is 10.
    88 Invalid name of Log file.
    89 Received message is too long (more than size of user buffer).
    8A The program string is long.
    8B Function parameters are invalid.
    8C History buffer is closed.
    8D Name of variable must be specified.
    8E Error in index specification.
    8F Controller reply contains less values than expected.
    91 Function is not supported in current version.
    93 Internal error: Error of the history buffer initialization.
    96 Unsolicited messages buffer is closed.
    97 Callback registration error.
    98 Callback function has been already installed.
    99 Checksum of the controller response is incorrect.
    9A Internal library error: The controller replies sequence is invalid.
    9B Internal library error: WaitForSingleObject function returns error.
    9D Internal library error: Error of the unsolicited messages buffer initialization.
    9E Non-waiting call has been aborted.
    9F Error of the non-waiting call cancellation.
    A0 Queue of transmitted commands is full.
    A2 The library cannot send to the specified communication channel.
    A3 The library cannot receive from the specified communication channel
    A4 Internal library error: Sending of the chain is failed.
    A5 Specified IP address is duplicated.
    A6 There is no Application with such Handle.
    A7 Array name was expected.
    A8 The file is not a valid ANSI data file.
    AB Application Saver Loader CRC error.
    AC Application Saver Loader Header CRC error.
    AD Application Saver Loader File Size error.
    AE Application Saver Loader File Open error.
    AF Application Saver Loader Unknown File error.
    B0 Application Saver Loader Format Version error.
    B1 Application Saver Loader Section Size is Zero.
    B3 Internal library error: Thread local storage error.
    B4 Error of the PCI driver initialization.
    B9 Pointer to the buffer is invalid.
    BD Specified priority for the callback thread cannot be set.
    BE Cannot access DPRAM directly through any channel but PCI and Direct.
    C0 Invalid DPRAM address was specified.
    C1 This version of simulator does not support work with DPRAM.
    C3 Returned by functions that work with host file system when a specified filename is not found. Check the path and filename.
    C5 The application cannot establish communication with the SPiiPlus UMD.
    C6 The controller does not reply for more than 20 seconds.Check the following: Controller is powered on (MPU LED is green)or Controller connected properly to host or Controller executes a time consuming command like compilation of a large program save to flash load to flash etc.
    C7 The DLL and the UMD versions are not compatible.
    AF Application Saver Loader Unknown File error.
    B0 Application Saver Loader Format Version error.
    3 Axis is Out of Range.

    RESOURCES AND LINKS

    All SDKs, libraries, software setup files, manuals, and datasheets are provided by the client.

    GLOSSARY

    • Controller: The electronic component that manages and controls the operation of the servo motor.
    • Encoder: A device used to measure the position or speed of a motor shaft and provide feedback to the controller.
    • Axis: In the context of motors and motion control, an axis refers to a direction or degree of freedom along which a motor or a mechanism can move.
    • Driver: A component that amplifies the control signals from the controller to the motor.
    • Motion Profile/PTP Movement: A predefined pattern of motion used to control the movement of the motor.
    • Acceleration: The rate of change of velocity of the motor.
    • Deceleration: The rate at which the motor slows down.
    • Torque: The rotational force produced by the motor.
    • Feedback: Information about the motor's performance that is fed back to the controller for adjustment.
    • Position Control: The ability to control the motor's position accurately.
    • Speed Control: The ability to control the motor's speed accurately.
    • Motion Control: The ability to control the motor's motion, including speed, position, and acceleration.
    • Integration: The process of incorporating the motor into a larger system or machine.
    • Communication Protocol: The rules and conventions for communication between the motor and other devices systems.
    • EtherCAT: A real-time Ethernet fieldbus system used for communication in industrial automation.
    • CANopen: A communication protocol based on the Controller Area Network (CAN) bus standard.
    • Modbus: A communication protocol commonly used in industrial automation systems.
    • PLC (Programmable Logic Controller): A digital computer used for automation of electromechanical processes.
    • HMI (Human Machine Interface): A device or software that allows users to interact with the motor or control system.

    Prosilica GT6600 driver document

    Introduction

    Brief overview of the

    The Prosilica GT6600 is a high-sensitivity 29-megapixel camera designed primarily for outdoor imaging applications. Equipped with a Gigabit Ethernet interface (GigEVision®), this camera offers robust performance in extreme environments, making it suitable for a variety of industrial, security, and surveillance applications.

    Purpose of the document

    The purpose of this document is to provide a detailed guide for developing a driver for the Allied Vision Camera – Prosilica GT6600 device. The driver will enable communication between the device and external software applications. It covers the software development process, including setting up the development environment, implementing the driver, testing and debugging, and integrating the driver with the Prosilica device.

    The primary objective of the document is to provide a comprehensive guide for developed drivers for Prosilica.

    Scope and objectives

    1. Technical Information and SDK Overview: To provide comprehensive technical details about the Prosilica GT6600 camera, including its specifications, features, and operational principles, while also offering an overview of the software development kit (SDK) associated with the camera. This aims to ensure users have a thorough understanding of the camera's capabilities and functionalities for informed decision-making, as well as to provide developers with insights into integrating the camera into their applications effectively, leveraging its capabilities and features through the SDK.
    2. Driver Development and Implementation: To outline the development process for the Prosilica GT6600 camera driver, facilitating communication between the camera hardware and the operating system, while also providing guidelines and best practices for implementing the driver. This aims to guide developers through the creation of software that enables seamless interaction with the GT6600 camera, ensuring compatibility with various operating systems and hardware configurations, and ensuring successful integration of the driver into users' systems.
    3. Testing and Debugging: To outline strategies and methodologies for testing and debugging the Prosilica GT6600 camera driver, verifying the reliability, stability, and performance of the driver under different conditions, as well as to troubleshoot and resolve any issues that may arise during development or deployment.
    4. Documentation and Support: To provide comprehensive documentation and support resources for the Prosilica GT6600 camera. This ensures a smooth and successful experience with the camera, facilitating its integration into various applications and systems.

    Device Overview

    Description of the device for which the driver is being developed

    The Prosilica GT6600 stands out as a reliable and rugged camera solution, offering high-performance imaging capabilities for demanding outdoor applications. Its advanced features, robust construction, and wide range of applications make it a valuable tool in various industries requiring high-quality imaging in challenging environments. Key features and characteristics of the Prosilica device include:

    • Sensor: The camera features a Truesense KAI-29050 sensor, providing high-resolution imaging capability.
    • Connectivity: With Power over Ethernet (PoE) support and Ethernet surge suppression, the GT6600 offers reliable connectivity and power supply, even in harsh conditions.
    • Smart Features: The GT6600 includes a range of smart features such as auto exposure, auto gain, auto white balance, flexible binning, and region of interest (ROI) readout, enhancing its usability and adaptability to different imaging scenarios.
    • Global Shutter: Equipped with a global shutter (digital shutter), the camera ensures distortion-free imaging of fast-moving objects.
    • Models: Available in both mono (GT6600) and color (GT6600C) versions, the camera offers flexibility to suit various imaging requirements.
    • Applications: The Prosilica GT6600 finds applications in outdoor imaging, traffic imaging/ITS, public security and surveillance, industrial inspection, machine vision, as well as military and space applications, highlighting its versatility and adaptability across different industries.

    Technical Specifications of Prosilica GT6600

    GT 6600 Specification

    Manufacturer : Allied Vision Model : Prosilica GT6600 B/C Total Pixels : 28,829,184
    Resolution : 6576 (h) 4384 (v) Sensor size : 35mm Color/B & W : Color / Monochrome
    Frame rate : 4 Sensor type : CCD Sensor device : ON Semi KAI-29050
    Pixel size : 5.5 (h) 5.5 (v) A/D Bits : 12 Shutter speed : 30 us to 33500000 us
    Interface : GigE Voltage (VDC) : 7-25V Power (watts) : 7.7
    Lens Mount : F Shutter type : Global Weight (grams) : 372
    S/N Ratio(dB) : call External trigger : YES Dimensions (mm) : 96Lx66Wx53H

    Hardware and software requirements

    Prosilica GT6600 requirements are as shown below:

    Hardware Interface Gig E
    SDK Availability Vimba X (Downloaded and installed in local PC)
    IP Address 169.254.100.1
    Pixel Format
    • Mono8
    • Mono12
    • Mono12 packed
    • Mono14
    Gain 0-32 dB
    Models GT6600, 6576 x 4384, 4 fps, CCD mono, GT6600C, 6576 x 4384, 4 fps, CCD color

    SDK OVERVIEW

    Vimba C++ API is an object-oriented API that enables programmers to interact with Allied Vision cameras independent of the interface. It utilizes GenICam transport layer modules to connect to the various camera interfaces and is therefore generic. Features and capabilities of the SDK.

    Vimba C++ API has an elaborate class architecture. It is designed as a highly efficient and sophisticated API for advanced object-oriented programming including the STL (standard template library), shared pointers, and interface classes. If you prefer an API with less design patterns, we recommend the Vimba C API.

    Steps To Be Carried Out

    To build powerful Windows Prosilica applications carry out the following steps:

    1. Install the Vimba X Software SDK.
    2. Install the desired free Microsoft Visual Studio tool.
    3. Prepare the C++ projects.
    4. Run the project.

    Getting Started

    Installation : Begin by installing the Vimba X SDK on your development machine from the provided location.

    Exploring Examples : Explore the example projects provided in the SDK's "Examples" directory to understand how to interface with the Prosilica GT6000 camera using your preferred programming language.

    VimbaX Shortcut : Utilize the "VimbaX" shortcut to access the SDK's essential files and resources conveniently.

    DLL Usage : Make use of the DLLs located in the api\bin directory for interfacing with the camera and controlling its functionality within your driver development projects.

    With the Vimba X SDK and the provided resources, developers can embark on driver development for the Prosilica GT6000 camera. Whether using C, C++, or Python, the SDK offers comprehensive support for creating custom drivers tailored to specific application requirements. By leveraging the examples, documentation, and DLLs provided within the Vimba X SDK, developers can effectively interface with the Prosilica GT6000 camera, unlocking its full potential for industrial imaging applications.

    How to set up visual studio for the build

    Below is the link for setting up the build for visual studio:

    Link: https://docs.alliedvision.com/Vimba_X/Vimba_X_DeveloperGuide/sdkManual.html#building-applications

    API Documentation

    Below is the link for api documentation of Vimba X:

    Link: https://docs.alliedvision.com/

    DRIVER DEVELOPMENT

    Introduction to driver development for the device

    The Prosilica GT6000 camera offers high-performance imaging capabilities for various industrial applications. To harness its full potential, developers can create custom drivers to interface with the camera and control its functionality.

    Supported Languages : The Vimba X SDK supports multiple programming languages, including C, C++, and Python, allowing developers to choose the language they are most comfortable with for driver development.

    Installation Location : Upon installation, the Vimba X SDK is typically located at:

    C:\Users\Public\Documents\Allied Vision\Vimba X

    Vimba X Directory Structure : The SDK includes example projects for C, C++, and Python, providing developers with a starting point for their driver development efforts.

    VimbaX Shortcut : A shortcut named "VimbaX" is created during installation, leading to the directory:

    C:\Program Files\Allied Vision\Vimba X

    • This directory contains essential files and resources for driver development.
    • C:\Program Files\Allied Vision\Vimba X\api\bin houses DLLs required for interfacing with the camera.
    • C:\Program Files\Allied Vision\Vimba X\bin contains additional DLLs and supporting files necessary for driver development and camera control.

    Choice of programming language (Python or C++)

    For developing the driver we have used C++.

    The best API for our purpose

    Vimba provides four APIs:

    • The Python API is ideal for quick prototyping. We also recommend this API for an easy start with machine vision or embedded vision applications. For best performance and deterministic behavior, the C and C++ APIs are a better choice.
    • The C API is easy-to-use, but requires more lines of code than the Python API. It can also be used as API for C++ applications. The C API is also recommended to easily migrate from PVAPI to Vimba.
    • The C++ API is designed as a highly efficient and sophisticated API for advanced object-oriented programming including shared pointers, the STL (Standard Template Library), and interface classes. If you prefer an API with less design patterns, we recommend the Vimba C API.
    • The .NET API supports all .NET languages, for example, C#, C++/CLI, or Visual Basic .NET. Its general concept is similar to the C++ API.

    Driver Implementation

    The following drivers or APIs are developed and tested

    1. Open Device
    2. Close Device
    3. Get Device Details
    4. Set Exposure Time
    5. Set Pixel Format
    6. Set Gain
    7. Save Current Configuration Parameters
    8. Load Current Configuration Parameters
    9. Get Image File - (.jpeg, .png, .bmp, .tiff, .bmp)

    gRPC API’s Description for Prosilica

    1. OpenDevice

      Description for OpenDevice API: Establishes a connection to the GT6600 Camera, initializing communication for further operations.

      RPC Command :rpc OpenDevice(CommandIPRequest) returns (CommandResponse){}

      Request:
      message CommandIPRequest {
      string ip_address = 1;
      string com = 2;
      int64 port_address = 3;
      int32 device_id = 4;
      string file_path = 5;
      int64 device_model =6;
      optional string device_alias=7;
      int32 axis =8;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      ip_address Specifies the IP address of the device.
      com Indicates the communication protocol or interface to be used
      port_address Denotes the specific port address for the device on the communication interface.
      device_id Unique identifier for the device, used to distinguish it from other devices in the system.
      file_path The path to the file, which may include configuration, program, or data files for the device.
      device_model Represents the model number or type of the device being communicated with.
      device_alias A user-defined alias for the device, providing a more descriptive or convenient reference.
      axis Specifies the axis number (e.g., X, Y, Z) on which the command or operation will be performed.
      enum DeviceType{
      NONE = 0;
      SENSOR_3D = 1;
      MOTION_STAGE = 2;
      CAMERA = 3;
      IO_MODULE = 4;
      SAFETY_CONTROLLER = 5;
      ANIMATIC_MOTOR=6;
      }
      enum DeviceModel{
      DUMMY_MODEL = 0;
      ED527 = 1;
      ED588 = 2 ;
      JR3000 = 3;
      OPTOE = 4;
      BASLER = 5;
      SPiiPlusEC=6;
      GT6600 = 7;
      MOTOR = 8;
      }
      enum DeviceStatus{
      OFFLINE = 0;
      ONLINE = 1;
      NOT_REACHABLE =2;
      }
      message CommandResponse{
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_message = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python3 prosilica_gt6600.py OpenDevice 192.168.88.88 ProSilica_GT6600_1
      Description for CLI Command
      • OpenDevice: API called to the GT6600 Camera through CLI Command to Connect and Initialize all Resources
      • 192.168.88.88: IP Address of the device
      • ProSilica_GT6600_1:Aliased Name of GT6600 Camera

    2. CloseDevice

      Description for CloseDevice API: Disconnects from the Prosilica GT6600 Camera, releasing all resources and deleting associated handlers to ensure a clean shutdown.

      RPC Command: rpc CloseDevice(CommandRequest) returns (CommandResponse) {}

      Request: message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias Unique alias of the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python3 prosilica_gt6600.py CloseDevice ProSilica_GT6600_1
      Description for CLI Command:
      • CloseDevice: API called to the Prosilica GT6600 Camera through CLI Command to Close Camera Connection
      • ProSilica_GT6600_1: Aliased Name for device

    3. GetDeviceDetails

      Description for GetDeviceDetails API: Retrieves detailed information about the connected Prosilica GT6600 Camera, including its configuration and status.

      RPC Command : rpc GetDeviceDetails(CommandRequest) returns (GenericDeviceModel) {}

      Request:
      message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias Unique alias of the device
      Response:
      message GenericDeviceModel{
      string instance_id = 1;
      string device_alias = 2;
      DeviceType device_type = 3;
      DeviceModel device_model_name = 4;
      optional DeviceStatus device_status = 5;
      string ipaddr = 6;
      string mac_addr = 7;
      google.protobuf.Value conn_handle=8;
      string port_name = 9;
      int64 port_address = 10;
      CommandResponse cmd_response = 11;
      }
      Parameter Description
      instance_id New instance for the device in the enumeration
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      device_type Indicates the type of device like Motion stage, Safety Controller etc (defined below in the DeviceType enum)
      device_model_name Indicate the model name for each device (define below in the DeviceModel enum)
      device_status Indicate whether the device is online , offline or not reachable (define below in the device status enum)
      ipaddr Indicate the ipaddress of the device
      mac_addr Indicate the mac address of the device
      Conn_handle Handle object to keep the device open
      port_name Port name
      port_address Port address
      cmd_response Indicates command response that describes API response code and its description (Defined below in CommandResponse)
      enum DeviceType{
      NONE = 0;
      SENSOR_3D = 1;
      MOTION_STAGE = 2;
      CAMERA = 3;
      IO_MODULE = 4;
      SAFETY_CONTROLLER = 5;
      ANIMATIC_MOTOR=6;
      }
      enum DeviceModel{
      DUMMY_MODEL = 0;
      ED527 = 1;
      ED588 = 2 ;
      JR3000 = 3;
      OPTOE = 4;
      BASLER = 5;
      SPiiPlusEC=6;
      GT6600 = 7;
      MOTOR = 8;
      }
      enum DeviceStatus{
      OFFLINE = 0;
      ONLINE = 1;
      NOT_REACHABLE =2;
      }
      message CommandResponse{
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_message = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_message Description of the response code

      CLI Command:python3 prosilica_gt6600.py GetDeviceDetails ProSilica_GT6600_1

      Description for CLI Command:
      • GetDeviceDetails: API called to the GT6000 Camera through CLI Command
      • ProSilica_GT6600_1: Aliased Name for device

    4. ChangeAlias

      Description for ChangeAlias API: Updates the alias of the device, allowing it to be referenced by a new identifier.

      RPC Command: rpc changeAlias(ChangeAliasRequest) returns (CommandResponse) {}

      Request: message ChangeAliasRequest{
      string current_alias=1;
      string new_alias=2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      current_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      new_alias The device_alias to change to
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python3 prosilica_gt6600.py changeAlias current_alias new_alias
        Description for CLI Command:
      • ChangeAlias: API called to the GT6600 Camera through CLI Command to get new alias name
      • current_alias: The current device_alias used to refer to the device
      • new_alias: The device_alias to change to

    5. SetExposureTime

      Description of the API: Sets the exposure time for the GT6600 Camera to control the amount of light captured during image acquisition.

      RPC Command: rpc SetExposureTime(SetExposureTimeGT6600CameraRequest)returns(CommandResponse) {}

      Request: message SetExposureTimeGT6600CameraRequest {
      float time_value = 1;
      CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
      }
       message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      time_value Indicates time value to be configured in microseconds (Ranges from 10us to 10 sec) units: in us(microseconds)
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python3 prosilica_gt6600.py SetExposureTime ProSilica_GT6600_1 100

      Description for CLI Command:

      • SetExposureTime: API called to the GT6600 Camera through CLI Command
      • ProSilica_GT6600_1: Alias of the Device
      • 100: Sample Exposure Time value Configured in millisecond

    6. SetPixelFormat

      Description of the API: Configures the pixel format of the GT6600 Camera for image capture.

      RPC Command: rpc SetPixelFormat(SetPixelGT6600Request) returns(CommandResponse) {}

      Request: message SetPixelGT6600Request {
      string pixel_format = 1;
      CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
      }
       message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      pixel_format Indicates pixel format to be configured ("Mono8", "Mono12" "Mono12P" or "Mono14" are supported for GT6600 Camera)
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python3 prosilica_gt6600.py SetPixelFormat ProSilica_GT6600_1 Mono12

      Description for CLI Command:

      • SetPixelFormat: API called to the GT6600 Camera through CLI Command
      • ProSilica_GT6600_1: Alias of the Device
      • Mono12: Pixel format to be configured ("Mono8", "Mono12" "Mono12P" or "Mono14" are supported for GT6600 Camera)

    7. SetGain

      Description of the API: Configures the gain setting for the GT6600 Camera.

      RPC Command: rpc SetGain(SetGainGT6600CameraRequest) returns(CommandResponse) {}

      Request: message SetGainGT6600CameraRequest {
      float gain_value = 1;
      CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
      }
       message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      gain_value indicates gain value to be Configured (units in db)
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: : python3 prosilica_gt6600.py SetGain ProSilica_GT6600_1 21

      Description for CLI Command:

      • SetGain:API called to the GT6600 Camera through CLI Command
      • ProSilica_GT6600_1: Alias of the Device
      • 21: Gain to be configured

    8. LoadCameraConfig

      Description of the API: Loads the camera's configuration from a pre-existing .xml file.

      RPC Command: rpc LoadCameraConfig(stream LoadConfigGT6600CameraRequest) returns(CommandResponse) {}

      Request: message LoadConfigGT6600CameraRequest {
      string file_name = 1;
      bytes config_data = 2;
      CommandRequest cmd_request = 3;
      }
       message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      file_name Indicates pre-existing configuration file name to be loaded to the camera (Camera config file format: xml)
      config_data Represents camera features data like Gain, Time, Resolution, fps etc
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command:python3 prosilica_gt6600.py LoadCameraConfig ProSilica_GT6600_1 GT6600_save_settings.xml

      Description for CLI Command:

      • LoadCameraConfig: API called to the GT6600 Camera through CLI Command
      • ProSilica_GT6600_1: Alias of the Device
      • GT6600_save_settings.xml: XML settings file path to be loaded

    9. SaveCameraConfig

      Description of the API: Saves Camera's Configuration to .xml file

      RPC Command: rpc SaveCameraConfig(SaveConfigGT6600CameraRequest) returns(stream SaveConfigGT6600CameraResponse) {}

      Request: message SaveConfigGT6600CameraRequest {
      string file_name = 1;
      CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
      }
       message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      file_name Indicates the name of the file under which the camera's feature will be saved
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message SaveConfigGT6600CameraResponse {
      optional bytes config_data = 1;
      optional string file_path = 2;
      optional int64 file_size = 3;
      CommandResponse cmd_response = 4;
      }
       message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      config_data Indicates file contents received from the server
      file_path Indicates userdefined file, configuration file name received from the server
      file_size Indicates the size of the configuration file name received from the server
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command:python3 prosilica_gt6600.py SaveCameraConfig ProSilica_GT6600_1 GT6600_save_settings.xml

      Description for CLI Command:

      • SaveCameraConfig: API called to the GT6600 Camera through CLI Command to Save camera features.
      • ProSilica_GT6600_1: Alias of the Device
      • GT6600_save_settings.xml: XML settings file path to be saved

    10. GetImage

      Description of the API: To Capture Single Image with user defined name and Format

      RPC Command: rpc GetImage(GetImageFileGT6600CameraRequest) returns(stream GetImageFileGT6600CameraResponse) {}

      Request: message GetImageFileGT6600CameraRequest {
      string file_name = 1;
      CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
      }
       message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      file_name Indicates the user defined name under which the image will be saved
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message GetImageFileGT6600CameraResponse {
      optional bytes image_data = 1;
      optional string file_name = 2;
      optional int64 file_size = 3;
      .generic.CommandResponse cmd_response = 4;
      }
       message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      image_data Indicates image data
      file_name Indicates the user defined file name of captured image
      file_size Indicates the file size of captured image
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command:python3 prosilica_gt6600.py GetImageFile ProSilica_GT6600_1 gt6600_getimage.raw

      Description for CLI Command:

      • GetImageFile: API called to the GT6600 Camera through CLI Command to Capture an Image
      • ProSilica_GT6600_1: Alias of the Device
      • gt6600_getimage.raw: Name and format of the image to be saved

    11. SingleTrigger

      Description of the API: Captures a single image and streams it over grpc server

      RPC Command: rpc SingleTrigger(CommandRequest) returns(stream SingleTriggerGT6600CameraResponse) {}

      Request: message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message SingleTriggerGT6600CameraResponse {
      optional ImageMetaData image_data = 1;
      optional string file_name = 2;
      optional int64 file_size = 3;
      optional bytes buffer = 4;
      .generic.CommandResponse cmd_response = 5;
      }
       message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      image_data Indicates the object which holds frame width, height and pixel format which are taken from Vimba SDK
      file_name Indicates userdefined file name received from the server
      file_size Indicates the file size received from the server
      buffer Indicates buffer which contains image bytes
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python3 prosilica_gt6600.py SingleTrigger ProSilica_GT6600_1 Description for CLI Command:
      • SingleTrigger: Name of the API
      • ProSilica_GT6600_1: Alias of the Device

    12. StartLiveStreaming and StopLiveStreaming

      Description of the API: To start and stop live streaming over grpc server(Bi-Directional streaming)

      RPC Command: rpc StartLiveStreaming(stream GT6600LiveStream) returns (stream GT6600LiveStream) {}

      rpc StopLiveStreaming(CommandRequest) returns (CommandResponse) {}

      Request and Response: message FrameModel {
      int64 frame_size = 1;
      bytes frame_data = 2;
      }
       message GT6600LiveStream {
      FrameModel frame_model = 1;
      CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
      CommandResponse cmd_response = 3;
      }
       message CommandRequest {
      int64 device_alias = 1;
      }
       message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      frame_size Indicates the frame size received from the server
      frame_data Indicates the frame content received in bytes format from the server
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python3 cl3000.py GetStorageData CL3000_1 0 10 File/cl3000_storage.csv

      python3 prosilica_gt6600.py StopLiveStreaming ProSilica_GT6600_1

      Description for CLI Command:
      • StartLiveStreaming, StopLiveStreaming: Name of the API
      • ProSilica_GT6600_1: Alias of the Device

    Limitations of the driver

    WProsilica cameras, like any other technology, come with their own set of limitations. These limitations can vary depending on the specific model and application context, but here are some common limitations associated with Prosilica cameras:

    1. Resolution and Sensor Size: While Prosilica cameras offer high-resolution options, they may not match the resolution or sensor size of some specialized cameras designed for very high-resolution imaging tasks or specific sensor formats.
    2. Frame Rate Limitations: Depending on the camera model and resolution settings, Prosilica cameras may have limitations on the maximum achievable frame rate. This can be a concern in applications requiring very high-speed imaging.
    3. Dynamic Range: While Prosilica cameras generally offer good dynamic range, they may not match the performance of specialized cameras designed for extremely high dynamic range imaging tasks.
    4. Lens Compatibility: Compatibility with certain lenses or lens mounts may be limited, depending on the camera model and lens interface options. This can restrict flexibility in choosing lenses for specific applications.
    5. Connectivity Options: While Prosilica cameras typically support Gigabit Ethernet connectivity, they may not support other interfaces such as USB or Camera Link. This can be a limitation in setups where a different interface is preferred or required.
    6. Environmental Limitations: Prosilica cameras are designed for industrial use and can often withstand harsh environments. However, they may have limitations in extreme environmental conditions such as very high or low temperatures, high humidity, or exposure to corrosive substances.
    7. Software Compatibility: While Prosilica cameras often come with comprehensive software development kits (SDKs) and drivers for various programming languages, compatibility with specific software platforms or operating systems may be limited.
    8. Support and Maintenance: While Prosilica cameras typically come with manufacturer support and warranty options, access to technical support and availability of spare parts may vary depending on the region and the specific model.

    Understanding these limitations is essential for selecting the right camera for a given application and managing expectations regarding performance and capabilities. In many cases, Prosilica cameras offer an excellent balance of features, reliability, and performance for industrial imaging applications despite these limitations.

    Precautions to take before executing the driver

    • Make sure Gain Range is 0 to 30dB.
    • Make sure the Gain value should be float.
    • Parameters need to be expressed as 5.0 rather than 5.

    TESTING AND DEBUGGING

    Error Codes

    Error Name Error Code Error Description
    VmbErrorSuccess 0 Success
    VmbErrorInternalFault -1 Unexpected fault in VmbC or driver
    VmbErrorApiNotStarted -2 VmbStartup() was not called before the current command
    VmbErrorNotFound -3 The designated instance (camera, feature etc.) cannot be found
    VmbErrorBadHandle -4 The given handle is not valid
    VmbErrorDeviceNotOpen -5 Device was not opened for usage
    VmbErrorInvalidAccess -6 Operation is invalid with the current access mode
    VmbErrorBadParameter -7 One of the parameters is invalid (usually an illegal pointer)
    VmbErrorStructSize -8 The given struct size is not valid for this version of the API
    VmbErrorMoreData -9 More data available in a string/list than space is provided
    VmbErrorWrongType -10 Wrong feature type for this access function
    VmbErrorInvalidValue -11 The value is not valid; either out of bounds or not an increment of the minimum
    VmbErrorTimeout -12 Timeout during wait
    VmbErrorOther -13 Other error
    VmbErrorResources -14 Resources not available (e.g. memory)
    VmbErrorInvalidCall -15 Call is invalid in the current context (e.g. callback)
    VmbErrorNoTL -16 No transport layers are found
    VmbErrorNotImplemented -17 API feature is not implemented
    VmbErrorNotSupported -18 API feature is not supported
    VmbErrorIncomplete -19 The current operation was not completed (e.g. a multiple registers read or write)
    VmbErrorIO -20 Low level IO error in transport layer
    VmbErrorValidValueSetNotPresent -21 The valid value set could not be retrieved, since the feature does not provide this property
    VmbErrorGenTLUnspecified -22 Unspecified GenTL runtime error
    VmbErrorUnspecified -23 Unspecified runtime error
    VmbErrorBusy -24 The responsible module/entity is busy executing actions
    VmbErrorNoData -25 The function has no data to work on
    VmbErrorParsingChunkData -26 An error occurred parsing a buffer containing chunk data
    VmbErrorInUse -27 Something is already in use
    VmbErrorUnknown -28 Error condition unknown
    VmbErrorXml -29 Error parsing XML
    VmbErrorNotAvailable -30 Something is not available
    VmbErrorNotInitialized -31 Something is not initialized
    VmbErrorInvalidAddress -32 The given address is out of range or invalid for internal reasons
    VmbErrorAlready -33 Something has already been done
    VmbErrorNoChunkData -34 A frame expected to contain chunk data does not contain chunk data
    VmbErrorUserCallbackException -35 A callback provided by the user threw an exception
    VmbErrorFeaturesUnavailable -36 The XML for the module is currently not loaded; the module could be in the wrong state or the XML could not be retrieved or could not be parsed properly
    VmbErrorTLNotFound -37 A required transport layer could not be found or loaded
    VmbErrorAmbiguous -39 An entity cannot be uniquely identified based on the information provided
    VmbErrorRetriesExceeded -40 Something could not be accomplished with a given number of retries
    VmbErrorInsufficientBufferCount -41 The operation requires more buffers
    VmbErrorCustom 1 The minimum error code to use for user defined error codes to avoid conflict with existing error codes
