    GLOSSARY

    Glossary of Terms for Prosilica GT6000 Camera:

    • Resolution: The level of detail in an image, typically measured in pixels horizontally and vertically. Higher resolution provides greater clarity and detail in captured images.
    • Frame Rate: The number of frames captured by the camera per second. Higher frame rates allow for smoother motion capture, essential for applications requiring real-time monitoring or high-speed imaging.
    • Sensor Size: The physical dimensions of the camera's image sensor, often expressed in inches or millimeters. Larger sensors generally capture more light and offer better image quality, particularly in low-light conditions.
    • Dynamic Range: The range of light intensity levels that a camera can capture, from the darkest shadows to the brightest highlights, without losing detail. A wider dynamic range enables the camera to capture scenes with high contrast more effectively.
    • Pixel Size: The size of individual pixels on the camera sensor, typically measured in micrometers (µm). Larger pixel sizes can capture more light, improving low-light performance and reducing noise in images.
    • Bit Depth: The number of bits used to represent each pixel's color or grayscale value. Higher bit depths provide greater color fidelity and dynamic range but require more storage space and processing power.
    • Interface: The method by which the camera communicates with external devices, such as a computer or controller. Common interfaces include Gigabit Ethernet, USB, and Camera Link.
    • Triggering: The process of initiating image capture based on external events or signals, such as a sensor input, timer, or software command. Precise triggering is crucial for synchronizing multiple cameras or capturing events at specific moments.
    • ROI (Region of Interest): A defined area within the camera's field of view where image capture and processing are focused. Limiting image processing to the ROI can improve efficiency and reduce data transfer and processing requirements.
    • Exposure Time: The duration for which the camera's sensor is exposed to light during image capture, typically measured in milliseconds (ms) or microseconds (µs). Adjusting exposure time controls the amount of light reaching the sensor, affecting image brightness and clarity.
    • Gain: An amplification factor applied to the camera's sensor signal to increase image brightness in low-light conditions. However, excessive gain can introduce noise and reduce image quality.
    • White Balance: The adjustment of color balance in an image to accurately represent true colors under different lighting conditions. White balance settings compensate for variations in light color temperature, ensuring accurate color reproduction.
    • Shutter Mode: The camera's operating mode for controlling exposure time and capturing images. Common shutter modes include rolling shutter, global shutter, and electronic rolling shutter, each suitable for different applications and motion conditions.
    • Image Processing: The manipulation and enhancement of captured images to improve quality, extract relevant information, or perform analysis. Image processing functions may include noise reduction, sharpening, color correction, and object detection.
    • SDK (Software Development Kit): A set of tools, libraries, and documentation provided by the camera manufacturer to facilitate software development for controlling and interacting with the camera. SDKs typically support multiple programming languages and offer APIs for accessing camera features and data.

    Triton Camera driver document

    Introduction

    Brief overview of the Project

    This project focuses on developing drivers for the Triton Camera (TRI0245S-MC) for use in automation applications, with an emphasis on integrating it with a user interface (UI) application. The goal is to create software components that facilitate smooth communication between the Triton Camera, enabling precise control over camera settings, image capture, and real-time data streaming. By integrating these systems, the project aims to improve the operational efficiency and functionality of automated processes, contributing to increased productivity and reliability in industrial environments.

    Purpose of the document

    The purpose of this document is to provide a detailed guide for developing a driver for the Lucid Triton Camera (TRI0245S-MC). The driver will enable communication between the Camera and external software application (Arena View), allowing to capture an Image, change camera settings like pixel format, exposure time, gain and many more. It covers the software development process, including setting up the development environment, implementing the driver, testing and debugging, and integrating the driver with the Lucid Triton Camera.

    The primary objective of the document is to provide a comprehensive guide for developed drivers for Lucid Triton Camera (TRI0245S-MC) used in automation using a UI application. This includes detailed instructions, software installation guide, a device description with its features, and best practices to ensure the successful development and integration of drivers with the devices.

    Scope and objectives

    1. Driver Development: The document focuses on the development of a driver for Triton Camera using industry-standard protocols.
    2. Technical Information: It provides the technical specifications of the camera, hardware and software requirements, and detailed information about the Software Development Kit (SDK) provided for the device.
    3. SDK Overview: Introduction to Arena SDK and Arena View software, covering the installation process and usage of these tools for development
    4. Driver Implementation: This section covers the driver development process, including the selection of a suitable programming language, usage of APIs for interacting with the camera, limitations of the driver, necessary precautions before execution, and the actual implementation strategy.
    5. Testing and Debugging: The scope extends to testing and debugging methodologies, ensuring the driver performs reliably and meets the required performance standards in real-time automation scenarios.
    6. Documentation and Support: : This document provides information about documentation standards for the development process and available support resources for developers working on integrating the driver with the Lucid Triton Camera.

    Overall, the aim is to facilitate the successful development and implementation of the Triton Lucid Camera, ensuring it meets the required standards and serves its intended purpose effectively.

    Device Overview

    Description of the device for which the driver is being developed

    LUCID Vision Labs Triton™ GigE Power over Ethernet (PoE) Cameras provide exceptional price performance in a compact 29 x 29mm form factor. These cameras are available with Sony’s Pregius™ and Starvis™ imaging sensors with up to 24.5 megapixels of resolution, as well as Sony’s polarized sensor. Each imaging sensor is actively aligned during manufacturing, ensuring sharp and crisp images even in the corners. Using the accessory IP67 lens tubes (sold separately), LUCID Vision Labs Triton GigE Power over Ethernet (PoE) Cameras can operate in harsh environments where dust or water are present up to IP67 thresholds. Triton cameras are ideal for automotive, process control, and food and beverage applications..

    The full list of features for Triton cameras can be accessed here. here .

    Technical Specifications of Triton(TRI0245S-MC)

    Type Area Scan Camera
    Model Lucid Vision Labs Triton™ TRI0245S-MC
    Resolution (H x V Pixels)

    5,320 x 4,600
    Resolution 24.50 MP
    Sensor Type

    Sony IMX540

    Progressive scan CMOS

    Global shutter
    Sensor Format 1/4.3"
    Pixel Size (H x V) 2.74 x 2.74
    Frame Rate (at Default Settings) 4.90 fps
    Product Family Triton™
    Mono / Colour Mono
    Image Data Interface

    Fast Ethernet (100 Mbit/s)

    Gigabit Ethernet (1000 Mbit/s)
    Pixel Formats Mono8, Mono16
    Gain 0 – 48 decibels
    Synchronization

    Via hardware trigger

    Via software trigger

    Via free run
    Exposure Time Control

    Via hardware trigger

    Programmable via the camera API
    Camera Power Requirements

    ≈3W External Power Supplyt

    ≈3.5W (PoE)
    I/O Lines

    1 opto-coupled input line

    2 general purpose I/O (GPIO) lines
    Lens Mount C-mount
    Size (L x W x H)

    29 x 29 x 45 (excludes connectors and lens mount)
    Weight >67 g
    Software

    Arena View SDK

    Available for Windows 7(32-bit and 64- bit)/10(32-bit and 64-bit)/11(64-bit)/10,Ubuntu 20.04/22.04(64-bit).

    Software Overview and Requirements – Arena SDK

    The Arena SDK is a comprehensive software development kit designed for high-performance imaging applications. It provides developers with a powerful set of tools for working with cameras, such as those in the Lucid Vision product line, including the Triton Camera series. The SDK simplifies integration, control, and management of camera operations for various industrial and automation applications.

    Features of Arena SDK

    • Cross-Platform Compatibility:Arena SDK supports both Windows and Linux operating systems, allowing developers to build applications across different platforms.
    • Easy Camera Integration: It provides simplified APIs for connecting and managing cameras, making it easy to control settings such as exposure time, gain, frame rate, and pixel format.
    • GenICam Compliance: Arena SDK is fully compliant with the GenICam standard, allowing seamless control of various cameras that adhere to this standard.
    • High-Speed Data Streaming: Designed for high-performance applications, the SDK supports efficient data transfer and streaming from cameras to external applications.
    • Extensive Documentation and Sample Code: Arena SDK offers extensive documentation, tutorials, and sample applications to help developers quickly understand and implement key functionalities.
    • Multi-Camera Support: The SDK allows simultaneous operation of multiple cameras, making it ideal for complex imaging systems.
    • Advanced Imaging Controls: Provides features like region of interest (ROI), binning, and trigger modes, which are crucial for optimizing performance in specific applications.

    Hardware and Software Requirements

    Software Requirements:

    • Operating Systems: Windows 10/11, Linux distributions such as Ubuntu.
    • Supported Programming Languages: The SDK supports C, C++, and C# languages, providing flexible options for developers.
    • Libraries: Includes precompiled libraries and drivers required for camera operation and integration with custom software applications.
    • Development Environment: Compatible with popular IDEs such as Microsoft Visual Studio and GCC-based compilers on Linux.
    • Power supply for the camera- Power Over Ethernet

    Hardware Requirements:

    • Lucid Vision Cameras: Designed for use with Lucid Triton Camera and other models in the Lucid Vision series
    • High-Performance Processors: For real-time image processing and handling high data throughput, a multi-core CPU is recommended
    • Memory and Storage: Sufficient RAM and storage to handle large image data files and high-speed data streaming.

    Additional Requirements:

    This version of Microsoft Visual Studio works best with Internet Explorer 10 or higher. If Internet Explorer 10 is not installed on your computer, some features might not work as expected.

    Installing Triton Arena SDK Viewer

    This topic tells you how to install the Arena SDK Software Suite for Windows.

    System Requirements

    The Triton Arena Camera Software Suite for Windows requires one of the following operating systems to be installed on computer:

    • Windows 10 (64 bit)
    • Windows 11 (64 bit)

    Installation

    To install the Triton Arena Camera Software Suite for Windows:

    1. Download the Arena SDK installer from here .
    2. Launch the downloaded installer.
    3. Follow the instructions in the setup wizard. The wizard will guide you through the installation process. During installation, you can choose the interfaces of your cameras (e.g., USB or GigE) so that only the software you need is installed.

    Introduction to Software Development Kit

    The Arena View SDK is a specialized software development kit that provides a robust platform for interacting with Lucid Vision cameras, including the Triton Camera series. Arena View is the graphical user interface (GUI) application that complements the SDK by enabling users to interact with and control their cameras easily. The SDK is designed for use in high-performance, real-time image capture and processing, making it an ideal tool for industrial, scientific, and automation applications

    Documentation and Samples Comprehensive documentation, plus a collection of programming samples for C ++, C, .NET languages (C#, VB.NET, etc.), illustrate various use cases for different grab strategies, multi-camera applications, recording video files, apply image processing, and many more.d many more.

    DRIVER DEVELOPMENT

    Installing the Arena Software Suite SDK

    Download the desired or current version of the Triton Arena Camera Software Suite from the Lucid Vision website:

    here.

    Installing the Desired Free Microsoft Visual Studio Tool

    1. Be ready to have a Microsoft account registration (email address and password).

      The Free Microsoft Studio IDE applications are free developer tools for single users and small commercial teams. To download and use them longer than the trial period, a Microsoft account is requested that is easily and free available through registration with a valid email address.

    2. Download the desired free Microsoft Visual Studio tool:
      • Microsoft Visual Studio Express 2013 for Windows Desktop
      • Microsoft Visual Studio Community

    Driver Implementation

    The following drivers or APIs are developed and tested

    1. Open Device
    2. Close Device
    3. Get Device Details
    4. Set Exposure Time – (Max: 462130 micro seconds. Min: 45 micro seconds)
    5. Set Pixel Format – (Mono 8, Mono 16)
    6. Set Gain – (0 to 48db)
    7. Save Current Configuration Parameters
    8. Load Current Configuration Parameters
    9. Get Image File - (.jpeg, .png, .bmp, .tiff, .bmp)
    10. Get Gain
    11. Get ExposureTime
    12. Get PixelFormat

    gRPC API’s Description for lucid triton Camera

    1. OpenDevice

      Description for OpenDevice API: Establishes a connection to the Triton Camera, initializing communication for further operations.

      RPC Command: rpc OpenDevice(.generic.CommandIPRequest) returns(.generic.GenericDeviceModel) {}

      Request:
      message CommandIPRequest {
      string ip_address = 1;
      string com = 2;
      int64 port_address = 3;
      int32 device_id = 4;
      string file_path = 5;
      int64 device_model =6;
      optional string device_alias=7;
      int32 axis =8;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      ip_address Specifies the IP address of the device.
      com Indicates the communication protocol or interface to be used
      port_address Denotes the specific port address for the device on the communication interface.
      device_id Unique identifier for the device, used to distinguish it from other devices in the system.
      file_path The path to the file, which may include configuration, program, or data files for the device.
      device_model Represents the model number or type of the device being communicated with.
      device_alias A user-defined alias for the device, providing a more descriptive or convenient reference.
      axis Specifies the axis number (e.g., X, Y, Z) on which the command or operation will be performed.
      enum DeviceType{
      NONE = 0;
      SENSOR_3D = 1;
      MOTION_STAGE = 2;
      CAMERA = 3;
      IO_MODULE = 4;
      SAFETY_CONTROLLER = 5;
      ANIMATIC_MOTOR=6;
      }
      enum DeviceModel{
      DUMMY_MODEL = 0;
      ED527 = 1;
      ED588 = 2 ;
      JR3000 = 3;
      OPTOE = 4;
      BASLER = 5;
      SPiiPlusEC=6;
      GT6600 = 7;
      MOTOR = 8;
      }
      enum DeviceStatus{
      OFFLINE = 0;
      ONLINE = 1;
      NOT_REACHABLE =2;
      }
      message CommandResponse{
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_message = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_message Response message code
      CLI Command: python tritoncamera.py OpenDevice 192.168.200.100 Triton
      Description for CLI Command
      • OpenDevice: API called to the Triton Camera through CLI Command to Connect and Initialize all Resources
      • 192.168.200.100: IP Address of the device
      • Triton:Aliased Name for the Device

    2. CloseDevice

      Description for CloseDevice API: Disconnects from the Triton Camera, releasing all resources and deleting associated handlers to ensure a clean shutdown.

      RPC Command: rpc CloseDevice(.generic.CommandRequest) returns(.generic.CommandResponse) {}

      Request: message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias Unique alias of the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python tritoncamera.py CloseDevice Triton
      Description for CLI Command:
      • CloseDevice: API called to the Triton Camera through CLI Command to Close Triton Camera Connection
      • Triton: Aliased Name for device

    3. GetDeviceDetails

      Description for GetDeviceDetails API: Retrieves detailed information about the connected Triton Camera, including its configuration and status.

      RPC Command : rpc GetDeviceDetails(.generic. CommandRequest) returns (.generic.GenericDeviceModel) {}

      Request:
      message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias Unique alias of the device
      Response:
      message GenericDeviceModel{
      string instance_id = 1;
      string device_alias = 2;
      DeviceType device_type = 3;
      DeviceModel device_model_name = 4;
      optional DeviceStatus device_status = 5;
      string ipaddr = 6;
      string mac_addr = 7;
      google.protobuf.Value conn_handle=8;
      string port_name = 9;
      int64 port_address = 10;
      CommandResponse cmd_response = 11;
      }
      Parameter Description
      instance_id New instance for the device in the enumeration
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      device_type Indicates the type of device like Motion stage, Safety Controller etc (defined below in the DeviceType enum)
      device_model_name Indicate the model name for each device (define below in the DeviceModel enum)
      device_status Indicate whether the device is online , offline or not reachable (define below in the device status enum)
      ipaddr Indicate the ipaddress of the device
      mac_addr Indicate the mac address of the device
      Conn_handle Handle object to keep the device open
      port_name Port name
      port_address Port address
      cmd_response Indicates command response that describes API response code and its description (Defined below in CommandResponse)
      enum DeviceType{
      NONE = 0;
      SENSOR_3D = 1;
      MOTION_STAGE = 2;
      CAMERA = 3;
      IO_MODULE = 4;
      SAFETY_CONTROLLER = 5;
      ANIMATIC_MOTOR=6;
      }
      enum DeviceModel{
      DUMMY_MODEL = 0;
      ED527 = 1;
      ED588 = 2 ;
      JR3000 = 3;
      OPTOE = 4;
      BASLER = 5;
      SPiiPlusEC=6;
      GT6600 = 7;
      MOTOR = 8;
      }
      enum DeviceStatus{
      OFFLINE = 0;
      ONLINE = 1;
      NOT_REACHABLE =2;
      }
      message CommandResponse{
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_message = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_message Response Message
      CLI Command: python tritoncamera.py GetDeviceDetails Triton
      Description for CLI Command:
      • GetDeviceDetails: API called to the Triton Camera through CLI Command
      • Triton: Aliased Name for device

    4. ChangeAlias

      Description for ChangeAlias API: Updates the alias of the device, allowing it to be referenced by a new identifier.

      RPC Command: rpc ChangeAlias(ChangeAliasRequest) returns (CommandResponse) {}

      Request: message ChangeAliasRequest{
      string current_alias=1;
      string new_alias=2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      current_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      new_alias The device_alias to change to
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python tritoncamera.py ChangeAlias current_alias new_alias
        Description for CLI Command:
      • ChangeAlias: API called to the Triton Camera through CLI Command to get new alias name
      • current_alias: The current device_alias used to refer to the device
      • new_alias: The device_alias to change to

    5. SetExposureTime

      Description of the API: Sets the exposure time for the Triton Camera to control the amount of light captured during image acquisition.

      RPC Command: rpc SetExposureTime(SetExposureTimeTritonCameraRequest) returns(.generic.CommandResponse) {}

      Request: message SetExposureTimeTritonCameraRequest {
      float time_value = 1;
      CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
      }
       message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      time_value Exposure Time to be configured in float. Max :462130 micro seconds. Min: 45 micro seconds
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python tritoncamera.py SetExposureTime Triton 5000

      Description for CLI Command:

      • SetExposureTime: API called to the Triton Camera through CLI Command
      • Triton: Alias of the Device
      • 5000: Sample Exposure Time value Configured in millisecond

    6. GetExposureTime

      Description of the API: Retrieves the current exposure time setting of the Triton Camera.

      RPC Command: rpc GetExposureTime(.generic.CommandRequest) returns(GetExposureTimeTritonCameraResponse) {}

      Response: message GetExposureTimeTritonCameraResponse {
      float exposure_time = 1;
      .generic.CommandResponse cmd_response = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      exposure_time Current Exposure Time of Triton Camera
      message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python tritoncamera.py GetExposureTime Triton

      Description for CLI Command:

      • GetExposureTime: API called to the Triton Camera through CLI Command
      • Triton: Alias of the Device

    7. SetPixelFormat

      Description of the API: Configures the pixel format of the Triton Camera for image capture.

      RPC Command: rpc SetPixelFormat(SetPixelTritonCameraRequest) returns(.generic.CommandResponse) {}

      Request: message SetPixelTritonCameraRequest {
      string pixel_format = 1;
      CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
      }
       message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      pixel_format Pixel Format to be configured. "Mono16", "Mono8"
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python tritoncamera.py SetPixelFormat Triton Mono16

      Description for CLI Command:

      • SetPixelFormat: API called to the Triton Camera through CLI Command
      • Triton: Alias of the Device
      • Mono16: Setting Pixel Format as Mono16

    8. GetPixelFormat

      Description of the API: Retrieves the currently configured pixel format of the Triton Camera.

      RPC Command: rpc GetPixelFormat(.generic.CommandRequest) returns(GetPixelFormatTritonCameraResponse) {}

      Response: message GetPixelFormatTritonCameraResponse {
      string pixel_format = 1;
      .generic.CommandResponse cmd_response = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      pixel_format Current Pixel Format of Triton Camera
      message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python tritoncamera.py GetPixelFormat Triton

      Description for CLI Command:

      • GetPixelFormat: API called to the Triton Camera through CLI Command
      • Triton: Alias of the Device

    9. SetGain

      Description of the API: Configures the gain setting for the Triton Camera.

      RPC Command: rpc SetGain(SetGainTritonCameraRequest) returns(.generic.CommandResponse) {}

      Request: message SetGainTritonCameraRequest {
      float gain_value = 1;
      CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
      }
       message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      gain_value Gain value to be Set in decibles. 0-48 decibles will be the range
      device_alias Unique alias of the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python tritoncamera.py SetGain Triton 40

      Description for CLI Command:

      • SetGain: API called to the Triton Camera through CLI Command
      • Triton: Alias of the Device
      • 40: Gain to be configured

    10. GetGain

      Description of the API: Captures the current gain setting of the Triton Camera.

      RPC Command: rpc GetGain(.generic.CommandRequest) returns(GetGainTritonCameraResponse) {}

      Response: message GetGainTritonCameraResponse {
      float gain = 1;
      .generic.CommandResponse cmd_response = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      gain Current Gain of Triton Camera
      message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python tritoncamera.py GetGain Triton

      Description for CLI Command:

      • GetGain: API called to the Triton Camera through CLI Command
      • Triton: Alias of the Device

    11. LoadCameraConfig

      Description of the API: Loads the camera's configuration from a pre-existing .txt feature file.

      RPC Command: rpc LoadCameraConfig(stream LoadConfigTritonCameraRequest) returns(.generic.CommandResponse) {}

      Request: message LoadConfigTritonCameraRequest {
      string file_name = 1;
      bytes config_data = 2;
      CommandRequest cmd_request = 3;
      }
       message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      file_name Indicates pre-existing configuration file (.txt format) to be loaded to the Camera
      config_data Represents camera features data like Gain, Time, Resolution, fps etc
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python tritoncamera.py LoadCameraConfig Triton tritonCameraConfig.txt

      Description for CLI Command:

      • LoadCameraConfig: API called to the Triton Camera through CLI Command to load camera features.
      • Triton: Alias of the Device
      • tritonCameraConfig.txt: Camera Features File to be Loaded to Camera

    12. SaveCameraConfig

      Description of the API: Saves Camera's Configuration in .txt file

      RPC Command: rpc SaveCameraConfig(SaveConfigTritonCameraRequest) returns(stream SaveConfigTritonCameraResponse) {}

      Request: message SaveConfigTritonCameraRequest {
      string file_name = 1;
      CommandRequest cmd_request = 2;
      }
       message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      file_name User defined .txt file name to be provided to save camera’s features.
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message SaveConfigTritonCameraResponse {
      optional bytes config_data = 1;
      optional string file_name = 2;
      optional int64 file_size = 3;
      CommandResponse cmd_response = 4;
      }
       message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      config_data Camera’s Features like fps, gain, time , height , etc
      file_name Name of File under which camera’s Configurations are saved
      file_size Indicates the size of the configuration file name received from the server
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python tritoncamera.py SaveCameraConfig Triton TritonCameraConfig.txt

      Description for CLI Command:

      • SaveCameraConfig: Name of the API
      • Triton: Alias of the Device
      • TritonCameraConfig.txt: User Defined file name in .txt format

    13. GetImage

      Description of the API: To Capture Single Image from Triton Camera with user defined name and Format

      RPC Command: rpc GetImage(GetImageFileTritonCameraRequest) returns(stream GetImageFileTritonCameraResponse) {}

      Request: message GetImageFileTritonCameraRequest {
      string file_name = 1;
      }
       message CommandRequest {
      string device_alias = 1;
      }
      Parameter Description
      device_alias The unique device_alias used to refer the device
      Response: message GetImageFileTritonCameraResponse {
      optional bytes image_data = 1;
      optional string file_name = 2;
      optional int64 file_size = 3;
      .generic.CommandResponse cmd_response = 4;
      }
       message CommandResponse {
      int32 resp_code = 1;
      string resp_description = 2;
      }
      Parameter Description
      image_data Indicates image data
      file_name Name of the image file with format. Supported file format are .jpeg , .png , .tiff and .bmp
      file_size Size of the captured image file
      resp_code Response code from the device API
      resp_description Description of the response code
      CLI Command: python tritoncamera.py GetImageFile Triton image.jpeg

      Description for CLI Command:

      • GetImageFile: API called to the Triton Camera through CLI Command to Capture and Save Image
      • Triton: Alias of the Device
      • image.jpeg: User Defined name with Format

    14. Precautions to take before executing the driver

      Ensure to load good configuration file through LoadConfig API to overcome any issues with driver.

      TESTING AND DEBUGGING

      Error Types and codes with Description for Triton Camera

      Error Type Error Code Error Description
      AC_ERR_SUCCESS 0 Operation completed successfully
      AC_ERR_ERROR -1001/td> Generic error
      AC_ERR_NOT_INITIALIZED -1002 Arena SDK not initialized
      AC_ERR_NOT_IMPLEMENTED -1004 Resource already in use
      AC_ERR_ACCESS_DENIED -1006 Null/incorrect handle
      AC_ERR_INVALID_ID -1007 Incorrect ID
      AC_ERR_NO_DATA -1008 No data available
      AC_ERR_INVALID_PARAMETER -1009 Null/incorrect parameter
      AC_ERR_IO -1011 Timed out
      AC_ERR_ABORT -1012 Function aborted
      AC_ERR_INVALID_BUFFER -1013 Invalid buffer
      AC_ERR_NOT_AVAILABLE -1014 Function not available
      AC_ERR_INVALID_ADDRESS -1015 Invalid register address
      AC_ERR_BUFFER_TOO_SMALL -1020 Resource cannot perform more actions
      AC_ERR_OUT_OF_MEMORY -1021 Not enough memory
      AC_ERR_BUSY -1022 Busy on another process
      Custom Error Code 4 File Format is not supported, Please Provide Correct File Format
      Custom Error Code 0003 Provided Pixel Format is Not Supported, Please Provide Correct Pixel Format
      Custom Error Code 0002 Invalid handle or camera not initialized.
      Custom Error Code 5 Invalid Gain. Should be from 0 to 48db
      Custom Error Code 6 Invalid Exposure Time. Should be from 45 to 462132 micro seconds

      RESOURCES AND LINKS

      • Arena SDK Sample Manual: Click Here
      • Download Arena SDK: Click Here
      • Triton Product Documentation: Click Here

      GLOSSARY

      Glossary of Terms for Triton Camera:

      • Driver: A software component that enables communication between the operating system and a hardware device, in this case, a camera.
      • SDK (Software Development Kit): A set of tools, libraries, and documentation that developers use to create software applications for a specific platform or framework.
      • API (Application Programming Interface): A set of rules and protocols that allow different software applications to communicate with each other.
      • Firmware: Software that is embedded into a hardware device, such as a camera, to control its operation.
      • Resolution: The number of pixels in an image, typically measured in megapixels (MP), that determines the level of detail and clarity in the image.
      • Frame Rate: The number of frames or images displayed or processed per second, often measured in frames per second (fps).
      • Gain: Gain in the context of a camera refers to the amplification of the signal from the camera sensor. However, increasing the gain too much can introduce noise into the image, reducing its quality. Gain is usually measured in decibels (dB).
      • Exposure Time: : The amount of light that reaches the camera sensor, controlled by settings such as shutter speed, and aperture.
      • Pixel: The smallest unit of a digital image, representing a single point of color.
      • Buffer: A temporary storage area in memory used to hold data, such as images, before it is processed or transferred.
      • Streaming: The process of continuously transmitting data, such as video, over a network in real-time.
